review_content:
2011 bottle from Folty shares at Heller’s Holiday Hoopla
Dark fruits and chocolate nose. Very mild notes of malt and taste presents caramel, raisin and a dry finish. Aged very well!
Bottle, dark brown color with an off white head. Nose and flavor were roasted malt, yeast, fruits, cacao, flowers, and spice. Carbonation was average with a silky smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle shared at Leightons place. Many thanks to Daniel Osprey for this one. A mid brown chestnut coloured pour with a halo of light tan head. Oil slick on top. Aroma semi sweet, grape, mint, age, oak, light medicinal. Flavour is composed of semi sweet. Brown sugars, red grape, some booze,. Palate is semi sweet, rounded, some oak, tannin,

2011 bottle thanks to Dan. It pours darkest brown to black with a small beige head. The aroma is sweet, sticky, roasted malt, liquorice, umami, coffee grounds, oak, leather and earth. The taste is dry, toothy, wood, leathery, liquorice, coffee grounds, bit of alcohol, boozy, hot, oxo cubes, roasty, spice and toothy action with a drying finish. Medium to full body and fine carbonation. Not bad.
2012 bottle friends brought. Not much of a saison. Aromas were dark malt, bit of spice. Flavors were like nose, mainly sweet. Aging didn't help it, maybe hurt.

1/15/17 (Chicago). 16 oz draft pour into chalice at Goose Island Tap Room ($6). Dark black pour, thin off white lacing. Toasty aroma and taste, accompanied by pepper. Easy drinking, overall good offering.

Dark brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, fruit, some floral, & spice; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit, some pepper, and spice; Finish is dry; Overall, wasn’t sure what to expect - good offering but not great.

Bottles from Rehill’s, Jesmond, Newcastle and The Bottle, Stonegate, York. 2011 Bottle drank on 2017-03-15. Hazy black-brown in colour with a thick white head. It has a rich, sweet cherry and dried fruity flavour followed by chocolate notes and spiced, slight tart fruit on the smooth, warming finish. Still excellent!
Usually not a Belgian or Saison beer guy, but this one was ok..Nice peppery aftertaste - wouldn’t want too many but this was pretty good.
Very dry with high effervescence and persistent head. Black and roasty with a good hop backbone.

Bottled on 6/11/12, an older vintage. Cola like appearance w big frothy head. Smoke, soy sauce, malt, and belgian yeast aroma. Almost no sweetness taste wise. I get smoked malt, slight dark fruit and lots of carbonation. Almost tastes like a smoked beer, in my opinion, which is not in my wheelhouse
A malt and hop aroma, pours a dark black color with a tan foamy head. Taste of smoked malt, dried fruit and hops. Pleasant to drink but not spectacular.

Næsten ugennemsigtig, og med et flot skum der holder i flere minutter.
Det dufter lidt af belgisk øl, som det skule være. Men smagen er hlet anerledes frugtagtig, med en eftersmag af noget fersken.

Ikke typisk belgisk i smagen, men god alligevel.
Pours a dark brown/gold color. Aromas of tart fruit, bread, hint of citrus, and yeasty. Flavor is malty/citrus. Leaves a yeasty hay/citrus aftertaste

Color of a dark cola, whispy yet resilient beige head. Aroma of tobacco, raisin, wood. Somewhat thin on the tongue but the caramel, cherries, and toffee carried it. Pretty good and a great dinner beer but I didn?t get much Belgian out of the beer as the label suggests...some notes of Belgian yeast did emerge in the finish as it warmed.

The aroma is kind of off and I’m not getting much flavor...it’s quite carbonated. My bottle is 2013 so I was ready for anything. Definitely has a dry finish...I’m starting to get the pepper taste now as the chill is subsiding. Maybe by the time I finish off the bottle I will be happier with it.

Bomber from 2011 vintage. Molasses and sweet dark fruit aromas from a nearly opaque very dark brown body with a ruby tinge and a good tan head. The molasses fades away on the sip with more of the dark fruit sweetness of cherries and plums coming through. This is followed by a cola taste and consistency and medium roast coffee. Some notes of dark and bittersweet chocolate. Body is a bit thin but may be due to the age on this bottle. Finishes with a slight sour note and more chocolate sweetness. I need to try a fresh bottle to compare this one to.

Dark black in color with thick foamy tan head... Aroma of Belgian malts, biscuits, rye malts... Hint of spice... Flavor is light chocolate malts, rye, bready malts, hints of peppercorn... Mouthfeel is fairly silky... Light spices on finish... Solid 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 ml bottle, 2013 Edition (had in late Summer 2015). Poutd a clearish ruby reddish dark brown to black with a short lived beige head. Aroma is red berries, roast, oldish, woody. Flavor is dark berry (blackberry, blueberry, black grapes), coffee and roast. Finish is dark chocolate, burnt, dusty and oldish. Lingering wood and dark fruits. Medium to full body, soft mouthfeel and weak to average carbonation.

I did not expect such a dark beer upon pouring. I was pleasantly surprised by the taste after seeing just how dark it is, because I feared it would be drowned in a coffee taste or something more bitter more typically associated with beers this dark, but it wasn’t like that. The coffee notes were subtle, and worked nicely. Nothing really stood out beyond that, and it wasn’t quite as smooth as I like, but it is a good beer. Is it worth the hefty price tag (something like $20 for a 750ml bottle)? No, I don’t think it is.

Was hoping for a golden ale for some reason. Charred flavor, not much Belgian yeast flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The aroma is life a porter with roasted malt and soapy hops. The appearance is like a porter. The palate is average. Overall a nice find but not a farmhouse.

A great combo of porter and a farm house. Some nuts, toast, cocoa powder and grain. Slight funk at the end with a smooth texture

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bottle from BrookFalls Discount. 6/13/12 bottle date. Note on the bottle says can age up to 5 years. Shrug? Chocolate brown foamy pour with a tan head leading nice lacing. Aroma has chocolate, caramel and tangy raisins. Later down the glass some herbs, some molasses and a bit of olive show through. Taste is of tangy caramel, light cocoa, some herbs, maybe mushroom (came and went). Medium bodied and effervescent. Finishes tangy and somewhat sweet. No idea what style they were going for, but certainly a different type tasting brew. Possibly a touch infected. And certainly 3 years old. 12.7

355ml bottle, trade with Skinnyviking. Lacing rings from an opaque mahogany coloured body. Tan-coloured head that stayed well. Moderate smell of earthy, brown and black malts, hints of molasses. Rather comprehensive taste of prunes, ash, molasses, and sweet liquorice offset by dark spices. Prolonged finish. Medium bodied. Pretty nice (Tromsø 17.09.2015).

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a head of foamy auburn colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a no visible carbonation opaque dark black colored body and a thick foamy lacing. The mild aroma was malty. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a medium mild malty aftertaste. The mild flavor contained notes of mild rye mild spice dark malt and crisp. An OK brew just nothing special.

Bottle at home. Dark black body with thin, tan head. Nose is smoky, malty, spicy. Taste is malty, caramel, dark chocolate, plums and fruity. Finished drier, again with chocolate kicking in. Not bad at all.

Tart pepper and spices aroma. Appearance is live body with lots of active legs. Quickly diminishing head. Kind of a spiced saison. Flavors are smoke, sour candy, cookie, pepper. Kind of unique even though I am not a huge fan.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark dark reddish brown. Tan, lively head, good retention. Aroma is spicy, yeast, dark fruits, roasted malt. Flavor is dark fruit, slightly tart, roasted malt on the finish. Dry, with a creamy finish and lively carbonation to start. Long, slightly spicy finish. ABV seems higher than 6.4%. This beer is nuanced; I’m a big fan.
2013 version. Pours reddish brown. Mellowed out nice with age. Mellow Brett, red wine and hazelnuts.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Tempo. Thanks Tom L. Very dark brown with a quickly dissolving head. Vinous aroma with some nuts, alcoholic, sweet, a little bitter and spicy taste. Medium body, vinous, spiced apple finish.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Tempo. Thanks Tom L. Brown with reddish hues. Soapy aroma, spicy, with tree sap, a bit of roast, olives. Sweetish flavor with caramel, roast, some spiciness. Medium-bodied.

Bouteille, Anno 2013, bottled 09/20/2013.
Brune foncée, col blanc-cassé moyen.
Arôme est malté grillé, pointe de levure belge, retrouve une note de mélasse et un côté herbacé , botanique-soda dont le poivré reste un peu en retrait.
Plais est malté, clairement orienté sur un côté belge dans la levure, petite note venant chatouiller la gorge, raisin, fruité noir, sucre candi. Malt carapils, pâle et chocolat. Retrouve une épaisseur caractéristique du seigle. Fini reste belge, grillé avec une fine note d’amertume houblonnée.
This looks, smells, and tastes like a slightly boozy Irish stout. Taste of rum and roast. Not a lot of floral.
2011 vintage bottle from Mark. Unique style and flavors from this American-Belgian Black Rye Saison. ----Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle from 2013. Pours black with a generous beige head. Aroma is a mixture or fruitiness and some roastiness. Fruity and spicy character up front on the palate which is balanced by a roasty finish with just a hint of smoke. Quite good and very interesting.

2013 750ml. Pours dark brown with a nice beige head. Head retention is good. AROMA: roasted malts, peppercorn, herbal/floral hops, caramel, chocolate, light coffee, slight citrus, smoke, vanilla and light candied sugar. TASTE: peppercorns, hop bitterness, slight citrus, caramel, coffee, chocolate, smoke, roasted coffee beans and light candied sugar. AFTER TASTE: caramel, coffee, peppercorns and very slight alcohol with an oily finish. Great tasting brew but I prefer Monkish Shaolin Fist over Pepe Nero.

Bottle.
Appearance: dark, mild head
Aroma: cereal, roasty, 
Taste: light sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate:light body, soft carbonation, not much finish
OK, Not a favorite
Version 2012, bue après 2 ans. Goût de baies confites, raisins secs et cassonade. Goût de madère évident mais cela ajoute une autre dimension au liquide.

duft. svag duft. lidt karamel lidt krydret
smag: karamel lidt røget eftersmag. lidt krydret.

Pours a dark brown with a gray-taupe head. Sweet and tart nose consisting fig, grape, brown sugar, bits of chocolate, and Belgian earthiness.  Smells like an appealing quad. Full body and a bit crisp. The flavor expresses the Belgian earthiness much more abundantly then what is detected in the nose. A blank, bitterish seltzer flavor persists throughout. Some tart grape. None of that wonderful brown sugar or chocolate in the flavor. At least none that can compete with the aforementioned ones.
Vintage bottle at Goose Island Clybourn. Poured very dark brown with light thin beige head. Aroma is nutty caramel malty. Light carb med bod. Taste is very dry very roasted malt.

Large bottle purchased at Haskells. Consumed with commonshawn. A dark brown nearly black color...even purple? Off white head. Aroma has unexpected chocolate elements plus some plum and espresso. Taste has Belgian qualities bringing to mind a less sweet, alcohol-centric quad or a milder, less spice-forward saison. The black pepper is very subtle but comes through towards the finish. Dark fruit tart and funk can be found. Very interesting beer. Just short of excellent.

Big bottle from Haskells with commonmac. Almost black with off white head. Smells plum and raisin and some nearly chocolate sweetness. Almost a chocolate porter malt initial taste. then spicy dark fruit and slight alcohol. Lingering taste is spicy and peppery and nice. Very interesting and unique profile to this one. Quite complex.
Dark brown color , thin off-white head. Pepper , wood , yeasts in roasted aroma - the strange combination for my sense of smell. Rich taste of roasted/ smoked malt , yeasts and fruits . Dry finish.
Roasted caramel malt aroma. Deep dark brown body. Thick fluffy off white head. Smokey roasted malt taste. Clean wet finish.

Thanks Bill for sending.
This was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a dark brown ranging close to black in color with a creamy close to off white colored slim foamy head that dissipated within less than a minute. Light lacing strings in and out along the glass.
The smell had a light pepper spice over top of a smoky yeasty/slightly breadiness.
The taste was pretty much the same with a slight added roasted nutty note to lead to a semi-sweet smoky and yet spicy aftertaste that’s very nice. There was a semi-dry finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a tolerable sessionability about it. The carbonation is so smooth and helps to lead to creamy palatable quality rolling over my tongue.
Overall, I’d say that this was a very good dark saison. I’d definitely have it again.
Dark black. Thin head. Oily. Peppery. Sweet brown sugar. Somewhat woody. Thanks Casey.
Bottle at home. Pours deep brown, nose is peppery, spicy, roasty, taste is similar, fruity.

From the 12 oz bottle. Pours a reddish black with a Thick off white head. Dry Belgian yeast esters, spicy rye aroma. Smooth spicy malt body with peppery 
and clove notes in the taste.
Terrible example of the style. Tasted more like a stout then anything else. Shame.
Thick rye flavor. 2011 bottle. Spice and sweetness are balanced. Enjoying the smoothness. Deep color. Says 6% but since it was a 2011 I think it has increased. Very good.

Bottle @ Three Notch’d Tasting. Browish pour with a small off-white head. Aroma of red apples and earthy toast. Flavor of yeasty fruits. Toasted grain and spice. Mellow sweet finish. Medium body, active carbonation. Pretty forgettable, but decent.

Pours dark amber with small tan head out of bottle. Aroma of malt and spice. Flavor similar to smell but with characteristics of an amber ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I home brewed a dark bitter saison that this reminded me a whole lot of. Except this had some age on it, and it was crisp. So basically my home brew plus aged and mashed at a lower temp. Gonna nail it.

12 Oz bottle. Pours black with an off-white head. Flavor and aroma changes a lot as it warms. When cold, lots of banana on the nose. As it warms, more malt comes through, especially molasses. Flavor is sweet with bready malt, molasses and citrusy yeast. Finishes with citrusy yeast and some hints of roasted malt. Medium body with a slick mouthfeel. Overall, interesting complexity to this. More like a dunkel Weiss, but complex malt.
Bottle in FL. Pleasant light aroma. Hard to place flavors. Fruity but not tart. Not bitter. Proper carbonation. Intricate tasty beverage
Very light smell, malty, carbonated, nothing unique behind the up front maltiness, decent

12oz bottle - 

A really nice, albeit different, beer. Unlike an America Black Ale, which still maintains most of an IPA characteristics, this didn’t maintain many saison characteristics, let alone just a few. This could have been some kind of smoked ale to be quite honest, but it was tasty. Aroma light/medium cofee and a touch of dark chocolate, some soy, a bit earthy but mostly coffee and earthy. Out of left field comes a smokey/peaty flavor, combining with the coffee note (which isn’t very pronounced), some soft spice and a bit of coca-cola thrown in there makes this pretty intriguing. I definitely enjoyed it and look forward to my other 3 bottles.

Belle couleur noire avec plusieurs reflets brun et un col beige qui résiste. En bouche c’est décevant, gout un peu étrange d’épices avec une finale de grains grillés. C’est moyennement complexe... Décevant...

Brassin 2013. Bouteille de 750 ml achetée à la LCBO (Hawkesbury, ONT) au coût de 12,80$. Arôme: Odeur de céréales avec une pointe de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est noire avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence d’un large col beige mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de céréales grillées avec une pointe d’épices. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de céréales grillées en arrière goût. (Rating #5835)
765 ml bottle. Pours a dark brown colour with a medium to large tan head. Aroma is malts, rye. Taste is malts, spices, chocolate.
Smells of black raspberries. Pitch black color. Low head. Licorice taste amid a heavy malt body. Unbitter. Complex and heavy. Like it.
Pitch black, nice Lacey head. Some licorice, blackberry nose. Blackberry tingling taste. licorice building up . Medium aftertaste

Bottle from deeside drinks emporium. Bottled on 15/01/2013 Pours an almost jet black with a off white head which slowly fades. Excellent lacing. Aromas of smoke, boozy plum and a little of that typical Belgian whiff. Flavour is a smokey treacle with a slight peppery hint. Has a nice sweetness to the finish that resembles a boozy plum again. Lovely intricate beer.

February 2013 bottle drank in September 2014. 1.5 years old. 
Dark brown with a red tint, with a disappearing, frothy, thin, creamy head. Nice sweet smell of malt with rye, prunes and a peppery, smokey sour cherry touch. Caramel. Medium to full oily body with no carbonation. A slight dry finish. Initial taste of bitter nut with a caramel middle and a cherry yeasty, liquorice finish. Leaves the mouth with a sour prune lingering. I never thought of a saison like this. Very easy to drink and super excited aged some more.

# 3514
ersma: wie der name schon impliziert mit schwarzem pfeffer gebraut. auf der flasche ist zu lesen, dass sie lebendige hefe enthält und bis zu fünf jahre weiterreift. warum dnn schluss ist, wird nicht erläutert.
pechschwarz im glas, oben viel beige-bräunlicher schaum, der recht stabil ist.
der geruch ist süßlich und röstmalzig, aromen von lakritz und vanile, etwas schoko und etwas pfeffer.
der antrunk ist röstmalzig mit viel karamell, dazu lakritz und schoko, dahinter eine leichte schärfe, die zur mitte schon deutlicher wird. da ich ja mehrere biere mit tabasco oder szechuanpfeffer braue, weiß ich, dass diese schärfe sich mit jedem schluck addiert. der abgang bringt anflüge von hopfenherbe mit, aber nur anflüge. die schärfe wird etwas ausgeprägter, ohne wirklich scharf zu sein, das kommt halt erst nach mehreren schlucken. karamell und lakritz sind noch vorhanden, nehmen jedoch deutlich ab. 
die flasche mit dem mattschwarzen etikett ist ansehnlich.
fazit: schön ausbalanciertes belgisches ale, dem der pfeffer noch das besondere gibt. unbedingt probierenswert.
13,12,11,11,13,11 - 11,45 		28/9/14

"Not sure why i hadn’t reviewd this yet, but here goes. While a very well crafted beer, the combination of dark malts and a saison type beer is a stylistic miss for me. This gives the impression that it is about as good as the style gets. I just prefer a light sunshiney feel to my saisons, and black malt cant really pull that off. the chocolate roastiness and pepper combo was interesting, though. I’d have this brew again fo sho, just wouldnt seek it out."

33cl bottle. Pours clear, dark brown with a small, short lasting, light brown soda-head. Aroma has malty roast and caramel, slightly bready grains, some chocolate and some herbs. But overall not a whole lot of aroma in this one. Taste has a bit more funk to it, some hop-bitterness, and some more fresh, subtle bitter-sour notes. Still these roasty licorice, coffee and chocolate-notes. Really easy drinking with a fairly high carbonation and a smooth body.

(bottle - 12 oz - 2011 vintage) Dark brown pour with a fluffy tan head. Slightly chocolatey and roasted aroma overtop a spicy and peppery yeast note. Flavor has a lot of that spicy farmhouse earthy flavor at the start with a roasted chocolate and burnt malt bitterness coming up at the end.

765 ml bottle purchase at The LCBO on Rideau and King Edward (Ottawa) on August 24, 2014. Black, small head. Malty pepper aroma, some ripe fruit notes. Pepper and fruit juice taste, a bit of dry yeast, very spicy aftertaste. The peppercorn is really not over done in this saison!

765ml bottle. Clear cola colour body, medium mocha head with good retention. Aroma of yeast, toast, licorice, delicate smokiness, raisins, earthy notes. Taste of roasted malts, smoke, licorice, yeast, a touch of woodsy notes. Light. Gets better when warms up.

Transfer from BA review on 1-8-13-

 Poured from bottle into a tulip glass with a bottled on date of 5/22/12. The label says it can be aged up to 5 years after bottling.

 Appearance – Pours a cola colored brew with a huge tan head. The head has huge carbonation bubbles entrapped within, which slowly pop over time to leave a light level of lacing on the sides of the glass

 Smell – The aroma is bready and yeasty with hints of some apple within. Accompanying these smells are notes of banana and some dark chocolate smells.

 Taste – The taste starts out with a smoother blend of roasted malt and hints of chocolate. It begins without much of a saison taste, only to develop it more as the taste advances beyond the initial. Some fruit flavors come to the tongue rather quickly off the start being mainly of a banana and light fruit flavor. These remain rather light and are soon meet with some grassy and herbal tastes. A yeasty taste also soon comes to the tongue with the flavor now starting to develop more of a saison like flavor. In the end some bitter chocolate with an increase in a more bitter herbal flavor and some black pepper come to the tongue. These flavors all combined in a rather awkward way to leave a rather odd dark roast, light fruit and bitter herbal flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel- The body of the beer is quite light with a carbonation level that is on the lower to medium side. This is a tough one as I can’t say if a creamier body for the roasted flavor would have been better or if staying with a thinner body for the fruit, yeast and herbal flavors was the better rout to take. The same goes for the carbonation.

 Overall – Well nothing I really cared a whole lot about for the price that you pay. The tastes were a little confused with none of the flavors really melding well together. The nose, appearance and mouthfeel for me were all just average as well. It may be worth a try, but this is one I will likely not go back too.
Bottle. 2 years old. Pours dark brown with big long-lasting tan head. Nose is dark fruit and caramel. Taste has a carbonation bite. Nice caramel and rye spice. Tastes like a spicy dubbel.

Nice strong light brown head of dense and creamy bubbles with very good carbonation. Aroma of rootbeer, licorice, roasted grains and fresh air in the spring. Color is a very dark brown. Rather darl for a "saison". Fizzy in the mouth with a little bit of tartness, more roasted grains, rye and some salt water. Funishes dry with a bit of lingering tartness. A pretty good but strange brew.

330ml bottle from Appellation Wines, cheers Ash! Pours opaque brown with a thin off-white head. Aromas of sourdough bread, rye, spice. Taste is spice, dark sugar, molasses. Finishes very clean and crisp. Nice.
Slight roasty aroma. Black in color with little head. Taste is roasty. Faint sourness, slight pepperyness
Dark brown, stable light tan head. Roasted aroma, fruit, caramel. Flavour is sweetish, fruity and malty with discrete alcohol. Finish is light spicy with nice alcohol notes.

Saison bien brune, rappelant même la couleur et la texture du cola, avec une petite mousse en film à la surface ; le nez est dominé par des raisins, du caramel et du sucre d’orge, avec un je ne sais quoi de vanillé, comme un baril de chêne. La bouche est ronde, caramélisée comme une red ale, la levure se perd dans le malt très costaud et c’est dommage. Au final c’est une rousse avec une levure de saison trop faible et du seigle sans réelle personnalité. Une belle bière, mais je ne comprends pas le "hype".
Bottle. Dark brown with a small head. Smooth with some fruitiness. Medium body and left no lacing. Not a great one but still pretty pleasant to drink.
Bottle - dark pour (tan head) with a spicy aroma. Roasted malts and somewhat peppery. Mild roasty and a smoky flavor. Medium mouthfeel.
Pours black. Aroma and taste are roasted malts, spices, and has a sweet finish.

From a bottle. Pours dark brown with a bubbly tan head. Tastes like dry raisin, swet roasted malt, and some nice black peppercorn. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like light raisin, roasted malt, and a little sweetness, and a little pepper.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with frothy beige head. Aroma is bready malts, light wheat, Belgian yeast esters, light grassiness, faint chocolate, and faint spice. Flavor is dry malt base, light roast, some chocolate, some dark fruit esters, and light hops; dry finish with some Belgian yeast sweetness lingering. Medium body and carbonation.

12-JUL-2014, bottle @Kregme.
Dark Brown with huge tan head.
Aroma is Brown sugar, cherry, bread, smoke.
Taste the same. Sweet, tart. Huge carbonation, medium body. Nice.

Pours a deep burgundy / black with a thick beige head. Certainly an interesting mix of smoke, pepper, dark cherries and roasted malts with a creamy texture. Really thought I would enjoy this more. Will try again when I’m feeling a bit more depressed.
12 oz bottle. Dark brown pour with a thick light tan head. Aroma of peppers, faint smoke, earthy funk and burnt caramel. Medium body with a slight warming alcohol finish.

Beer #1500 (2012 bottle). An AB-InBev product. Thanks to Rob and Ally for sharing this! Aroma: More smokey than expected, almost peat-like in some way; roast never tends toward coffee. Pepper is hanging around, creeping around the edges; ointment. Appearance: Dark garnet brown with a foamy tan head that settles into a bubbly skin. Flavor: Smokey, peppery, still can’t shake that peat note. Pepper ever present, but not powerful. Ointment more apparent toward finish. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, long finish. Overall: Definitely an interesting approach to a Saison. Not sure if I enjoyed it that much, however.
2011 bottle. Dark brown pour with a beige head. Aromas of black pepper and dark fruits with notes of yeast. Flavor is spicy rye with dark fruit and some funk. Pretty solid.

Deep brown in colour with a thin but long lasting beige head, excellent lacing. The aroma is of pepper, light spice, dark fruits, yeast and bread. The flavour is of chocolate, rye bread, malty, yeasty with some citrus tang, fruit. Lightly yeasty mouthfeel, medium body, moderate carbonation. Finishes long and yeasty, good malt bite. A pretty nice dark saison, love the rye in this.


765ml bottle from the LCBO in Peterborough, Ontario.

Bottled on May 28, 2013.
Bottle from Ashley. Dark pour with a brown head. Aroma is fruit, sour, and spices. Taste is the same but super toasty. Grape, raisin finish.

From the 2013 bottle dated 21/MAR/13. Gorgeous dark brown to near black pour with long lasting soft tan head. The aroma has some nice dark malts, yeast, light spice, and sour notes to it. Bold body. The taste is sweet and sour actually with the sour notes not too tart and not too off-putting.
Definitely the best saison that I’ve ever tasted. A little tart, and incredibly smooth.
Khaki top with brown underneath. Yeast bread aroma with anise malt flavor. Slight sweet finish.

Draft pour. Pours black with a cream head. I’ve never seen a saison like this before, and almost thought I was poured the wrong beer. Slightly sour fruit aroma. The is beer is so smooth. So so smooth. Really nice peppery flavor with some darker fruit. A little tart at first, with a mild roasted finish. I have nothing but good things to say about this beer. Another solid from these guys.

ベルギー スタイル ファームハウス エール
スタウトっぽいが、苦味がしっかりあり、甘さや濃い味と良くあってる 
黒にしては、かなり美味しい

765 ml bottle from LCBO, dated 2013. Chestnut brown with tan head. Roasted malt on the nose with sweet cola, herbal (anise) and spicy notes. Taste has some anise or licorice notes, cola, cocoa, herbs. Easy drinking an enjoyable. Not much like any saison I’ve had, but a good beer no less.
Bottle. Black with a big khaki head. Yeasty, bread dough, light rye and molasses. Taste is mildly sweet with a yeasty flavor. Body is heavier with a foamy feel.
Enjoyable, easy smooth beer, some toffe taste. I liked it, would love to try it on tap. Might be a bit to pricey to purchase again however.

Ins Glas ergießt sich ein sehr dunkel rötlichbraunes Bier mit schöner beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, fruchtig, leicht rauchig. Geschmack röstmalzig, rauchig, Schinken, leicht fruchtig, etwas würzig.

Rated on 7-19-2011 (Bottled on 01/07/11) The appearance is a medium sized frothy, fizzy tan head that mostly diminishes, dark brown opaque body, fizzy carbonation, and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is malt, roasted, yeast, funky, sweet, and spicy. The taste is spice, malt, yeast, roasted, and funky. This beer has a semi-dry finish. The mouthfeel is tingly carbonation and this beer is light-medium bodied. This beer is quaffable and the roastiness comes out as the beer warms.

On tap at Zeno’s. Nice roasted barley nose, light spicy rye notes. Chocolate and some smoke. Dark brown-black clear with thin off-white head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts fairly dry with roasted barley, light smoke, and cocoa. Spicy rye character with light hop fruity finish. Medium smooth after.

Dark for looks light to taste. Pepe Nero is marketed as a Belgian style ale. Malty with notes of fruits and light pallet always leaves you wanting more. 7/10

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: we can detect very clearly notes of smoked meat; even smoked ham. aroma profile is rapidly decreasing leaving space for alcohol. Subtle notes of herbal hops are also showing up. Not very impressive aroma.
Appearance: Black with red glints and translucent. An enormous and eternal foamy head sticking to glass a bit and leaving some traces.
Taste: Attack is showing notes of smoke with a thin texture feel. Finish is dry with a little metallic aftertaste. Smoke accents are dominant with some molasses and anise notes. the use of roasted malts is giving it an earthy and ashy aspect with a very dry finish. Sparkling is active but not excessive; texture is somehow thin and herbal hops are mixing well with the roasted aspect of it’s flavor palette. Une bière hors norme, difficilement classable. Mais puisqu’il faut la classer dans un style, classons la dans saison. Mais avec de fortes tendances porter. Quand même agréable à boire.

pours unclear medium dark brown-reddish with a small light beige head, some retention and lacing. spicy yeastiness - pepper, red grape juice - fruity it is but awkward, grainy spiciness, cola, cherry coke, torrefied malts, bitter coffee, slightly ashy and smoky. lively carbonation - almost foamy, light body, dry bitter and lightly astringent grassy-spicy finish. blah.

355 ml bottle.

Pours dark red, almost black color with a large off-white head. Aroma has lots of berries, some ripe fruits as well as some yeast, subtle spice notes on the background. Flavor is a bit malty, some dark berries, rye and faint caramel, yeast and subtle spices. I don’t really like the malt and rye notes here at all, Saisons should be refreshing and at least moderately citric and fruity, this attempt fails on both accounts. I’ve had better rye-saisons. A great disappointment.

4334
bottle. Brown with small head. The peppery flavor here does not work for me at all. Medium malt body with some dark fruit and smoke.
Dark brown, fruity, prunes, light chocolate, has a fizzy character with light chocolate and a fair bit of Belgian yeastiness.
Brune foncé. Beau collet blanc. Nez poivrée. Épicé. Légèrement boisé. Cacao. Herbacé. Bouche: ronde. Chocolaté. Cacao. Florale. Acidulé. Orange. Boisé. Légèrement poivré. Très particulier.
Pours out a dark brown that closely resembles a cola. Aroma still has the spiciness you would expect from a saison, but it also has a caramel and toasted smell. Taste is smokey and very enjoyable.

Bottle - near black with slim beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, smokiness, liquorice, dark fruits. Flavours are roasted malts, smoke, raisins, plums. Medium to full bodied, moderately carbonated. Quite pleasant.
Bottle at bar. Black color, beige head. Bitter taste with hops, citrus, roasted malts, caramel and pine. Bitter finish with citrus, raspberries and roasted malts. Very nice brew.

Brune foncée aux mèches rougeâtres, son col mousseux s’amincit rapidement. Un bouquet complexe de fruits rouges confits, de toffee et de céréales sucrées est relevé de notes fumées subtiles. Majoritairement sucrée, les céréales sont très présentes, contrairement à l’aspect poivré qui semble s’avoir dissipé avec le temps. Pensez à un vin d’orge moins costaud et houblonné. Intéressante cette bière, mais je m’attendais à mieux.

Bouteille âgée d’un an.

March 9, 2014. 750mL bottle from LCBO. Very dark, opaque black with tan head. Nice lacing. Roasted malt, hints of raisins and plums in aroma. Lovely peppery flavour, very lively in the mouth and smooth. Quite nice.

Bottled. Dark mahogany to ruby color, weak head. Smoky aroma or malts, a touch of brandy, bakers yeast, sour rye bread, fermented dark berries, dried fruits (raisins). Herbal and woody hop notes. Dry, slightly sour malty flavor. Rye is gives spicy feeling. Dry fruits and woody bitter finish with yeasty esters and pepper. Medium body, smooth and frothy carbonation.

I picked up a b0ttle 0f this at the l0cal F00d 4 Less. N0t a bad price. It l00ked like a c0la with a tall f0amy head and left cl0tty lacew0rk in its wake. It smelled sweet,candy-like, with dark fruit and a t0uch 0f fl0ral funk. The flav0r c0ntinued with the dark fruit, a hit 0f w00d sm0ke, lightly sweet, with a t0uch 0f anise. 0kay.
i dont usually like saisons much, but the peppercorns and rye help to mellow it out. i dont like the heavier carbonation though. too much like a soda.

Pours a dark brown with an orange glow and a tan head. The smell is roasted malt, molasses, spice, yeast. The taste is spice, roasted dark malt, molasses, yeast ending dry. The body is medium with tight carbonation.

Tastes pretty good. Similar to the sofie, but a bit maltier. A little bit of licorice flavors to balance out the breadiness from the yeasts. Pretty strong molasses aromas as well, almost like a doppelbock.. Not really sure what the rye does, but the beer was pretty smoky for the style. Can’t really say that it added anything besides an interesting dimension though. Would drink again, and also wouldn’t heartily recommend.

Bottled on 02/24/11

This one have developed really well. 
Mature notes of strawberry/raspberry jam in the nose. 
Taste follows the aroma, with a mild roasty and smokey suprise in the finish. Simple and clean.
As it warms up a light note of butter begins to show, but it doesn’t disturb, now it smells like a roasted butter jam sandwich.

I’ve had 2 bottles of this batch and they have been exceptionally good, with a big difference from all other Pepe Neros I’ve had.

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy dark brown with shades of ruby and airy but very stable light tan head. Clear aroma of fruit, malt, and caramel, with hints of hops and alcohol in the long nose. Sweetish, fruity notes, enhanced by touches of malt and caramel. Notes of hops and pepper. Mildly spicy and sweetish finish. A nice one.

Pours a dark brown on the bottom and black on top. Head is off white and long lasting. Aroma of cherry, roasted coffee and fresh pine. Taste of roasted coffee, maple, smoked cherrywood with a classic Belgium yeast. As it warms it develops complex new flavors. You get a more warming alcohol followed by sweet/tart cherry bitter dark chocolate. Tangerine and banana follow well at the very end. Smoky/dry finish. Not overwhelming, very drinkable. I'm a huge fan of robust porters and the roast character in this beer is very enjoyable. Really good beer. If you love robust porters and Belgium beers you must try this!
2011 bottle. Pours A thick dark deep brown with thick carmel head with good head retention . Aroma of roasted malt
2011 Bottle. Awesome head retention. Nice spicy smell. Very light, clean finish. Dark cherry, vanilla, mineral finish. Probably wouldn’t cellar again, better fresh.

Very dark brown pour, big, billowy off white head. Peppery aroma, dried, dark fruit, yeasty and bready, with some spice. A cross between a dubbel and a saison. Light roasty notes, some nuts and more musty fruit. Finish is clean and dry with low bitterness. Minerals linger in the end with a sweet yeasty, breadiness. The roast caps it off, with a touch more of the spice.

Bottle - BCA - Bottled Apr 2011, BBE Apr 2016, Drank Jan 2013 - Dark Reddish Brown in colour. Good carbonation; thick foamy tan head. Malty; lightly roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, some coffee, smoky notes, hint of nuts; includes black rye. Yeasty and spicy; peppery. Fruity; dark fruits. Hoppy. Roasty malty yeasty spicy fruity and dry throughout; slight fruity sourness. Dry yeasty finish. Nice Beer!

765ml Bottle from my local LCBO. Pours a dark opaque brown, thick foamy tan head that sticks around with lacing, high carbonation. Not getting much nose of this, malts and that’s about it. Taste of that lovely yeast that seems indicative of a good Belgium-style beer, malts, hints of smoke. Not the best beer from the Island.

On tap. Ruby brown color with tan head. Nice dark rye bread, roasty, herbal, earthy dirt, Saison spice aromas. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation. Dry hay, medium roast malt, bready, Saison spicy yeast flavors____lightly drying finish---good.
Interesting blend of roasty and tart. Rather light bodied, but packed full of flavor. Has some slight coffee, chocolate, pepper, and tartness.
Black, thick beige head; aroma is yeasty, dark fruits; taste is malt, smoke, ash, dark fruits; yeasty, dry finish; enjoyable.
Bottled sample from happy harrys. My first black saison. Pours brownish with minimal head. boozy tasting and delicious

@ Party Source / Bellvue KY Clear, very dark mahogany with a spotty head cover, sheet of lace rising 1" out of the drink. Taste is slightly sour malt with dark fruit that becomes more pronounced in the palate. The finish returns to a slight sourness. Overall, acceptable, but not as complex as it seems it should be, and a long way from the saisons with which I’m familiar.

2014.01.21 - Goose Island Pepe Nero - 12oz bottle in pint glass. 2012 vintage - bottled 04/17/2012

Aroma: smells like a Belgian Strong Ale. Hints of coffee, some dried fruit.

Appearance: Pours around upper 30s on SRM scale. Deep walnut brown with reddish highlights. Mostly opaque. 1-2 finger foamy tan head lingers, dissipates slowly to a tan slick.

Taste: somewhat but not overly complex, basically a complex malty fruity front with a bit of roast quickly followed by mild alcohol heat and a mild tart end. Agree with characterization below, more hoppy and mild grass.

Palate/Mouthfeel: medium, a bit creamy. 

Overall: It’s definitely in my ballpark and clearly vying for me as a customer given I like big Belgian ales. Ultimately I am hit or miss on Saisons ( and this seems like a pretty heavy dark saison) and there are other Goose Island brews in this series that I prefer. Not bad though.

Aroma 5/10, Appearance 3/5, Taste 6/10, Palate 3/5, Overall 12/20
Bottle. Brown with slight reddish tint, spongy large beige head, caramel aroma, high carbonation, caramel-mocha taste mixed with roasted malt, longish finish. Very similar to a good porter.
Floral aroma. Nice pour, no head. Very light Begian taste with a bit of chocolate and malt.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Opaque pour. Nice foamy white head up front. Dark spicy malt with some dark red sour fruit. Chocolate nibs. Spicy dark tropicals. Prunes. Somewhat bizarre mix of flavors, but works quite well. Well worth trying.

765ml bottle, bottled 02/12/13, deep dark brown color, with a fluffy beige-kaki head, with a nice belgian yeast, faint chocolate nose, with some light dark dried fruit, chocolate chip cookie dough, raisin pie accents, and a toasted, biscuity, chocolate, caramel malt, faint spicy pepper corn, mocha, apple sauce note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a good fruity, doughy, yeasty, mild dark bitter chocolate, spicy pepper corn, dark dried fruit character, with some roasted, toasted, caramel malt, chocolate chip cookie dough, chocolate pie crust, faint mocha, chocolate ice cream, apple sauce flavours, leading towards a yeasty, doughy, dark dried fruit fruitiness, faint dark bitter chocolate, mild pepper corn spiciness finish.
Bottle->tulip. Deep brown with huge frothy lite tan head. A: spice, apple, coffee, Belgian yeast. T: light malt, herbs, dark fruits and herbal hops. Zesty. Interesting.
Cola appearance with a big fluffy head. Yeasty aroma, some fruitiness. Taste is saison yeast, light peppery, sweet malt, dark fruit. Seems lacking, but nice anyways.

I’m getting a nice kick out of the aroma...big wheat and Belgian yeast and dark fruits. The smell kind of indicates that I’m going to enjoy drinking it.

Wheat and yeasty flavours there, pretty much dominated by a strong peppery flavour. The pepper doesn’t add a whole lot of heat at all and the flavours do not mesh all that well, imho. I guess it’s spicy for spicy sakes and not much to it. It gets a bit trying on my palate after several sips. The abv is reasonably low so it isn’t THAT hard to drink. I wish is was a bit more complex, in a good way.

Nice and smooth mouthfeel. Again, I think it’s what, too one dimensional? If that makes any sense. This is not a brew I’d bIt pours a very dark brown, has reddish hues, a small head of foam that shrinks quickly but leaves some good lacing behind.
uy again but I’ve said that about brews from most of the breweries I’ve had the chance to try. No slant on Goose Island intended.

22 ounce bottle. Bottled on 4/16/2012. Pours a translucent dark brown color with a tight bubbly tan head. Sweet roasted malt aroma has notes of prunes, chocolate liqueur and dark cherries. Rich, chewy sweet roasted malt flavor has an underlying dried dark fruit component. The yeasty, fruity saison-like character is here with the added touch of complex spicy rye grain and dark roasted maltiness. Their is a touch of earthy, smokiness here as well. Finishes with a sweet soy and plum maltiness.

2013 edition at the LCBO, in a brown wine bottle, but with a beer cap. Bottled 12 FEB 2013. Pours a dark copper colour with a dark beige head, decent retention and some creamy lacing. Looks clean so far. Aromas of sweet malts with mild dark fruits, chocolate notes and some light Belgian Ale yeast. Gets sweeter with time and even candy shows up. The taste is not as sweet though. More on the hoppy side with mild grass, creating a little dry mouthfeel. Yeast over the light spices. Wishing more of the flavours for this one, but nice to have a dark Saison.  Note: the 2014 version does have a little more taste, with the roasted malts showing in the aftertaste. Not a bad brew.

Thanks for this in a trade to Dhren1979, cheers Doug!
Bottled: 02/2011

A: Pours opaque, black. Single finger, light mocha, loose foam head dissipates within a minute and leaves thin sheet of the same. Spotty lacing.

S: Classic saison: farm, coriander, belgian yeast, lemon peel. Hints of peppercorn. 

T: Again, classic saison: belgian yeast, lemon peels, nuts, earth. The dark malts finally make their appearance here with a nice, dry roasty back end. Nice, fresh as a style.

M: medium with lively carb. typical of the style. Leaves palate dry with slight slick.

D: This beer is very nice. Not among the better saisons I’ve tried, but then again, I’m new to the style.

Serving type: bottle

03-07-2011

Pours a deep black brown with a lighly cinnamon head. Aroma is moderate black pepper, mildly toasty. Flavor is moderately toasty with a mildly hopped finish. Slightly sticky body. Not wild about this one.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a deep ruby red with a thick tan head that sticks around. Some lacing is left behind. Aroma is of licorice, roasted malt and some yeast. Lively carbonation, little spice on the tongue, some malt in the background. Slight dry finish with some sourness. Interesting.

Une bouteille de 12 onces datée du 13 mars 2013. Un liquide brun et une tête beige respectable. Un nez de levure épicée avec des arômes légers de malts rôtis et de chocolat. Quelques notes de cerises apparaissent au fil de la dégustation. En bouche, le caractère fumé du malt se confirme. Les fruits me semblent être ici légèrement surets. Des épices piquent mes papilles. Au palais, le corps crémeux est contrôlé par un pétillement faible. En finale, c’est un mélange de levure et de malts rôtis qui me font grimacer de façon nettement étrange.

Bottle (22 oz). From TheJester, thanks! Brown with a huge fully lasting beige head and good lacing. Aroma is of liquorice/anise, belgian yeast, some sweetness and peppercorns. Taste is moderately sweet but never cloying with anise, peppercorn, yeast, smoke, and light caramel. Medium body. Good carbonation. Dry/spicy finish. Good dark Saison. Nice spiciness. Drinkable and tasty.

A unique beer with a great range of subtle flavors. Rye, spice, dark chocolate, light smoke, sugar and yeast. I want to marinade some pork chops in this stuff. Light bodied. Really nice; a session beer with a lot of character.
Bottle. Very dark brown...almost black. Small off white head. Sweet roasty malt aroma. Smoky toffee flavor with some spice. Nice balance. Smooth and light.

Bottle, shared with my folks over the Thanksgiving weekend. Pours a dark brown color, modest light mocha head. Nose is a little of the fruity yeast, cocoa, and light florals. The assertiveness of the peppercorns caught me off guard at first, but towards the end of the glass it balanced out with the dry, smoky, and chocolate notes. A little more of the fruity yeast, but dry and spicy. Lively is a good descriptor. Enjoyable.
Bottle. Deep brown with some ruby and a big, beige head. Red fruit and toffee aromas. Caramel, toffee and fruit.

Pours chocolate brown with a generous pillowy tan head. Dark fruit and cocoa aromas prevail with the signature notes of Belgian yeast and some citrus. Flavor starts with some subtle smokiness, transitions into sweet yeastiness and finishes with a peppery kick. I’ve never had a saison quite like this before. I’m definitely a fan.

[Bottle / 2011 / 2 years old] Thanks, Jeff! Deep mahogany & ruby body that appears almost black in the glass, topped with a khaki head; nice, foamy, & creamy. A touch of wet lacing. Aroma is mild; roasted malt, toasted bread, faint caramel, a touch of yeasty esters, banana pudding, a hint of wet hay, & some light, rye-like dryness. Taste is very flavorful... roasted malt, a hint of sweet smoke, light peppercorn, a touch of peat, some zesty yeast flavors, toasted bread, very faint cocoa dust, a touch of banana cream esters, & a bready, yeasty finish. Wasn’t expecting much from this but I really enjoyed it.

From 12oz bottle. 

Pours dark with a light brown head. Malt/fruit/sour aroma. Taste follows. Saisons are not my favorite, but this is drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle - Yeast, pomegranate, rye and dark malts. Mahogany, clearish and bubbly beige head. Dark molasses, spicy grains, yeast and booze. Nice, dark and complex. My first dark saison and I like it.

Black pour, definately saison based, but has quite a bit more dark fruit. Grapes sweet prunes. Almost wine like without the carbonation or that suck the moisture out of your mouth feeling. Dont get much of the smoke cjocolate or pepper others are mentioning, just lots of fruit and a touch of belgian yeast.

12 oz. on tap. Opaque chocolate with a lasting creamy film of lace. Smells of dark berry, chocolate, and earthy dark grape must. Flavor is the same, plus some delicate touches of char and soy in the finish. Creamy and smoothly carbonated medium body is well balanced and sessionable.

Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown like a good dark porter. Medium tan head with light lacing. Taste is much lighter than one would expect with pepper and spices undertone. Very effervescent on the torque. Not a bad change of pace!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured black out of bottle with aromas of yeast and rye. Taste of chocolate dark fruit spices. Finishes with a bit of bitterness.

35,5cl bottle from Microbar, Manchester. Pours very dark brown with a beige head. Malty and yeasty aroma with dark fruits (ripe plums?), spices, rye bread and hints of licorice, chocolate and roasted malt. Moderate sweet with nice dark malty, fruity and yeasty flavours with some lightly sour notes and a somewhat dry finish with peppery notes. Well balanced. Interesting, different and quite delicious.

My Bottom Line:

Dark chocolate, roastiness and delicate fruitiness are taken into bitterness and mild acidity in this very effervescent dark Belgian-style Ale.



Further Personal Perceptions:

-A veil of foam skirts the red-hued dark brown.

-The prevalent roastiness and acidity don’t work that well for me.

-This roastiness reaches ash-y levels at times.

-The mouthfeel is nicely lean.



Bottle.
3 ounce sampler at the Grovetoberfest Miami beer festival 10/13/12. Very good!

12 oz. bottle at World of Beer in Land O Lakes. Poured a dark ruby brown with a roamed beige head. Aroma had a nice mixture of dark pitted fruits and spices. Flavor had some roasted, smoked malt notes mixed in with the spices. A touch of sourness in the mildly sweet finish. Wonder if aging this one will bring out more sour notes. May have to try that.

Sampled at Whole Foods during Goose Island Migration Week St. Louis, paired with Wild Ophelia chocolates. It poured a hazy brown colour with beige head of spritzy little bubbles, long-lasting with fine Belgian lace. Husky grains, rising dough, freshly baked brown bread, spicy rye, fruit leather, subtle noble hoppy balance, pepper, clove, faint nutmeg. Light body, high carbonation, smooth alcohol, long-lasting spicy and bittersweet aftertaste. Layers of complexity. Delicious and drinkable.

Pours a deep mahogany with a huge bubbly light brown head. Very spicy nose, lots of pepper and wet grass with a hint of rye, there’s some barnyard funk, notes of coffee, and a nice roasted malt note. A nice light smokiness in the taste, spice from the peppercorn and rye, some nice dark fruits, roasted malt, and a hint of chocolate. Quite nice but nothing too special. The beer is well made, don’t quite get all the GI hate.
The great conundrum. Balanced or bold. This is a conservative brew with an in conservative style/make up. So balanced you almost want more, but you respect the balance so why hate? Try it for its....

Pours a dark dark brown with a decent tan head. Aroma is absolutely wonderful. Very sweet, lots of fruit. Cherries, blackcurrant, plums, raisins. Very fragrant. Flavor isn’t quite as deep as the aroma would lead me to believe, but good nonetheless. Sweet roasty malts. Nut and fruit notes.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear black color with a finger of light tan head. Aroma is yeasty, very traditional saison smell, along with a very pleasant rye spiciness. Taste is very muted tart saison flavors, with some roasted malt, and caramel and finished with a rye spiciness. Fairly light in body with a moderate carbonation. Slightly dry.

Farmhouse ale. Saison. Not sure which but this is high up high up my leader board for each. Not to crazy in yeast and not banana bread overpowering. Wonder how a year or two old one would taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber into glass, clear dark red pout with floating chunks f sediment, aroma is caramel and fresh water.somethign else I cant point out, taste is taste is roasted nuty taste, good shiz

On tap at Urban Brew. Clear, cola-ish pour with a medium head that disappears quickly. Not much in the way of aroma, a little rye and pepper. Taste is the same - pretty light on everything, but coffee, rye, and pepper all come through. Really thin. Not my thing, but a refreshing enough saison.

22 oz bottle into a glass. It’s over one and a half years old, so fingers crossed it’s held up.

A: Pours a hazy chestnut color with tons of evident carbonation. The head is a two finger mocha shade. Very airy in texture, it retains itself quite well - fantastically, even. Leave it sitting long enough, and excellent lacing will be left on the glass.

S: A one-two-three punch of caramel, chocolate, and nuts really come through once this warms up. Before that, the aroma mainly consists of bready Belgian yeast and just a touch of black pepper spice. Not really getting how this is even a dark saison - this smells like a Belgian brown ale with some spiciness. Pleasant nonetheless.

T: The flavors seem to reveal more in the way of roasted coffee notes, especially around the midtaste. It opens with bready yeast flavors, developing a faint fruit quality (apples, pears, white grapes) right before the roast takes over. Chocolate, caramel, and sliiight (emphasis on all the i’s, it’s faint) cherry esters come out on the aftertaste. I’m beginning to wonder if the pepper notes have died down with age, because I’m not picking them up on the flavor profile. Overall, there’s a modicum of complexity, but none of the funk notes I like in my saisons.

M: Wow, this is strongly carbonated. It can be a bit much at times, but it also has the positive effect of drying the beer out very well. The lightness of body helps all that carbonation come through even more vividly. Okay, now I’m more inclined to believe that this is a dark saison - the mouthfeel is (nearly) dead on, helping to accentuate the coffee notes quite well.

O: Dark saison or really dry, fizzy Belgian brown? I don’t care, this is damn good. It lacks some of the fine-tuned sophistication to make it a true great of the style (...whatever that style is), but considering I got this on clearance, that’s really a moot point. Put it this way, I’d gladly get this again at regular price.

Edition bottled 2011 and 6% ABV.
Appearance: Clear ruby/dark brown with a finger thick ivory head.
Aroma: Vinous, brandy, citrus, bread, prunes, caramel/toffee, marzipan and perhaps notes of sour cherry.
Taste: Low/medium sweetness, low bitterness and medium/high sourness.
Palate: Thin light smooth texture with a light body, slight astringency and average carbonation. The lingering finish is quite tart with vinous notes, prune, toffee, and has a very subtle chocolate note to it.
Comments: This was delicious. There was a slight glass lacing. It reminded me more of a Flemish sour ale than a saison.

Pours clear moderate brown color with light tan head. Light roasted malt and Belgian yeast aromas with some rye. Roasted malt flavor with some spice from the rye and slight doughiness. Light to medium body with lively carbonation.

Trade with Aurelius - thanks! Dark cola pour, bubbly, foamy khaki colored head. Aroma has some hints of potting soil, some roasted notes. Flavor is full bodied with some nutty notes, a hint of unsweetened chocolate, some roasted notes, a bit of cigar smoke. Mouthfeel has a nice dry chalkiness to it.

12oz bottle, bottled on 1/15/13. Shared with caterwaul. Very dark brown color. Light brown / red color around the edges, but body is near-black. Nice thin khaki head. Dots and short ropes of lace. Good-lookng stuff. Bigger body. Smooth, creamy carbonation. Lightly dry finish. Very nice black peppercorn aroma, not too spicy though. Chocolate, dark malts, light darkf ruit. Not as spicy as a typical saison, nice robust sort of portery-ness to it. Alden says it has a pumpkin finish. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Tasty, dark farmhouse.
Poured as a taster. There is a smoky/roasted black malt on nose, tastes are malty, bit of hops, coffee.

Deep brown black with ruby highlights and a decent ashen tan head. Pleasant chocolate malts trying to coexist with light tartness and slight funk, maybe some very deep treacle, dune off the grape juice you get with stouts, more quite enough saison for me. Medium body, velvety effervescence. Lots of friendly, rich chocolate, grapes, dark treacle, very little saison; off dry with gentle bitterness and a pleasant, dark roasted malt finish.

Tannic, wood-funky aroma. Clean label on a standard longneck. Deep rootbeer brown-black; apparently clear, hard to tell. Dark candisugar, licorice and herbal flavors, a little peaty, modest sweetness, very light astringency. Slippery mouthfeel, medium heavy body, good carbo balance. ABC, Bull Run. Porterpounder, I got one saved for you.

Bottle. Pours a clear-ish red color with a two-finger off-white head. Aroma of malt, spices, rye, fruits and yeast. Tastes sweet and dry and pretty much like the aroma indicates, but with a peppery aftertaste. Fresh and full bodied. Not as good a saison as their Bourbon County Stout is as a stout, but definitely not bad.

From 22oz bottle to chalice. Pour is a deep copper, almost black. Nose is hop, coriander, smoky. Taste is bitter, medium bodied. Great carbonation that finishes well. Almost a smoky like aftertaste that lingers.

Pours dark red-ish brown with a thin offwhite head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is more like a cola than a nice saison: sugary, spicy. It feels fresh, aromatic herbs fresh. Taste is sweet, too sweet for a saison. There is some cardamom-like freshness. Carbonation level is medium, alcohol a little apparrent. Not a revelation.
Pours a hazy brown on tap, thin cream colored head with light lace. Aroma is yeast, funk, slight peppery spice. Taste follows with a nice coffee middle. Nice stuff, no crazy funk.
Dark brown pour with a slight tan foam. Spicy Belgian yeast aroma. Some vinegar in the aroma. Belgian yeast tang in the taste. Slight roasty taste and rye spice.

Bottle from Proof. Deep brown almost black pour with a soft tan head. Spicy, smoky, chocolate aroma with hints of roast and yeastiness. Smooth chocolate entry with smoke and ash, yeasty funk mid palate with a spicy ending. Smooth palate and soft carbonation. Pretty tasty stuff if you ask me.

Brown bottle, 765 ml, best before 12 FEB 2013, purchased at the LCBO, savoured on August 25 2013; eye: mahogany, semi-opaque, nice beige head that turns into a tiny sheet, nice lacing; nose: slight roasted barley, nutty, light dusty, slight plum, slight tobacco; mouth: malt, nutty, slight roasted barley, slight dusty, slight plum, slight tobacco, nutty finale with slight presence of plum, medium body, average carbonation, slick texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 765 ml, 6,4 %, meilleure avant 12 FEB 2013, achetée à la LCBO, savourée le 25 août; œil : acajou, semi-opaque, belle mousse beige qui se transforme en une mince couche, bonne dentelle; nez : malt, léger orge torréfiée, noix, très léger poussière, très léger prune, très léger tabac; bouche : malt, noix, très léger orge torréfiée, très léger poussière, très léger prune, très léger tabac, finale en noix avec très légère présence de prune, corps moyen, carbonatation moyenne, texture coulante; en résumé : bien
Dark brown pour. Chocolate banana and some bubblegum. Mildly bitter with a dry finish. Nice beer.

Appearance: Very dark brown, clear. Some light tan head.
Aroma: Sweet, caramel, dark fruit, smooth malt.
Taste: Dark malt, dark fruit, slightly roasted. Smooth, nice.
Info: 650ml bottle, 20/8-2013

Pours black, brown at edges, slight head springs up and dies almost immediately. Aroma of milk chocolate and light spice. Flavor is far more of a typical saison than the color or nose would lead you to believe. Gentle malt sweetness combines with enjoyable peppery belgian yeast character. Quite excellent. Goose Island can make some really elegant beers sometimes.
Holy cow awesome brew thanks to GT2 love goose island this is dark and awesome and easy to drink

From a 12 oz bottle poured in a tulip. Pours dark caramel colored black with minimal head or lacing. Flavor is significantly less peppery than I expected. Pretty well balanced, but also not that flavorful. Decent but nothing special.

12 oz bottle from Logan Twp Giant Eagle. Pours black with tan head. Notes of tobacco and licorice, raisin and cherry. Honestly tastes like I swallowed my chew. Tobacco and licorice, raisin. Not much hop presence. I honestly don’t know what to think. Just um, yeah. .
Poured from a cold bottle into a glass. Dark brown color, large tan head. Sweet smell, slight malt. Light candy caramel taste, lots of carbonation.

Bottle- Pours a dark brown color with a good tan head that fades to nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit, some chocolate and spice. Taste of roasted malt, some dark chocolate with dark fruit, spice and just a bit of smoke. Has a mild bitterness and a dry finish. Fairly full body, smooth with a creamy texture. Well balanced with a robust feel to it. Good beer to kick back and relax with.
Bottle. Deep brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is cranberries and grapes. Taste is prunes with a light smoky finish. Creamy body.

2/02/2011: Goose Island Pepe Nero... Aroma: Dusty
Belgian chocolate; dark raisins; banana and bubblegum; slightly spicy.
 Appearance: Dark cola color, mostly opaque with a very dense,
static, tan-colored rocky head; fine, nearly solid lacing. Flavor:
Raisin, plum; quite a bit of yeasty spiciness; bubblegum and spicy
herbal quality in the middle; moderate bitterness growing throughout
the roasty finish (tastes a bit like coffee grounds). Palate: Medium
to medium-full body; smooth; a bit heavy in the mouth. Overall:
Quite good and different (probably better) than expected; nice Dark
Saison with bold flavors and plenty of roasty characteristics; the
dark rye characteristics (roasty, spicy, and fruity) definitely shine
through and dominate nicely.



Pint (draught) at Marty’s Hops & Vines in Cincinnati (College
Hill), Ohio. Rating #611 for this beer.

7/27/13. Bottle from CBO $4.99. First beer drank out front at the July 13 block party. Nice sweetness and smokey. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Online from Sugaya, roughly 1300 yen so a bit pricey for 330ml. A black rye saison which sounds right up my alley. 2012 vintage brewed on April 17th, 2012 batch 1148. Great dark black pour with lots of light carbonation, reminiscent of coca-cola. Nice dark malt aroma but not that strong, possibly a hint of rye notes. Nice flavor! I get cherry, milk chocolate and,some spicy belgian yeast notes. A great really subtle mellow beer to drink while chilling out. As it warmed up the aroma became more pronounced and you could pick more belgian yeast & chocolate qualities.

Beautiful medium to dark brown, beige head. Big aromas, Belgian yeast and peppercorns, coriander arrive first followed by some chocolate, cherry pit, orange peel. Taste is yeasty, malty and spicy. Nice finish. Some might call this disjointed. I call it delicious.
Black or, cream head. Florals, rye, malt, sweet, and yeast. Easy palate, heavy yeast, spice, sweet malts, nice finish.

Bottle @ Goose Island O’Hare. Pours thin bodied dark brown with faint mocha head. Aroma is big dark chocolate, molasses, and a bit of coffee. Taste is thin dark roasty malt with decent spicy rye character. Finishes dry and peppery. Can’t say I’ve had a dark Saison like this before and am quite impressed.

This is a 2012 batch, bottled April 16, 2012 #0947. I haven’t had a saison this dark before, color and aroma recalls a stout. Thin beige head, bottle required a swirl at the end to suspend the sediments. Aroma is chocolate, molasses, dried fruit, oak barrel. Taste has the semi-sweet chocolate at the forefront, mild bitterness lingers on the palate. Very nice, enjoyed as a sipper, a good integration for me coming back to the States.

Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted almonds, coffee beans, brown sugar. Taste is chocolate, brown sugar, roasted almonds, some peat, hints of vanilla. Mouthfeel is quite mellow with some carbonation. Smooth, drinkable and well balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark sweet aroma with yeasty notes. Dark almost black body, not what I expected from a farmhouse ale but a pleasant surprise. Taste is sweet, spicy and roasty. Roast is not overpowering but is substantial. Some Belgian farmhouse flavor in there too. I wish the roast was not quite as strong as it is, it would all blend much better. Not my typical beer but I enjoyed the chance to try it.
Liked this lots, can see why it divides opinion though. Thanks Dom for suggesting I get it, tis working for me.

I’ve never been big on saison’s for some reason, that being said, I really like this particular one more than most on here it seems, so I’m not sure what that says. . . . Pours a deep mahogany with a short lived fizzy off-white cap that leaves bits of fizzy lace that quickly fade. The aroma malty, a bit of grape, light spice, light earthiness. The flavour is good, malty, almost a bit of chocolate, spice, a yeasty/estery element, grape, bit of citrus peel. Mouthfeel is soft and rounded, finish is dry and mildly bitter, like accidentally biting into a grape seed, but in this case not in a bad way. Lovely stuff.

Smelled faintly of melon, and more-so of co2. On appearance, the viscosity seemed too low, but the color and head were appetizing. A much desirable hint of spiciness in flavor, but overall diminished by overcarbonation and loss of whatever more refined characteristics this may start off with. Again I have been led not to believe GI’s ’will develop for up to five years’ bottle clause. This still had life after over a year, but it had lost flavor and aroma that were not replaced with complexity or an improved palate.

2011 bottle. Dark, just about pitch black body with a large head of large brown bubbles. Rye bread in the aroma along with some chocolate and a faint whiff of pepper and smoke. More rye in the taste slightly bitter, yeasty and some hints of smoke. Slightly thin in the mouth with a lingering bitterness. Not too shabby.
October 2012. Bottle. Dark saison with aromas of dark fruit, roasted malts and Belgian yeast. Good balance, carbonation just right and very refreshing finish.
The Belgian yeast dominates too much and overwhelms the stout, medium light body, with molasses and dark chocolate, but not really that balanced. Dry. Med body.
Pours dark brown, mahogany. Thick off white head with lacing. Aromas of roasted malts, coffee, spices and black pepper. Refreshing carbonation and dry. Lots of character!

750 mL bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a thick beige cap. Leaves nice lacing. Aromas of roasted malt, prune, espresso, cocoa, and pepper, both the vegetable and the spice. Surprisingly dry, medium to full carbonation with a clean mouth feel. Spicy on the finish. Different. Enjoyed.

So this is a saison, but I wasn't expecting this. Poured from a bottle, very dark brown, small tan head. The aroma is not as much saison as smoked rye. Has some coffee aspects in smell. Not what I'm looking for with a saison. Don't like the flavor combinations. The difficulty is the expectation of a saison type beer. If I wanted smokey and deep, I would have picked another one. Maybe I'll try it again without the expectation.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle into a tulip.

Pours a very dark brown, nearly pitch black, with a one finger tan head. Ok head retention and lacing but not great.

Aroma is quite unique for a saison. There is the spicy phenols typically associated with the style but there is a nice additon of coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted malt. Some nice complexity there.

The flavor has banana and pepper up front along with some yeastyness but there is sublte roast and coffee in the background adding a nice complexity. Some black pepper and lemon as well. There is some stickyness in the finish and it is not as dry as I would like but a very nice flavor.

Overall, a very nice and unique saison. While it could stand to be dried out a little more, it is one that I would not have a problem drinking again.

Bottle. Subtle aroma of smokey malts and yeast. Dark brown body with medium, lasting head. Flavor begins with belgian yeast and subtle rye notes, followed by a smokey malt flavor. Sweet,dry coffee finish.
750 mL bottle. Looks like a porter. Smells like a saison with jube jubes in it. And roast. It tastes like a dark saison. On the sweet side, though, for the style. Good, though.
Pours deep amber, close to black, with a small beige head. Gentle, yet spicy aroma of citrus, chocolate and some licorice. Spicy sweet taste of mango, citrus, licorice and some yeasty funk.

Bottle from Cherry Reds, Kings Heath. The start of my rustic day. Dark, delicious, and rather lovely. Bit too chilled but then we were sitting outside. Mussels are cooking, wine is flowing, love Sundays like this.

2012 bottle. Pours cloudy light amber with no head or lacing. Nose is plums and maybe some lemon. Notes of plums, lemons, yeast, some butterscotch. Tastes medium to high sweet and no bitterness. Body is light creamy with no carbonation. An odd duck, but enjoyable. He interesting to try a younger version.

It pours deep mahogany almost opaque, with ruby highlights; the head is beige and marshmallow-like. The aroma has notes of: plums, pepper, sour cherries, roasted malts, and slight tobacco (some sort of wood-like characteristic). The taste is medium spicy that finishes very light sweet and light sourness; there are notes of: plums, charcoal, pepper, rye sourness, and coffee. The palate is medium bodied, slick, almost no carbonation, slightly oily, and a long spicy rye finish. Overall, very interesting - it grows on you.

My third bottle of this great wacky saison/bier de garde - it grows on you - forget convention here is a ale with farmhouse roots that sould grace the table at special occasions. Deep clear brown with ruby highlights, massive tn cap lasts and laces your glass. Very subtle noe - some roasty sweetness and grassiness. Flavour is really unique, rasty , nutty but with some hints of fruit , hops sit back and guide the brew to the finish which is lightly hopped , cocoa and a light sweetness in the finish - if you don’t use this ale to wash down some red meat yer nutz!

2011 bottle to a tulip glass.  Color was dark brown/black with some crimson highlight.  Big, effervescent tan head that keeps coming.  Aroma is roasted, slightly smoky malt with some spice and pepper.  Taste is the same with undertones of dark fruits and a distinct peppery taste, reminiscent of peppercorns.  Full, slightly creamy mouthfeel with lots of carbonation.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from 12 oz. bottle after cellaring for 13 months.  Opening the bottle produced plenty of foam and effervescence, probably the product of secondary fermentation. 

Opaque, deep dark brown with a large, billowing khaki head and good lacing. 

Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, yeast, Riesling grapes, raisins and rye bread. 

Taste of roasted malt, coffee, yeast, white grapes, peat, funkiness and mild sweet dark fruit. 

Medium/light body and high/medium carbonization.

Overall, this brew comes across as a saison/imperial stout chimera.  It is best thought of as a saison with strong dark roast elements.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at Blue Dog in Chalfont, PA. Did not expect this type of smokiness in a Saison, but I was very impressed with how well it worked. A surprisingly good beer.

Served tulip glass at Blue Dig. They call it a farmhouse ale. Very nice. Black with beautiful creamy lacing. Note malt, coffee and a hint of sour as it finishes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Poured an unfiltered dark brown color with a frothy tan top and superb lacing. Taste of roasted malt, pepper, dried fruits, smoky finish. High fizzy carb, medium creamy body.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 12/20/2011.  Pours hazy and cloudy very dark reddish brown color with a nice 2-3 finger foamy khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Nice dense foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head.  Aromas of big raisin, prune, fig, apple, clove, pepper, molasses, dark candi sugar, toast, light roast, light smoke, and yeast earthiness.  Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/spicy esters with big malt presence; and good strength.  Taste of raisin, fig, apple, pepper, clove, toast, molasses, roasted malt, dark candi sugar, light smoke, and yeast earthiness.  Lingering notes of dark fruit, pepper, clove, molasses, toast, roasted malt, and earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Damn nice complexity of fruity/spicy yeast esters with a great dark malt balance; and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a fairly slick, crisp, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent black saison style.  All around nice complexity and balance of fruity/spicy ester notes with dark malt flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink.  A very enjoyable offering.

765 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a dark, ruby-tinged brown with lasting tan head.  Aroma is roasty dark and fruity malts with spicy Belgian yeast.  Flavour is quite roasty with cocoa, grape, pear, modest spiciness and a gentle funkiness.  Medium plus body.   Rather nice.

750mL bottle I got from the LCBO amidst the bi-annual ’oh shit they’re going on strike’ shopping spree people go on when they are suddenly reminded that they are alcoholics. Opaque dark brown and a big tan head. The aroma is interesting but not as much as the flavour to come. I just get a big whiff of Belgian yeast that reminds me of Unibroue, with undistinguished dark malts and fruits. But the flavour is quite interesting. The roasty smoke element is definitely present but not in an ostentatious way. Rich and creamy chocolate malt rides along the surprisingly smooth palate. I actually get very little of the fruit character I would typically expect from something like this. I wouldn’t say that the yeast character is peppery like it’s supposed to be, but it’s still interesting. A very good beer although the price is a bit ridiculous.

Bottle from LCBO.  Pours a super dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is a very nice combination of "saison" and roasted barley.  Taste has caramel, roasted notes, vanilla, spice, and light fruit notes.  Medium-full body.  I really enjoyed this.

Pours dark brown with a frothy tan head. Notes of dark fruit and roasted malt on the nose with a bit of yeast and bread.Taste is a great balance between sweet and bitter with a bit of a spicy dry finish. Overall a delicious beer and something different

Just a gorgeous beer. Puffy dark tan head over viscous black body. Salls over the palate velvety and light like silk. Yet bursting with subtle flavours of cocoa, grapes, kola-spicy phenolics, sweet grassy hops, lemon, decadent fresh whole grain bread, vanilla. Aroma clean and bright. Really offers a lot and now it sucks that I will want more of this drug for twelve bucks a hit. Sexy beer for sexy bitches!

Bottle shared with Deanso.  Pours almost black with a small beige head.  Aroma of dark fruits, sweet malt, yeast, roast and light spice.  Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter, roasty in the finish.  Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

33.cl bottle from khiosk .
Thin creamy off white head.  Clear deep burgundy pour.  Some choc holate but refreshing like a saison .

Bottle from Henry’s: Created a monstrous sizing of foamed head which took several minutes to fully retreat. The liquid was a dark brown with an amber reddish tint. As for the nose, there was a spicy scent of smoked dark malt with a notice of pepper and some floral aroma that hinted towards fruit perhaps banana. Taste is heavily spiced with dashes of pepper, clove and sweet malts that left behind an aftertaste of cigar tobacco.

Bottle from central market. Pours a very dark brown color with a foamy beige colored head. Aroma is roasty right off the bat. Some Belgian fruit and yeasty notes as well with perhaps a small funky bit. Flavor is roasted first, with a bitter farmhouse zest. Flavor is a bit funky, earthy finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle. Bottled 6/13/2012. Pours a dark brown with a tan frothy head.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, and pepper.  Taste just like the nose.  Roasted malts, almost burnt, dark fruits, a hint of smoke, and nice peppery spice on the finish.  Good carbonation. Pretty good. But Sofie, she’s much warmer and creamier. She’s def  my favorite Saison.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Pours Black, cola like, reddish highlights, tan foamy head, lots of lacing. Aroma of dark fruits and malts and spices. Taste is sweet, smokey roasted malts, fruits and spices very complex but very balanced, nice beer, nice sipper quite enjoyable.
Aromas of bread, purple grapes, and rose petals.  Midnight ruby with a lasting, light tan head.  Dry, fruity, and bready.  Medium bodied and yeasty, with a dry, fruity finish.

Bottle at Monk’s American Bar, 2011 version. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is coffee/chocolate, yeast and rye spiciness, black pepper. Taste is roasted sweetness with a dry peppery finish.
Bottle shared with jones. Pours deep brown with tan cap. Aroma of spices, dark fruit, rye, woody. Taste is fruity, light spice, earth. A gentle dry finish.

Bottle. Dark clear red brown pour with off white head. Dominant pepper notes, that marry well with the natural spiciness of Belgian yeast. Light fruity, vegetal, earthy and even roasty notes complete this gentle sipper. Palate is light with med-heavy carbonation. Quite drinkable and smooth despite the intensity of the spice.

Very dark for a Belgian, cola color with a pretty generous mocha head. Smells of sweet rye, dark fruit. A sweet malty, caramel, banana, rye taste with little bitter. Fairly carbonated mouthfeel, overall pretty good. Light taste that doesn't overwhelm the tastebuds but satisfies. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown, almost black. Beige head. Aroma is straw, cocoa and wild yeast. Foamy body at first sip, then thick milky texture. Tastes are oak, stone, cocoa, dark plum. A heavy foamy overly carbonated beer that is a.chore to drink. Stirs allergies.

Bouteille 355ml. De couleur brune-noire et quasi-opaque. Nez de levures épicées (poivre) aux faibles notes fruitées (cerises noires), de malt rôti aux notes terreuses et aux petites traces fumées avec des notes de houblon herbeux et de chocolat noir. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi qu’une texture moyennement crémeuse.
