Notes de levures fruitées (cerises noires), épicées (poivre doux) et aux petites traces rustiques accompagné de très faibles notes fumées (fumée de bois, faibles traces de beef jerky) ainsi que des traces de réglisse noire lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de malt rôti légèrement terreux avec des notes de chocolat noir et de pain grillé puis en finale l’on retrouve une légère amertume asséchante de houblon herbeux aux notes florales avec une légère progression du profil épicé de la levure (poivre plus présent). Post-goût moyen-long et un peu sec, légèrement amer de rôti doux, léger de levures épicées (poivre doux) avec des notes de chocolat noir et de houblon herbeux.

Saison - really?  If so, it’s the darkest boldest, and most interesting one I’ve ever had!  Pours dark brown with a nice white head that leaves significant lacing.  The aroma is full of subtle spice.  The taste is very Belgian esque with a very nice flavor explosion up front and finishes clean.  It’s pleasant on the palate and a very nice beer overall.  Good stuff!

12oz bottle - been in my beer chest for a while - no idea where I got it.  Black pour with big fluffy head.  Aroma is dusty roasted malts.  Tastes are smokey, pepper, rye, farmhouse funk... wow, definitely unique.  Creamy palate.  Not my thing tho.

Pours brown, tan head. Both aroma and flavor are dominated by fruity yeast esters, with a bit of dark fruit, and bread. I honestly don’t get much rye from it. Fairly thin body. Not going to be a favorite, but it’s nice.

Bottle. 15 months old. Black beer with no head. Aroma of sweet toffee and roasted malts. The taste is roasted malts, boiled sweets and mild spices. There is orchard fruits hidden in there too. Dry and slightly carbonated. An unusual saison, but I think I prefer the traditional style.

I have seen this in stores for a while and have always meant to try it.  Pours a dark chocolate deep brown.  Aroma is of roasted malt and a slight belgian yeast funk.  Taste is roasted caramel mixed with so belgian yeast funk, and a bit of a bite from the rye.  Bottle carbonation means it is aggressively carbonated.  Finishes dry and smooth.  Very nice beer.

750 bottle. Cap was a bit rusted (?). Opened with no pop and thought it was non-carbed. Poured aggressive and got a nice but swiftly deflating off-white head.  Nose of sweetened malts, slight farmhouse, and a little spice. Taste is the same. This is more of a Belgian dark ale for me. Not much alcohol kick here. Decent but a bit of a mixed up beer.

A darker Belgian, it pours dark with a caramel head.  Nice bready aroma and  a bit sweet.  Taste is darker with roasted malts, coffee and chocolate, but not my favorite Belgian Goose Island makes.  Nice beer overall, though.

2011 bottle 22 oz. Pours brown black with a big tight fluffy head that slowly settles to a foamy film. Aroma has roasted malt some light hidden plum raisins and light spice. Taste is more raisin plum some fig and sugars along with roasted malt  little smoke and yeast with a spice, but the peppercorn is well hidden. This is one of the more mild beers that use pepper/peppercorn. It is refreshing.

2011 bottling. Pours thick black with a thick creamy off-white head. Nose is semi-sweet fruit and dusty leather. Taste is dry fruit - raisin, apple and fig, with some rye spiciness. Nice finish that lasts a few moments. A little tannic like a red wine. Body is lighter than expected. Very tasty with a nice balance of sweetness and spice.
Very dark brown with a nice beige head. Aroma of roast, yeast and dark fruit. Taste is roasty and yeasty; mildly sweet and mildly bitter. Medium bodied.
Nice dark beer with a nice warming spiceiness to it with average carbonation.

Dark pour.  Fruity aroma and flavor.  Very carbonated, which I guess is expected for a Saison.  I wouldn’t call this a Saison myself, but that’s me.  Too fruity and dark.  It’s just okay, I doubt I will drink it again.
12oz bottle..Pour is dark with a off white head..Nose is roast,yeast,spice,dark fruit..Taste is.roast,dark fruit,spice,coffee..palate is.roast
Bottle on vacation. Pours dark with uneven head. Aroma is farmyard malt. Taste is dry malt, smoky. Dry finish.
Sour malt aroma. Dark brown color with a small tan head. Sour beginning with a building sour and bitter finish.

smell is a bit farmy, but beery.  dark & attractive looking.  a little uncivilized on the tongue. taste is like a beefed up fat gary’s but not as smooth.  medicinal finsh, not as light as i like my saisons.

12oz bottle (courtesy of Headbanger) poured into a Wide Mouth Stemmed Glass at 42°.  Color is a deep brown with a hint of ruby.  Carbonation is light producing a thin off white head.  Aroma is sweet with mild roasted malt and a wine like note in the back.  It has a medium body with a crisp mouth feel.  Flavor of dark fruits, brown sugar, light coffee and roasted rye with a spicy bitterness on the end.  After taste is slightly dry with the fruit lingering on.  Overall this is a great brew, not what I was expecting from a Saison.

Bottle from Village Wine & Spirits in Athens. Very light roast malt aroma, with some yeast. Dark brown, thin tan head, some lace. Coffee and dark sugar initial / a bit harch and fizzy in mid palate, with some light sweetness, raisins maybe, and a little pepper / finishes a bit sweet with a touch of bitterness. Kind of a session Belgian? Does not really impress much. Okay.
Poured from bottle deep mahogany with a khaki head. Aroma of roasted grains, bitter cocoa, and slight malt. Tastes of roasted malt, piney hops, and cereal. Good mouth feel.

Bottle @ home....It pours dark brown almost black with a medium beige head..... The aroma is light roasted malt, floral, sweet fruity and spicy... The flavor is roasted malt, ripe fruit, yeast, some smokey notes and spicy.....

Bottle from Canal’s. First off I want to say this is the bees knees. I loved it. Good amount of roast, hop, smoke, pepper, all blended to perfection.

I found the crisp finish refreshing.

Vintage 2012, bottled on 06/13/12. 12oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown.  Smells of roasted malt, and black pepper.  Tastes of roasted barley, spicy rye.  Finishes dry, with a peppery tingle, mostly roasted malt flavors.  (3619)

12 ounce bottle - $3.49 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.



Bottled On: 06/13/12



Appearance: Pours out a very dark brown, near black body with a tall crown of beige foam. The mighty soon recedes but never quite fades from sight. Minor lacing.



Smell: Bittersweet chocolate-coated roasted barley, but, then there’s a notable floral aroma accented by the spiciness from the phenols but also the p-corns and a light dark fruitiness.



Taste: Dark chocolate, roasted malts with a soft coffee tone. Modestly sweet. Plum-ish fruitiness, a tiny pinch of cloves, a little pre-chewed gum, and handful of nosegays. A little subtle pepper spiciness showing from time to time. Then, a little bit of licorice, but also some more chocolate. Spicy, choco-roasty, crispish finish.



Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation, mouthfeel is moderate peppy, yet it’s still rather smooth in a way.



Overall: Pepe Nero is not your everyday saison, or even your every other day saison, but I liked it well enough.

2011 vintage.  Pours an opaque dark brown with big and solid off white rocky head that has great retention and leaves good lacing.  Banana and juicy fruit aroma with a slight hint of roast, spiciness and some funk from the yeast.  Nice spicy peppery flavors in taste with roast and some smoke.  Banana and clove mid palate and finishes with hints of chocolate and an earthiness but little bitterness.  Full creamy mouthfeel that finishes fairly dry with moderate to high carbonation.  Works well as a black saison with the addition of rye.  Not as earthy and funky as typical saisons but carves out its own niche with the peppery and smokey flavors to create an interesting and flavorful beer that is pretty easy to drink.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A dark brown, almost black body with a quarter-inch thick dark tan head. There is a quick, initially mellow caramel and chocolate flavor that is quickly turned tangy from the peppercorn. This is a sharp hitting beer, where at times hard to put down. In between sips, there is a residual black licorice and vegetable juice note. Not something I would search for, but this is a very interesting experimental beer.

35cl Bottle, thanks Harmen! Almost black colour, creamy light-beige head. Aroma of lots of green apple skin and endive, toast, liquorice. Flavour is medium sweet, liquorice, laurel, green apple skin, toast, caramel, veggies, light bitter finish with some roasted malts and liquorice. Light-bodied. Didn’t enjoy this at all.

Pours black with a brownish head. Nose of "Belgian yeast", as I call it. Aroma of sweet light chocolate, light coffee. Is pretty good, though I didn’t know Saison was this type of color/aroma. In any case, wish the aroma was more present.

Aroma of Belgian yeast with hints of pepper.  Pours a deep dark brown with a large mostly lasting tan head and fine lacing. The taste is toasted malts upfront, yeasty in the middle and subtle hint of pepper in the finish. Somewhat of grainy aftertaste present. Medium body with crisp carbonation. Overall, while not a tradional Saison, this is an extremely enjoyable beer that I want to drink again. I liked adding the dark malts to a Saison.
Pretty decent. Pours black with good lacing. Some hay and booze, yeast in aroma. Taste leaves light astringency. Average carbonation. 2010 vintage on tap at Hopcat.
Smell of roast and yeast. Black colour with brown head. Too much yeast in aroma. Non-pleasantly sweet, also bitter

355ml Bottle from Cotteridge Wines poured dark brown with a decent sized off white head.Roast malt aroma with hints of spice.Roast malt and yeast flavour with some caramel and only a slight hint of pepper(more would be welcome)making a nice tasting enjoyable beer.

Pepe Nero poured a deep copper color with a resilient off-white head. It was darker than I expected from a Saison, but taking note that it contained black malt I adjusted my expectations as best as I could. The aroma was roasty, nutty and a bit citrusy. The flavor was peppery and nutty with just a hint of citrus and a bit of chocolate. Overall, the beer was god, but not quite what I am looking for in a Siason. Keep in mind, it did win a Gold Medal as a Siason so what do I know.

Price was okay at $10/4

Bottle from Elizabeth Station, Bellingham, WA
The color is dark, almost black, with small sized head. The aroma is interesting and delicate, with roasted malts, fresh timber, wood sap, light paper and spices. Smooth mouthfeel; moderate chocolate flavor, caramel, dynamic, almost refreshing; the pepper is basically hidden, more of it would be accepted (and maybe requested); in the final there is a light residual sweetness and light sweet liquorice; in the very late final there is a light tickling feeling that could be explained with the pepper.
It doesn’t have the spicy/dry/funky character expected from a Saison. But it’s a very good beer.

24th May 2011
Clear dark brown - red beer, ghost of a white head. Softish palate, low carbonation. Creamy start. Lightly sour coca cola with a little fruit.  Not bad.
From a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours a dark cola with a thick off white head.  Aroma of yeast and sour cherries.  Dominant malty backbone with a smooth finish.
Dark and with a texture like Coca Cola. Could be deeper and richer, and not as tasty as the Pere Jacques.

(bottle) Cola colored body with a big, frothy, brown, receding head and a fair amount of lace. Dark roasted malt, black pepper, chocolate, light wood, some fruit and yeast--interesting mix. Medium body. Medium sweet, pepper, moderate hops, resin, light yeast, chocolate.

Labeled bottled 5/22/12. Pour has a dark brown color and a fluffy tan head. Aroma has yeast esters, lightly roasted brown malt, some fruity sweetness, and a slightly sour twang that burnt off after a short while. Mouth feel is light with medium carbonation. Flavor has lightly roasted brown malt, lots of yeasty character, slight bitterness, and a touch of coffee. Interesting collection of flavors that play well together.

This was courtesy of Strkyzone. Pours black with a beige head. Almost no lacing.  Nose is malty.   Medium body. Smooth in the mouth. Flavor shows pepper spice, and the finish shows banana. Interesting flavor.

Black with a thick white head. Aroma is yeast with very faint hints of pepper. Flavor is roasted malt and cocoa with a nice peppery finish. Wouldn’t recognize it as a saison until the big hit of malt subsides a bit. It’s an interesting combination, executed pretty well.

On the Fifth Day of Christmas the beer Gods gave to me... A black saison.   Pours a dark brown color with a thick off white foam head.  Complex aroma of caramel, chocolate, zest and grass.   Has a sweet caramel taste with Belgian spice and chocolate notes on the backend.  Some tart mixed in.

2011 bottle; about a year old.  Dark pour with a fizzy tan head that settles quickly as a thin blanket on top.  The scent has some clove mixing with yeast, banana-like fruity esters, a little bit of dark caramel, and very mild alcohol.  The flavor adds a chocolate character and some roasted dark malt to the fruity esters and clove spice.  I wouldn’t call this a great beer but it’s pretty solid stuff that goes down rather easily.

Out of the bottle from Uptown Market. We got this one in our winter beer club delivery. A beer that I probably wouldn’t have purchased myself. Pours black with a thin white head. The smell is the typical sweet Belgian smell. The taste has a slight hint of roasted malts, but nothing overpowering. It merely adds a little compexity. There isn’t much of a hop flavor and it has the typical sour taste and aftertaste. This beer is exceptional!

Sample at the Goose Island tap takeover at World of Beer Brewery District on 11/21/12. Clear chestnut brown pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt, roast, coffee and herbs. Peppery yeast flavor with herbs and chocolate before a roasty coffee finish. Very interesting.

Pours black with a small tan head. Nose is wood, peppers, spices like cardamom, coriander and sage with hints of chocolate and raisins. Taste is sweet but mostly bitter. Mouthfeel is soft at first then gives way to a crispness, body is light and finish is long. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Pours a red hued clear slightly effervescent brown with a full creamy light tan head.  Aroma is mildly sour and fruit sweet with a rich roasty malt.  Nicely balanced flavor with some tart bitterness, a dry roasty body and a light sourness.  Lively biting carbonation with a medium body.  Nice.
Had this from a bottle, good dark color, decent head, and good lacing. Tastes kind of nutty,

12 oz bottle, 4/2012, dark brown opaque hue with creamy tan lasting head, decent lacing, smells of Belgian yeast, clove spice and dough, medium body, minimal carbonation, rye comes through on the back, some pepper, unique style, little bit of a skunk aftertaste
nose is spicey pepper. Taste follows by spicy pepper. green apply crispness, grass, and zippy yeast finish, interesting.
2012 bottle.  deep brown with a large, foamy, tan head.  coffee, chocolate, with pale grain aroma.  roasted malt and straw flavors.  palate is superb with a medium to full body and velvety texture.
bottle 2011 poured black with a light tan head. aroma light smoke with dark cherries, coffee,  molasses, anise, dark fruits, pepper. flavor,  same as aroma with chocolate and cloves, roasted malts.
A strange smoky cherry aroma probably sent me south for this one. Pours dark brown with a fizzy, lacing head. The flavor is quite bland. A bit of bitterness dries the finish.

Bouteille 355 mL. Millesime 2011. Brune foncee opaque avec tres peu de mousse. Nez leger de malt grille et une pointe de levure. Bouche moyenne ou on retrouve le malt grille, la levure et quelques epices. Bien.

First rating
355 ml bottle at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, on November 16, 2012. Bottled 02/24/11
Dark brown to black color, tan to light brown head. Sweet, tropical fruit, sugary, alcohol, yeast taste. Chocolate, sweet, malty, spicy aftertaste. Sweet, sirup, toffee, spicy scent. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Some bourbon vanilla notes in the aftertaste as well.
7/3/7/3/13=3.3

Rerate
355 ml bottle from Total Wine & More, Clearwater (thanks to Brian / not on ratebeer). Sampled on January 23, 2014. Bottled 30 Mar 13.
Clear dark red color, fluffy teal head. Sweet, berry scent. Sweet, malty, berry taste. Sweet aftertaste. Medium mouhtfeel, medium bitterness.
7/4/7/3/14=3.5

I appreciate experimentation in brewing, but that doesn’t mean that an unusual brew makes a good one. Goose Island Pepe Nero is proof of that. It’s a Belgian-style saison brewed with rye and peppercorns to give it a dark body and a hint of spice. Though there’s nothing particularly off-putting about the beer there’s just nothing holding my attention. 



I poured a 2011 vintage 12oz bottled on 2/24/11 into a tulip glass.



Appearance: Dark opaque black body like a stout. Forms a huge, khaki, fluffy head which slowly dissipates, and does leave some lacing on the glass.



Smell: A slightly stout-like scent from a distance, but a closer inspection reveals typical Belgian farmhouse aromas and a hint of dark fruit.



Taste: A beer like Goose Island Pepe Nero probably would be best tasted blind (literally). Seeing the dark, stout-like body, but tasting a fairly typical golden saison flavor really messes with the senses. It’s brewed with black malt, not roasted malt, so you get no stout flavors (not that you’re supposed to, but there’s a certain Pavlovian effect imparted by a beer’s color). The entire palate is classic saison flavor that’s lightly bitter, but quite "zesty." The use of peppercorns should add some spicy heat to this brew, but all it really does is make the finish drier.



Perhaps the underwhelming flavor is due to the fact this bottle is about 20 months old and even though it’s bottle-conditioned, it just doesn’t age well.  I’d imagine a fresh bottle would make great use of the rye and peppercorn spiciness. I’m not a big fan of saisons to begin with, and I definitely appreciated the originality to this palate, but there’s not much to it that’s impressing me. 



Drinkability: While the flavors might not wake up your mouth, the actually delivery of the beer across the tongue likely will. Goose Island Pepe Nero is definitely using Belgian yeast which makes it extremely foamy, fizzy, and spastic in the mouth. There’s a dryness to the character all around and a slightly chalky aftertaste (though tolerable). There’s a high amount of fine carbonation here,  but it still goes down surprisingly smooth. I think the rather low 6% ABV weight does the beer a disservice since it might need more energy to make use of its potential.

May 16th, 2011 - The black IPA was a tremendous leap in my beer tasting adventures, but a dark saison seems almost a little crazy. What will happen to those light and breezy grainy flavors? How will those flavors that taste like a captured sunset turn if they’re mired in dusk and darkness? Yet, if my philosophy is to give everything a try, no matter how small or pedestrian, then I am obliged to sit down with a glass of the wildly innovative. And in all honesty, I’ve always loved beers that try to combine sleek, subtle dark flavors with brighter, fuzzier tastes and melded on a palate that accommodates both. This beer, true to its official title, is a deep, light-gobbling black, with a great, massive head that rushes out of the top of the glass and down the sides of the glass. A little Pompei action never hurt anybody (excluding the town of Pompeii) so I advance to the nose. It’s a creamy aroma, sweet, almost like a milk stout, but smoother and lighter with lots of dark notes, but light and ephemeral and hard to describe. The sensation is like writer’s block - I just can’t put my pen around it. The flavor is easier to put into words: silky body, but thick, like silk doubled over itself, with a light grainy flavor, and a long dry hopped aftertaste. There’s a wood dryness too, but I think what really makes this different from a standard saison is a quiet, more muted take on the blend of grains. I also detect fewer spices, possibly because they’re contending with a roastier body. Whatever the case, this is an interesting permutation of the style, but not exactly a revelation for my palate.
22 ounce bottle pours black with aromas of light roast, some coffee, light pepper spice, with some light smoke.  Flavors follow suit with some earthy notes, nice little black sasison.

This dark saison is incredible. A beautiful medley of yeast, smoked malt and spices that have a lovely finish and nose. A beautiful bottle design, and dark but transparent pour. An outstanding brew from Goose Island.

From the bottle poured a brownish brew with a voluminous light brown head. Malty aroma with a hint of spicy pepper. Well balanced flavors of malt and hops with a nice little pepper finish in the back of the tounge. Medium bodied and tasty.

Bottle. Fairly dark with voluminous foamy tan head. Smells like chocolate and brown sugar with a hint of lemon and a hint of spiciness- almost akin to licorice. Has a bite to it, then a warming sweetness comes in balanced by a dryness. Bit of a sweet finish with a little hit of spice at the end. I would drink this.

Dark Brown with a 4 finger head pour. While the smell gives an impression of that of a doppelbock (Caramel, Malts, etc.) the flavor consists of cracked peppers, cloves, roasted malts and barley. The smell and flavor throws me off quite a bit but not necessarily in a way that causes it to be any less drinkable. Body is heavier and the carbonation could use a little less fizz. It’s a very unusual Saison style ale which is still good to drink, but I feel like I paid just a bit too much for it.
Poured from a 22 ounce bomber. Overly carbonated. Notes of chocolate, spicy, and yeasty. There is an odd woody character that is distracting. Meh.

Bottle. Black pour with a tall, foamy tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, dusty yeast, dry earth, light spice and watery coffee. Taste is roasted malt, Belgian yeast, soft earthiness, dark chocolate, light coffee notes, light smoky notes, soft spice, straw and light floral notes. Body is light-medium with a strong, effervescent carbonation. Slightly sticky as well. Ends with more roasted malt, dark chocolate, dusty yeast, earthy notes, light spice, straw and faint coffee.
Pepper, bubblegum, smoke and yeast on the nose.  Taste is nice and dry, with some smoke and roasted malt character.  Also, the bubblegum is a bit there.  Good beer, solid.  Doesn’t wow you.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Virginia Beach, VA.  Cola-like pour with a foamy khaki head.  Aroma resembles a porter with smoky malts, light chocolate, and faint floral hops.  The taste features light chocolate and coffee with a faint peppery finish.  I find it hard to classify this as a saison.  It is more of a Belgian-style porter if that is possible.  Classifications aside, this is a good beer.
Pours dark with a thick frothy, tan head. Aroma of heavy alcoholic malt. Lively, full bodyfeel with flavour of roasted malt over dry lingering aftertaste. Seems to be lacking something.

Pours a hazy chestnut brown with a large long lasting tan head, good lacing. Aroma and Taste of dark roasted malt, dark fruit, molasses, brown sugar and yeast, along with some sweet spices and bitter hops fill the senses.  A medium to full body, slightly sticky with good carbonation on the palate. Finish is sweet dark roasted caramel malt, yeast, dark fruit, molasses, some sweet spicy notes and good bitter hops for balance. A very good, flavorful and well balanced brew.

2012 bottle purchased at The Davis Food Co-Op.  The aroma on this is pretty roasted with some burnt metallic character, and a little spicy herbal nose.  Mostly roast.  Moderately opaque dark brown/black body with a small, rapidly dissipating light tan head present.  Starts with a good deal of carbonation, before this becomes quite roasted in the middle with some roasted coffee flavors.  Becomes a bit astringent, before a spicy peppery rye flavor comes through late.  Pretty impressive beer.  Perhaps a little overly carbonated and a little too astringent.
Nice rye black seasonal beer. Is liquid bread!! Very long and a bit sour aftertaste.
Slight chocolate aroma. Peppery chocolate flavors.  Overall a decent black saison with a twist. At least it doesn’t taste like anise.

Today it seems everything has been done in the beer world, yet a black saison is a new one for me. Really it looks dark brown like a porter, except it carbon release pattern is that of a Belgian. Toasted malt aroma combined with a farmhouse yeast funk. I don’t feel the taste is all that great. The tart element of the beer mixed with the smoky part to create something that comes off as grassy, stale, and burnt. Packs a bite that is not expected from a dark malty beer. Interesting stuff.

Bottle from 2011.  pour is dark brown letting no light through with tons of tight light brown head.  Nose is a balanced, light smokey note with a sweet Saison yeast, candied lemon, and peppery spice behind.  The taste is far more smokey, the body is oily and falls off in the middle and the finish is short. The roast dominates but sweet lemon and faint Saison yeast come in towards the back of the palate as roasted malts come in at the end and disappear.
Sample @ SBWF 12. Very dark colour with a small dark beige head. Malty, spicy aroma. Flavour of roasted malt and sugar, with a bit of spiciness.
Pours a deep dark brown. Almost black. A thick tan foamy head. Aroma of roasted malt, toasty coffee. Taste is toasty coffee. This seems more like a stout!!?? Either way, a solid beer!

pours a black with a small khaki head.

smell is of cocoa, malt, a slight amount of fruit, pepper, and some spice.

taste is of spice, cocoa, some roasted malt, hops, a touch of citrus, and some sweet fruits.  ends smooth and a little bitter.

Bottle from Whole Foods.  Pours black with a finger of rocky tan head that dissipates pretty quickly into a tan film.  There is some carbonation in the glass.  The aroma has your typical farmhouse yeast and a little bit of a smoke.. minor funk.  Taste has your usual saison zest with some smokiness.. the rye comes through a bit.  Really nice stuff here.  Very surprised at how good this is.
Pepper, roast, slight chocolate, and even yeasty sourness.  Throw in some smokiness and you have a modified Saison.  Plenty of flavor for a Saison with a dry finish.

Draft served in a tulip glass.  Rich brownish-black color with tan head.  Aroma of peppery spice, wheat, roasted malts and a little chocolate.  Taste adds more peppery spice (somewhat tangy) and some brown sugar sweetness.  Finishes dry, overall medium body and smooth.  Nice.

I was excited to try this one.  Had from 12 oz. bottle (2012) at Brasserie in Easton, MD.

Aroma is of slight pepper and Belgian farmhouse funk.  An interesting color, and the first time I have seen a black saison since trying De Viento at Jolly Pumpkin.  This one goes in a different direction, though.

A light taste here, with slight pepper and strong carbonation.  It is pretty unique, but no flavor stands out entirely.  Goes down easy, and is almost refreshing.  I would like to try this again.

Pepe Nero is a brown-black ale with huge brown foam on top.  The aroma has notes of stone fruit, plum wine, soft, toasted grain, alcohol and... chocolate?  It’s pretty full bodied.  It turns dry very quickly and vanishes upon the swallow, leaving the teeth a little chalky.  Nice, dark, resiny tones mingle, staying fruity but never veering into sweetness.  There’s a touch of phenol after the swallow.  A tangy aftertaste follows.  This is just a very tasty ale!  I chugged it at room temperature after letting it sit in a glass for a few hours.

Pours a rich deep umber color with a three finger off white colored foam that laces and sticks... Aromas are dark wheat, spicy belgian yeast and backnotes of chocolate, smokey roasted malts. On the palate it has good mouthfeel with an agressive bubble to keep this in the refreshing category. The flavors are roasted and earthy without being over the top... I do feel a slight sense of watered down quality does come through but after a bit of contemplation I feel it adds to the drinkability rather than detracts.

A colabrown beer with a medium and beige head. Aroma is quite strange, yeast, herbs, dark overcooked fruits and wet wood. Taste is slightly roasted, lots of yeast, dark fruits, lots of drying herbs in the aftertaste. Medium bodied, easy to enjoy. Quite strange beer that is not convinced, too much yeast and not very balanced.
Smoke and pepper. Would be awesome with a burger. Yeast taste, american new age hops(?). Sweet smooth smoke.

Bottle. Pours Dark brown with a medium beige head. The aroma is sweet fruity and light spicy with some malty notes. The flavour is ripe fruity with some yeasty and spicy notes. Light smoke and has a tart fruity finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber bottled Jan. 2011. Dark and nearly opaque brown like a porter, with a decent tan head, good retention, nice lacing. Nose is roasted malt and spicy Belgian yeasty. Mouth is a bit thick in the front, with malt and some mild yeast spiceness but that is overtaken by the roast, and everything fades pretty quickly. I wasn’t really impressed with this one, and it resembles a porter more than a saison, at least compared to what I’ve had so far.
Decent saison. Medium carbonation, with light Smokey spices. Dark beer with an easy finish.

12oz bottle. Clearish red/brown with a fizzy light tan head. Aroma of spicy rye, earthy yeast, dark fruit and caramel. Flavor is toffee malt, spicy yeast and a light tangy taste in the finish. Medium body with explosive carbonation. Nice beer, but sharing a bottle was enough for me.
12oz bottle poured a deep brown color. Decent head. Sweet, malty aroma that matched the tasted. Had hints of a Belgium beer sweetness. Great experience.

12 oz bottle to glass  whoa this is a saison??  dark dark brown rye malt aroma - niice.  thin med palate. avg carbonation.   not much in the taste dept - nothing bad but not much stands out - drying finish.  i took off a .10 b/c this isn’t a saison..
Ok, first of all, if you want to make a saison, then make a saison, don’t try to pawn off a half assed beligain quad as a saison. Black to ruby red color. Pepper and brown sugar in the nose.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a large head lots of carb. Tastes smells of dark fruit yeast little bit chocolate. Not bad not great.  A beer your not going to remember once it’s gone.
Sampled at Whole Foods ... yep.  Brown black beige head. Lots of chocolate nuts malts.  Malts chocolate biter and ok. A little watery. 7/3/6/3/13

Bottle at the Duchess of Cambridge, Stamford Brook - 12/07/12.
Deep brown to cola black in colour, very dark for a saison, medium tan head.
Grainy/yeasty aroma, farmland funk, must and a little dark fruit.
Taste follows nose with candy sugar, malt and raisen.
Smooth mouthfeel, medium body, good level of carbonation.

Pours dark black. The head was a bit much, lots of carbonation. The head literally rose 2 inches in my tulip glass, and yes I know how to pour a beer. After it sat, the nose was of Chocolate, raisins, green apple, and yeast. A little sweet on the first taste, with hints of coffee and chocolate. Later you can get just a hint of smoky nuts. Really yeasty too.

Bottle. Black pour with brown bubbly head. Spice, yeast and rye malt aromas. Flavor is more roasted malt forward with chocolate and smoked malt flavors dominating, spice and yeast like tones take a back seat.

(22 oz. (bottled 5/22/12) from Oak Street Provisions) Very, very dark brown, appears opaque. Two and a half fingers of tan head. Aroma of lilies, yeast, dark sour fruit. Flavor mostly of chocolate, dark sour fruit and yeast. Saison?

Pours an opaque ebony with a huge, aggressive head and smells malty and crisp.  The taste is crisp, too, with immediate rye malt and traces of raisins, vanilla, and hoppy bite.  I really enjoyed this.  It’s lighter than my usual stout favorites but was a refreshing summertime selection.

Bottle.  Pours clear black with a large, fizzy and effervescent tan head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy spicy rye malt, cookie and toast notes, plums, dates, figs, and raisins with spicy and earthy-minty hops.  Flavor is malt forward light hops and medium bitterness, moderate fruity esters and spices with a dry finish.  Medium body and heavy carbonation.

Very interesting brew.  The peppery yeast linger on the tongue, but doesn’t overpower.  Chestnut in color with high carbonation that gives a big head at first but quickly disappates.  The toasty malts are nice.

Dark chestnut in color with a medium sized off-white head. Head falls to a thin ring. Caramel, lightly toasted bread, candied ginger, molasses and a faint smokiness rounds out the aroma. Bright flavor - a bit surprising if you judge this beer initially only on its color - peppercorns, coriander and husky wheat atop some mild citrus fruits. Dry, mildly smoky pumpernickel rye finish. An interesting take on a saison, and a very fine drinker.

On draft at Churchkey in D.C.

The beer appears shockingly dark with a tan head. Initially, I think that I have been served the wrong beer, but alas, Pepe Nero is a dark saison. D’accord...The rye comes through quite strongly, with an odd and interesting aroma and flavor of funk. Not funky like wild yeast, or odd like I got a bad beer, just funky and odd. Ya dig? The flavor brings subtle chocolate and roast flavors, but I can’t discern peppercorns, per se. The feel is medium bodied with a solid carbonation level. Overall, this was intriguing and fun to try, but I’m not interested in having it again.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 02-23-2011

Minimal aroma. Light head that quickly flattens. Dark but not opaque beer. peppercorn flavor is mild on the back of the tongue that evolves into a something else.  The Saison funk is lacking - but that is also the case for their unaltered Sofie Saison. Overall an OK and not unpleasant beer but lacking in flavor nothing to rave about. Update: flavor deteriorated as the beer warmed and opened up further.

Bottled February 2011; Sampled July 2012

A steady pour into my small, St. Sebastiaan tulip produces a two finger thick, pale brown tinged, dirty tan colored head. The beer is a concentrated, chocolate brown color that shows some clear, amber hues around the edges if you hold it up to the light. The aroma smells predominantly of fruit, with plums and apples being most noticeable, up front, but there is a background note of spice and dark malt to round things out. The nose is slightly musty, a bit pepper like, there is an herbal / floral note here, as well as a subtle, dusty cocoa note. The malt here is quite a bit more subtle than I would expect from a beer with this color; once you really dig for it notes of chalky, whole grain spiciness come out as does some brown grain huskiness, and the aforementioned cocoa character.



This has a lively carbonation and is fairly light bodied. Up front the beer has an ample fruitiness that boosts the perceived sweetness. The finish has a light tartness that is accentuated by the carbonic acid, and there is a hint of bitter dark malt notes. The tartness & fruity esters combine to produce flavors of floral plums, a definite raisin like character. While I usually like my Saisons quite spritzy, the zippy carbonation here actually clashes a bit with the dark malt character; degassing this beer a bit helps to smooth things out. The finish has some estery and higher alcohol notes that add a certain bite to the finish, and there is also a phenolic, clove like character that is fairly noticeable. There is also a dusty cocoa, and brown malt astringency to the finish. The finish really has a certain spiciness to it, the spice character almost has a pungency to it (though that seems like the wrong descriptor in some way), and is definitely a bit woody; actually the piquant spiciness is found from the begging through to the end of each sip now that I have pinpointed it.



Better than I expected, as I was expecting this to be like Demolition or Pere Jacques; luckily this is a bit better than that, and something I am certainly enjoying. I like that the roast malt is fairly restrained, it definitely contributes to the acidity in this brew, and it provides a dusty, slightly roasted, hole-grain rusticity to this brew that works fairly well. The fruit character is really the dominant note here by a fairly big margin, but I like that it is well supported and that this beer still manages quite well to be balanced. The light body and quaffability also go a long way towards making this beer work.

Large head, brown, good lacing, mostly diminishing.

Roasted pepper aroma

Very smooth, light to medium body, slight pepper taste.  Wow very enjoyable.

Bottle. Bottled on 24.02.11. Pours a hazy dark ruby with a big khaki head. Decent lacing. Sweetish, tart, flowery, yeasty aroma with a cereal note. As it warms, the cereal note diminishes and the sweet and yeasty notes becomes more dominant, making it more well-balanced. The cereal note still lingers though. Flavour is almost sugary sweet, yet at the same time tart, making for an interesting blend. Notes of spice, pepper, wood and yeast. Finish is yeast, wood and alcohol and a lingering grassy and apple note and a faint note of plum as it warms. Overall okay, but too cloying and didn’t care for the cereal note in the aroma. Also, a bit too much carbonation. 31.07.12.

Bottled 4/16/2012.



A: Almost pitch black body with light only showing through the thin parts of my Dogfish Head stemmed glass, I see a furious stream of carbonation in the body. A dense billowing tan head sits on-top with a rather soft pour, be careful here. The head had great retention and is incredibly messy. This beer is stunning.



S: Very weak aroma, slight spice but mostly a chalky yeast aroma.



T: Whoa, this is very interesting. The intro is a tad smokey and roasted that builds up to a nice moderate level by the finish, mild rye hints are in the mid-taste but the roasted malts and smoke characteristics cover a lot of it up. A slightly spicy finish hints at some citrus that compliments this very well.



M: Medium bodied with fizzy that becomes sharp carbonation.



O: This is a very interesting beer though the dark characteristics take this over and take a bit away from what I was expecting. I am really enjoying this though for it’s interesting profile I’ve never experienced.

Strong, malty aroma has a firm, slightly sweet, slightly sour fruity overtone like a cider made from a mixture of pears and apples. It pours a dark reddish brown on the border between dark copper and mahogany with a thick, fluffy, rather persistent light tan head. Pleasing flavor has a fruity core, notes of apple and pear plus a hint of banana, along with malty and subtle caramel tones. Not overly sweet, just a teeny bit sour, just a teeny bit bitter. Smooth texture has good body and a decent amount of fizz. Definitely a beer to be sipped and savored, it hits the spot on a broiling summer afternoon.

2011 bottle.  Pours a very dark black color with almost no head.  Spicy belgian aroma.  Rye, smoke, pepper, and light fruit.  Taste is fairly bitter and very smooth.  The belgian yeast flavor is powerful here.  Medium body.  Finish is very smooth and lots of smokiness in the finish.  This is one of the better saisons I have had but its not one of my favorite styles.
Deep dark chocolate brown in color.  Bottle at Andy’s in bogota.  Malty caramel toasty aroma. Malty dry hop bitterness. Dark fruity flavor. Medium bodied.  Finish is dry. Very drinkable

Bottled 1/3/2011; drank today. Aroma is a combination of cola, pungent cherries, spicy peppercorns, horseblanket. Interesting, complex, not the most inviting, though, I have to say.

Looks dark brown, like root beer. Not a lot of yead, but then again it is over a year and a half old. More light passes through than expected. Does NOT look like a typical Saison, I can tell you that.

First flavor is cola, cherries, and a surprisingly spicy finish. There is hay and a musty (appropriate) quality. The Belgian funk is subdued, but it’s there: in fact, it’s a cross between a Saison and a Dubbel. 

Feels smooth and oily; very slick. This is a very, very nice beer. But given the fact that it purports to keep for five years, it seems to have softened a bit in the bottle. I must say, it gets much better as it warms up. Let it breathe after opening.

2011 bomber poured into a Duvel tulip. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a huge tan head and decent lacing. Very highly carbonated. Aroma is smokey and nutty with a subtle hint of Belgian spices. Honestly it smells more like a porter than anything else. The flavor is of roasted malts, sugar, rye, cocoa, and very mild spices. Mouthfeel is thin and very fizzy. Not bad overall, but there seems to be nothing saison about it.

12 ounce bottle.  It’s an interesting dark shade of brown, unusual for a saison, and it’s still fairly light in body.  The pepper and spice shine through nicely and add an enjoyable sophisticated feel to the beer.  It also has a smooth roasted smokiness and a sweet Belgian aspect that work well with the subtle spices.  My only complaint is that it’s a little flat on the back end and the flavor doesn’t last very long.  This is one of the best beers I’ve had so far from Goose Island and I’d put it in the B+ range.

The nose and taste are really full on this beer, truly enjoyable and complex.  It’s got pepper, soy sauce, and cola.  But the flavor also has a great unexpected but very aggressive smokiness to it.  My only issue was the palate.  Bubbles filled up the mouth too much and beyond that it was a bit watery.  Still, a really great ale!

Poured nice and was looking and smelling good to start. Unfortunately, this isn’t really my style of beer as reflected in my rating. I can see the appreciation for it, but for me it just wasn’t a huge hit.

This poured a meidum to light brown color with a beige head.  Aroma was lots of belgian yeast, some dark candy sugar, and roasted grain.  Flavor was much the same, much more dubbel esque rather than any type of saison, aside from the yeasty notes. No real sign of peppercorns either.

Pours black with generous root beer head. Earthy and decent and although it's not a great taste it is not bad either. Would drink again but would buy something else. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Delicious flavor would pair excellently with smoked or bbq meats.  Good on its own or with food

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

35.5 cl bottle at Black Door,bottled 28.12.2011

Aroma is sweet with lots of rye. Feels a bit like a rye pudding actually. Also some earthy notes typical to saisons. Flavour is sweet and really malty with sweetness from rye and some orange peel. Sticky palate and some warming alcohol after the finish. Also a weird, floury savor at the finish. Feels like a dessert or sugar candy, couldn’t find the saison behind all the rye.

Aroma of anis, prunes, and chocolate.  Pours black with a medium white head.  Taste is bitter and dry with notes of dark chocolate, floral, and rye.  It reminds me of when chocolate is soooo dark that it doesn’t taste good anymore.  Sophisticated but unenjoyable.
Aroma is roasted malts, yeast, and spices.  Pours dark brown with a big tan head.  Taste is raisins, coffee, and yeast with a little bit of hops.  Very good.

Bottle from March ’11 had in June ’12.  Meh.  Big sweet roasted malt nose with some belgian notes.  Dark translucent brown with big slow fading head.  Roasted malts, sweet...can kind of find the pepper if you look.  Disappointing.  Pretty one dimensional and almost cloyingly sweet.  Hoped for more rye profile and pepper nuances.  Ok, but glad I split the bomber.

Pepe Nero pours a nice brownish hue from the bottle. As it fills the glass, I caught a powerful red bursting through. A woody color comes forth when held to the light. There’s a strong, noticeable carbonation in the glass. The strong finger head is composed of very large bubbles. The froth takes it’s time dissipating. Smells like a saison with notes of funk, spicy yeast, belgian malt and some lemon zest. a bit of dark malt presence as well. 
Dark malty malts – lots of bread crust, good amount of soft roast, some toffee, some chocolate, background nutty & toasty malts, and lots of dark fruit sweetness – prunes & plums. Even a hint of smoke (that could also be from phenolics). Firm bitterness underneath – herbal with some spice & a back end hint of resin. Peppery aspect from peppercorns and /or yeast is there, but not terribly strong. More a lightish bodied porter than a saison, but nice regardless. Pepper grows late in the finish.Medium body, but just barely. And lightened quite a bit by active, expansive, and slightly coarse textured carbonation. Overall I was quiet impressed with the beer. Didn’t know what to expect from a dark saison, but I thought it was very interesting and worked well.
Vanilla aroma, some spices, Belgian plum/yeast.  Taste is similar - peppery, lighter finish than one might anticipate, lighter bodied.  Still full of good flavor.  Solid saison.

355 ml bottle. Black Door, Helsinki, Finland. 6.0%. Bottled 28/12/11.
Dark brown almost black colour with tiny tan head.
Aroma is quite unpleasant. Mild smoke, lactic notes, malt and something no so good in aroma. 
Flavour is a bit more drinkable. Malt, mild roastedness, mild fruity hops and farmyard touch in flavour. Very unbalanced and strange mix of different styles. There's no much Saison here. Disappointing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Bottle, 0.355 l - 2011 vintage, at Black Door, 20120616) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was almost non-existent. Aroma had smoke, spices and malts. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, Belgian style yeast, sweetness, spices, smoke, sourness,.sewer and bitterness. Aftertaste was almost burnt, a bit fruity and bitter. Too many things in this beer have resulted in only a unpleasant mess.

Pours nearly black with a steady, dark tan head.
Scent is peppery, earthy......a little fruit.
Taste is spicy up front, a little roast....slightly sour dark fruit....wood.
Very different....leaves a bit of annoying aftertaste.

Bottle from Ölkonsortiet 2012-06-15 Göteborg
AR: coco nibbels, coffee, chocolate, cherry wine, tar 
AP: dark reddish oak, high frothy fizzy beige head
F: fizzy, truffle chocolate, coffee, maderia, sugary sweetnees, fudgy

Pours a dark brown with a full beige head that lasts a long time.  Aroma is softer, being very grassy and floral with just hints of citrus.  Taste still remains a little bit floral, but there is more going on here than that.  Darker flavors dominate.  Caramel, chocolate, nuts, a touch of spicy pepper, and raisin.  Quite earthy actually.  Nutty, chocolate aftertaste.  Fuller body with nice carbonation.  Lots of lacing.  Good stuff.

2012 bottle. Pours a dark brown amber with a big, foamy, long lasting light tan head. Needs a better label because "belgian style ale" to me isn’t rye farmhouse saison. But once I got clear on that, it all came together all right. The spicy rye really comes through, but turns this into a one-note beer. No belgian yeast or sweetness to balance it out, so everything just falls flat. This is my first GI beer and it’s a big disappointment following the level of respect i’ve seen hoisted on them.

(Bottle) Pours dark brown with a nougat colored head. The aroma holds wallpaper glue, almonds, melted sugar, pepper, dark bread, dried herbs,  bubblegum, clove and milk chocolate. The flavour is light to medium sweet, light bitter and light acidic with notes of nobel hops, glue, bready malt, earth, some phenols and a tiny touch of fruits. The mouthfeel is too clean with a medium bodied. Tart fruits, grainy/dark bready malt, grassy hops and a phenolic touch on the finish. Medium bodied.

355 ml bottle bought @ The Bottle Shop Canterbury. Pours very dark brown with a rather small fizzy offwhite head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with red apples, cinnamon, overripe pears, vanilla, yeasty eaters, cloves, wallpaper paste, liquorice root, Sassafras, sweet dark bread and hints of black pepper. Taste is sweet, tiny sour and tiny metallic with dark bread, wood, cloves, black pepper, green apples, pears, lemon zest, grass, apricots and hints of yeasty esters, white paper, allspice, bubblegum, phenols land lemon juice. Mouthfeel is round, tiny sticky sweet, tiny tart and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and slightly sour with grapefruit juice, hay, black pepper, bubblegum, sweet dark bread and hints of allspice.

Goose Island es una cervecera americana que fue bastante potente en el panorama “craft beer”. Digo “fue” porque la adquirió el gigante InBev, tema que tuvo mucho debate en su momento. InBev al parecer les ha dejado seguir con su movida sin injerencias, sólo que ya no es independiente, pero bueno, eso para que cada cuál se lo plantee.

Huele a caramelito que da gusto, tal vez lo más predominante. Vienen notas de plátano que no nos las esperábamos, también a fruta madura.

Es negra como Luis Amaranto Perea (crack)  y al beberla viene primero un toque ácido que después se transforma en dulce, como a toffee. También algo de torrefacto por ahí suelto.

De cuerpo es bien cremosa, lo cuál es muy de nuestro gusto, y su espuma es dorada y muy bonita.

No es fácil de conseguir por estos lares pero vale la pena.

Appearance: Pepe Nero pours a nice brownish hue from the bottle. As it fills the glass, I caught a powerful red bursting through. A woody color comes forth when held to the light. There’s a strong, noticeable carbonation in the glass. The strong finger head is composed of very large bubbles. The froth takes it’s time dissipating. 

Smell: There’s a tartness up front, as with any saison. A vinegar flavor stands with the tartness but quickly leads into a fruity, almost strawberry aroma. A tinge of yogurt comes back, but only lightly. As the smells culminate, I catch caramel and roasty smokiness. 

Mouthfeel: Very light but large on the tongue. The beer stays together on the tongue, as if held together with a thickness on the interior. It closes incredibly smooth. 

Taste: The first taste I find is a (surprisingly) light tart sourness. It’s understated and really lets everything else shine while letting you know that this is still a Belgian. The pepper starts to blossom on the back two thirds of the tongue and is just spicy enough to be noticeable. Everything here blends well but starts to crowd the palate after a few sips. As the beer closes I start to notice a sweet pineapple or orange taste. That tangy citrus gets abruptly pushed though into a caramel flavor, closed by roasty malt. 

Overall: Goose Island makes some great Belgian beers and this is no exception. There were a few points where I felt this brew got a little "busy" and started to take away from the enjoyment. There’s a lot of flavor here and it’s hard to get you tongue into every nook and cranny. Still, this is more proof that the ladies and gents from Chicago are still putting out some good beer.

Bottle. Almost clear, really deep brown/black liquid with a red hue and huge light tan head. Aroma is quite spicy with notes of white pepper, cloves, smoke, ash, roasted malt, noble/earthy hops and dark fruits. The combination of the spicy notes from the Saison yeast and the peppery rye works well together. Taste is quite dry and light bitter with some light roasted notes, yeasty esters and fresh hops. A bit bland actually. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation, which works well in this type of beer. Quite interesting take on a Saison but I find it a bit boring.

Pours black with off white head and lots of sediment. Aromas are yeast, funk, some smoke. Nice mouthfeel. Dark dried fruit flavours combined with dark roasted malts, some smoky peppers as well. Nice beer.

Bottld. Pours a deep brown with a medium sized tan head. Fair lacing. Nose of roasted malts, spices and notes of yeast. Sweet flavor with roasted malts, chocolate and spicy notes. Medium bodied, creamy texture and soft carbonation. More dry in the finish and with a pepper and tiny malt bitterness. A nice brew indeed.

Bomber. Sweet lactose aroma much like a milk stout. Mostly opaque, brown body with red hues when held to light. Large, lasting tan head. I had tried tia once before and my recollection of it was pepper-forward. Served a little warmer this time and the pepper isn’t as evident, although there is a zing at the back of the tongue. Malty, and heavily carbonated. Good but not as memorable as I remember. I have the rest of the bottle chilling to see if it improves a little chilled.

2011 Bomber
Poured into a Brugse Zot glass. Two thick fingers of tan head. Dark brown, almost black color.
Ripe fruit on the nose; almost overripe peach or nectarine.
Balanced taste at first, moves to malty in the middle to end. There is something spicy at the very end, probably the peppercorns. But they come across very subtle.
Starts soft on the mouth, moves to crisp and bubbly at the end.
Overall good to go. Nothing weird, just a great drinking beer.
Bottle.  Spicy, barnyard yeast, malt  and fruit aroma. Dark brown with a moderate tan head. Roasty wheat, slightly funky yeast, spice, dark fruit, grass flavor. Light spritzy body. Very nice.

Had this before, but tried again at a World Wines and Liquor tasting. Pours dark reddish brown, into a plastic 4 0z. cup. medium carbonated head. Aroma is rich with spices, pepper, belgian yeast, dark fruit. Taste is fairly sweet up front with loads of pepper present. Some bitterness. Fairly quick finish. Light to medium body with some carbonation. Nice, simple but solid brew.

we lost contact .. . a dark saison, had 2 before and wasn’t impressed but this is G.I so i wanna try it .. . pours a deep tan brown .. light head .. light to medium foam .. . grain, sand, chip bark, and light burnt yeast .. . muddled and silly - this doesn’t fit .. . . i would have grabbed as many pancakes as i could hold and run!

2011 bottle at home. Pours dark brown with fizzy tan head that doesn’t hang around. On the nose its black pepper spice and toffee malt. Sweet up front with chocolate malt and a hint of vegetal horseraddish. A long sweet and spicy finish.

pours a deep dark brown hue with a small light brown head that is mostly diminishing
aroma of barnyard malt and some caramel
flavor is similar

Pours a deep dark brown, almost black with quite a large head that takes some time to reduce. Lots going on in the mouthfeel, chocolate orange, belgian malts, raisins, grapes. Sweet, maybe a little too sweet for me. Nicely carbonated, thick palate. Good beer

Bottle 33cl from Henrick thanks, a dark beer with huge brown head and good retention. Nose is on dried red fruit, dark candy sugar and alcohol. Aroma is on dark candy sugar, red fruits, dry body, belgian yeast, round caramel, slight burnt caramel notes, light spice notes such as Cinnamon, wood and light vanilla notes. Quite complex for a low alcohol beer.

Bottle.  First, I want to say that this is the most unique Saison I’ve had to date.  Actually, never would have thought it was a Saison from first pour and sip.  Pours dark with large lasting tan head.  Smell is raisins, toffee, spicy yeast. Taste is raisins, chocolate, some coffee, spiciness.  Taste is mild, but semi complex.  The yeast doesn’t dominate but blends well with the other flavors.  Quite nice.
pours a dark brown with a small off white head......malty..fruity aroma...decent amount of carbonation..a little bit of dark fruit flavor with some nice sweet spice..overall very enjoyable...
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is spices, malt, fruit. Flavour is vanilla, spices, malt, berries, hop, chocolate. Nice beer.

Appearance:  almost stout-like, with a near-black pour, a light tan head, and minimal soapy lacing.   Aroma: black pepper is prominent, over notes of chocolate, grassy barnyard, cherry syrup, leather, and tobacco.   Taste: as the aroma indicates.   Finish: spicy, medium-strong bitterness, talc-dry, with notes of bitter dark chocolate and ashtray.   Notes: MEH.  I was really looking forward to this after cellaring it for a year and change.  Just a big ball of black pepper and bitterness, with a rather unpleasant ashy finish.

Very attractive beer. Pours a rich dark brown with a growing head, dense and warmly colored. Rounded malty aroma, giving dark fruit, rye bread, and a soft spiciness. Solid flavor profile; finishes a bit more quickly than it might, but makes a solid first impression. Bubbly and entertaining palate, yet coating. Very nice beer. Bottle, 2011 on label.

Pours dark cola brown with a small tan head. Smells like figs and roasted malts. Taste is rich and complex with notes of fig, coffee, black pepper, clove, and earthy vegetables. Med bodied. Soft carbonation. Drawn out finish with a touch of sweetness and a toasty bitterness. Very complex and balanced, yet is simple to enjoy.
Bottle at Monk’s Café, Sveavägen, Stockholm, Sweden. This was a really coolveer, very interesting and special and very enjoyable. A slight hint of pepper in the aftertaste.

Bottle: &nbsp Nearly black, huge rocky beige head, nice lacing. &nbsp Has a toasted rye sort of nose, grassy, wheaty, slight dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Seems an interesting concoction. &nbsp Wheaty on the tongue, rye, roasted malt, semi-sweet, some dark pitted fruit like floral notes. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate, feels a little spritzy and bubbley on the tongue. &nbsp Roasty wheaty finish, but without that wheaty body. &nbsp Floral or barnish aspect of this Saison is light. &nbsp Definite rye, but I like my Saisons a bit brighter.

Se verse comme un porter avec des arômes de mélasse, poivre et malt rôti. La première gorgée se fait discrète mais les saveurs prennent leur place par la suite. Un croisement entre un London porter et une saison, chocolat, malt rôti avec une finale poivrée. Intéressante création.

Bomber. Bottled on 3/4/11. For some reason I’ve passed this beer up countless times in the past and I don’t think I ever would have bought it except for two things: it was recently mentioned in All About Beer magazine as an exceptional "Belgian Black Ale" and it was sitting on the discount shelf at my local beer shop. This is a 2011 bottle, a little over a year old and it states right on the label that it will improve with age up to 5 years. So there you go. Aroma is like toasted marshmallows; has a nice roasty smell. Pours impenetrable black with faint brown edges under a huge beige lacy head with excellent retention. Taste is unlike any saison I’ve ever had. It’s more like a big malty English porter. Hops are unnoticeable. Has a somewhat tangy finish. The peppercorns are very faint on the back of the throat after the finish, making me wish they were more expressive. Maybe they were when the bottle was fresher. Mouthfeel is a bit too foamy, carbonation average, body medium. Kind of a weird beer, but it’s pretty good.
36cl, Vintage 2011, American brew, from The Bottle Shop Canterbury, complex brew, spicy/sweet and slightly malty/roasted, easy to drink, very balanced, clear, good head, good brew, yet expensive!

[Bottle at the Bootlegger, High Wycombe] Black with a large beige head.  Mouthfeel is on the thin and fizzy side, but this is made up for by the flavours - it’s smokey, but not overwhelmingly so, with hints of coffee, malt and a little pine.  Pepper creeps through in the finish, but like the smoke it’s just the right amount.  A lovely beer, but could be better if the fizz was reduced a bit.
231011: Black color with a nice light brown foam with small bubbles. Good light smoke flavor. Fine roasted aftertaste.
I was surprised at how dark this one was. It pours with a nice head, but was largely unremarkable. Not bad, but not one go out of the way for. Not much smell to it at all.
Mycket diskret, lite mjölkig doft- kanske med en aning hö. Annars är smaken mycket tunn

Black in color with a large, light brown head that had lots of staying power and left good lacing.  Smelled and tasted quite yeasty and peppery, lots of spices, hoppy, with lots of roasty malts.  Body is highly carbonated and somewhat heavy for a saison, almost syrupy.  It’s tasty albeit a bit on the "not quite what I expected" for a saison.  Definitely try this if you like saisons though, it’s pretty good and definitely different.

12 oz bottle; might have had this before via a bomber but can’t remember; dark brown pour and almost black; trace white head; some slight diacetyl is obvious with dry chocolate and maybe rye; kind of a stale sweetness with dried fruit too and almost like spoiled lettuce; definitely some buttery and stale choco malt with some stale orange; ugh; thin mouthfeel and generally unenjoyable all around; strange husky and vegi flavor profile mixed with dry chocolate; not much of a saison; drinks more like an infected brown ale to me

Bottle.

Almost black with a medium, creamy slightly tan head. Aroma and taste of chocolate, some pepper and yeast, malt and caramel. Not bad but not that exciting either.

Not exactly what comes to mind when I think of a saison.  Pours darker than cola brown with a thin head.  The aroma is full of spice with some yeastiness and earthy hops.  The flavors are sweet and roasty, and yet fleeting.  I honestly couldn’t tell if I liked it or not.  Interesting, but not particularly enjoyable.

12 oz bottle pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts, spice and some nice yeast.  Taste is yeast, pepper and a hint of the malt.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes.  First reviewed 1/23/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

Pepe Nero pours a maple brown color with tints of walnut and ruby in the corners, along with a gorgeous fluffy beige head. It majestically sits on top, retaining very well, and leaving a web of lace on the glass.

Tons of yeast spice, black pepper, toasted malt, relaxed toasted malt and a bit of chocolate create a fairly unique aroma.

The taste starts with a soft sweetness, some general dark fruit notes, and a hint of cocoa. Lots of fruity yeasty esters that I expect out of the style. A full helping of black pepper completes the spiciness. Light earthy hops finish out the taste. The finish is lightly bitter but a little bit more sweet.

The mouthfeel starts out juicy with the sweetness, slowly drying out over course of the sip, It finishes fairly dry. A fairly full body for the style, with medium creamy smooth carbonation.

I have not had a black saison before, but this is a valuable addition to their lineup. Definitely something I will come back to when I am thinking about a GI, particularly after their very middle-of-the-road Belgian series thus far.

A really nice saison, if not quite a match to the greats of the style.  Pours a dark brown with fluffy, medium brown head, not unlike a dunkel.  Nose is yeasty with grass and spicy notes.  Flavor is much the same, with the grassiness and nice pepper flavors intermingling, and taking turns at various points during a single mouthful.  Yeast comes across in the finish, with rye as a faint afterthought.  Delightful.
Bottle, pours black to cola @ edges, rimy off-white head, spicy, lightly vinous aroma, rich, earthy flavor w/ lively carbonation, finishes bone dry, very nice

Bottled. Reddish brown coloured. Dense light brown head. Aroma of yeast, some ripe fruits, light smoke, vague roast and  some spice. Flavour as well yeasty, caramelly, vaguely smoked, spiced and with some ripe fruits. Quite sweet. Medium to full bodied. Has a dry and yeasty bitterness in the end.

Pours like a porter, smells like a saison.  Tons of gray-mocha head.  Aroma of sweet floral citrus and light fruity esters.  Slight acidity.  Flavor starts fruity, sweet, and citrus and ends with super light cocoa and roast.  Mild olive.  Somewhat dry and with lingering faint roast.

355 ml bottle. Dark brown. Clear. Dusty licorice aroma with hints of chocolate and raisins. Small light beige head. Peppery flavours with toffee and licorice. Body is rather light. Belgian yeast character. Some sugary sweetness in the finish. A little dull.

Loads of chocolate malt in the nose, a bit of pepper and  yeastiness when it warms.  Thankfully much more interesting palate.  Lots going on there and it would take repeat samplings to detect it all.  Lots of spiciness, earthiness, rye, the sour, a bit of cola.  Clear, with a reddish tone to this one with a really thick head and sloppy lacing. Really enjoyable.

12oz bottle thanks to thirdeye11.
Dark brown with some off-white head.  Spicy Belgian yeast, roast, and chocolate aromas - chalky mouthfeel with some smoke and cinnamon spice.  Interesting but not really my bag.

Bottle. Deep brown body, small white head. Nose is mild, with some hints of yeast and raisins. Hints of coconut, soap and banana. Taste is soapy notes of raisins and dark malts. Tart, grainy rye tones and astringent herbal hop hints. Surprisingly mild in both taste and aroma, and it seems like the beer is trying to say something but gets muffled somehow. Medium mouthfeel, prickling carbonation. A bit "meh", actually.

THOUGHTS: One of the best black saisons I’ve tried. Roasty but still saison like.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark red that was nearly black in the glass with a large to huge, tan head that mostly but slowly diminished and left virtually no lacing. The aroma had moderate roasted malt and chocolate; light grassy hops; light to moderate peppery and dusty yeast; slight funky yeast and cherry; a little citrus; and spicy rye. The initial flavor was lightly sweet and ever so slightly bitter; while the finish was moderately sweet, light to mod acidic and slightly bitter. There was roasted malt, a little chocolate and sour coffee, grassy hops, citrus, peppery yeast, dusty yeast, spicy rye and a little more coffee. The medium body was sort of creamy and then dry with fairly fizzy carbonation and a light astringent finish.

355 ml. bottle. Very dark colour with a deep red hue. Huge, light tanned head that slowly collapses to a thick cap. Fat lacework. Definitely Belgian styled: The aroma is spiced and peppery, with a earthy note. The rye kicks in with a smoked malt flavor. Medium body with an oily feel, soft carbonation. Nice finish with earthy yeasts, and a roasted note. An unusual take on the saison style, that worked fine for me.

Pours a deep mahogany with luscious tan head.  Nose is spicy peppercorns and fig jam.  Light, dry, crisp bod over flavors of cocoa, coffee, cola, a little tobacco and some dried fruity Belgian inspired funk.

12 oz bottle shared by Jimmie. Poured a brown body with burgundy edges and a small to average sized creamy light beige head. Aroma of very sugary dark chocolate, wet brown bread and Chardonnay. Flavor of  sugar, dark fruit meat, bad banana skins, smashed dates. Nice body though, soft carbonation and a medium body
Clear black color. Pepper was noticeable in both aroma and taste. IMO, a quality brew---but I just didn’t enjoy the taste!

355ml bottle. Dark mahagony with good lasting frothy beige head. Nice smooth spicy and floral aroma, Saison typical overall and contrary to what the colour lets expect. Concerning the taste the dark side cannot hide. Constant sweet liquorice undertone. A bit acidity, maybe some anise. Noticeable carbonation. Yeasty finish. Pepper starts around 3/4 and leaves an aftertaste. Interesting, diversified but not completely delicious.
Bottle - big foamy head, interesting dark amber color for a saison, fruity Belgian yeast aroma and flavor - much lighter than its color would indicate

The Goose Island Pepe Nero is described as a Saison/Farmhouse Ale, and should weigh in at about 6% abv. It’s pretty obviously not the Saison I’m used to, and I’m anxious to get the top off this brew. The Pepe Nero pours out an exceptionally dark shade of brownish-red. At first I thought it was black until I tried snapping a couple pictures. The foam was very subtle at first but then came to life and nearly over-flowed my DFH snifter. The foam is full of large bubbles forming a rocky surface with just a slight tint slight red/rusty color.

As the foam dissipates very little lacing is left behind a soft stream of bubbles throughout the duration of my sample bottle.  The nose on the Pepe Nero is very, very subtle. I give it a few really good swirls and get my nose as far into the glass as possible. I’m only getting very slight hints of chocolate, cola, and a little roasted malts. The closest thing I can compare this to is sort of like an earthy, rustic version of a Quadrupel. 

On the palate, the Pepe Nero is just as complex and equally as subtle.  Very soft hints of malty sweets, a little bit of coffee and chocolate here and there, and just a touch of dry bitterness on the finish. I let the Pepe warm completely to room temperature before finishing and the Pepe only gets better! Somewhere between a big belgian quad and a softer style stout, the Pepe Nero is in a class all it’s own.  I can hardly wait till the Goose Island beers are available regularly here in CT.

I normally avoid Goose Island’s yupscale beers since they seem to have enough fans in Chicago already.  I tried this because I’m curious to sample any dark beer that might be different.  Yes, this was something new for me: a dark peppery Saison..  Although the bottle says "Belgian Style Ale" it pours a very dark brown, almost black, with hardly any head.  Bomber dated 3/04/2011 and purchased / tried today. Weak on the nose, except for some faint hops.  Thin on the mouthfeel, but with noticeable carbonation and a definite pepper taste and slight bitterness.  Aroma is not as complex as I had hoped for., and I didn’t see any if the promised funky sediment. Roasted malts and pepper remain in the long finish. Mildly disappointing.

Hm I’ve never had a dark saison before.......Light aromas of pepper, spices and roasted malt. Decent sweet candy flavors balanced by the spiciness of the pepper and roasted malt. Mouthfeel was a bit light and boring. Overall I guess it’s an interesting and unique beer but it could be a lot better.

Pours a dark mahogany color, nice thick tan head. First aromas of rye and spice with a slight Belgian-esque sour to it. Flavor is definitely different. Roasted up front with a tad of sweet/sour with a nice peppery taste and ending with a Belgian style soury goodness.

Bottle from Ales By Mail. Pours dark ruby red with fairly high carbonation. Fizzy white head. Aroma is spritzy tangy chocolate witha touch of roast meat juice. Really appealing. Quite thin and watery on the palate. Lime and lemon chocolate then a thin chocolate aftertaste. A spiked pepper high drying to a iron edge. The gravy taste is still there and it really works. Will be saving a bottle or two as recommended to se how he flavours develop, but this a wonderful chocolatey spritzy easy-drinking beer.

This beer did next to nothing for me. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a medium sized foamy beige head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma was dryish, roasty and wheaty. The flavor was dry, a bit roasty and woody with notes of wheat, pepper, clove and anise. The finish was long, dry, woody and roasty. Medium body. Eh.

Brewery: Goose Island Brewing Co

Date: July 04, 2011

Mode: Bottle

Source: Total Wine, Vegas

Appearance: clear very dark brown, frothy tan head

Aroma: dry spicy aroma, very earthy

Flavor: rich malt flavor, dry and earthy, spicy with a peppery edge, plenty of bitterness along with the earthyness and spicyness

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20

Rating: 3.1/5.0
Drinkability: 7/10

Score: ** /4
Bottle.  Pours medium dark with a smallish tan head.  Aroma and flavor are quite roasty, some rye tang, some smoke and spice, some good Belgian earthiness.  Satisfying beer.

750 mL bottle (2011 vintage).  Pours a dark black/brown with medium a tan/beige head.  Aroma is slightly subdued and not overpowering; mostly spiciness with some yeast.  Flavor is mostly of roasted malts and some yeast.  The finish is a bit abrupt, a tad watery.  The beer seemed to get better as I drank it, but there really isn’t a lot of complexity here. Maybe a little too watery.

Pour black dark brown light beige head with good lace. Aroma pepper, belgian yeast, fruity, grassy, light fruitiness, spicy, mild abv. Taste pepper, rye, grassy, light smoke, bready, good malt backbone balanced bitterness. MF medium body with fine fizzy carb. Really tasty brew both on tap and from bottle well done.

2011 bomber from Ledgers. Nose is roasty, lightly smoky rye with hints of candi sugar and pepper. Clear dark brown with a big, long lasting beige head. Flavor is peppery, rye, and hints of tartness and caramel sweetness.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with off whitehead. Aroma has faint vegitable with hints of datlrk roasted grain. Flavor much the same. Overall, solid beer!

Bottle from SL, one of those brews you drink a second time cuz you think you liked it and never got around to rating it the first time. The pour was dark brown to black with a tan to chocolate colored head. The aroma was peppery roasted chocolate and caramel. The flavor followed, metallic notes mixed in there, phenolic spices, roasted elements, dried dark fruits. The mouthfeel was highly carbonated which made the body seem medium, who knows. A decent brew, but the metallic type caramel notes made it seem imperfect for sure, just not clean and crisp as these can get with the carbonation and phenolic bite..
Pours a dark brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is of rye, roasted malts, spices, and some yeast.  Flavor is lighter with the roasted malts and rye dominating.  Light mouthfeel as well.

On tap at Blue Tusk. Brown with a biege head. Nuts, grain, somewhat sweet, earthy, bit prickly, roasted yet caramel malts. Average carbonation, medium bodied, dry ending, very nice with coriander and some malt that leave a nice coating on the palate as things dry out.

Pours dark reddish brown, medium head. Aroma is rich with spices, pepper, belgian yeast, dark berries. Taste is fairly sweet up front with loads of pepper present. Some bitterness. Fairly abrupt finish. Light body with some carbonation.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted caramel and dark fruit. Flavour is roasted caramel, alcohol, dark dried fruit and light nutty notes.

Pours dark reddish brown to near black with a thin foamy tan head. Notes of debittered black malt, toffee, chocolate, red wine, dark vinous fruit, black pepper, spice, cardamon. Full bodied with lively carbonation. Interesting, but I don’t care for this yeast variety.

Draft at Dexters.  Opaque brown-black, thick beige head.  Sweet, the body is a touch watery.  Some fruity undercurrents.  Mellow chocolate. The pepper is noticeable, but not dominating.  Odd, an interesting one-off.

Nov 21, 2011: 12 oz bottle from October 2011, which lets me later on compare to the bomber I got in January. Poured in the recommended GI tulip glass, it kicks up a healthy head of foam over a solid black body. Smell brings in some nice  spicy farmhouse ferment memes. For looking so thick and rich, I gotta remember this is "just" a 6% ale, so not to expect another BCS. Instead it’s a nice, slightly hearty cross between a saison and a Belgian style stout. Dark but not roasty malts with a good dose of funk. Small deposit of yeast in the bottom of the bottle. It is still pretty heady, aided by the light level of saison and rye spices, with nothing dragging the palate down.
Rating for 5/13/15, from Jan. ’11 bomber. This has really aged well. Yeah, the spiciness and yeast has settled down, but it leaves me with a rich malty blackness in my tulip. Did not gush over, thank goodness, just a sturdy layer of fizzy foam that settled in leaving rings of lace. A thick caramel malt more accentuated by peppercorns than rye malt. Mellowed out malts seem to make this beer feel stronger, but it’s still just 6%, according to the 2011 label. Nose has a bit of cereal grain, and has lost any trace of the funk or saison that I might have smelt 4 years earlier.
Bumping the overall rating up from 3.9 just because this one aged surprisingly well!

Bottle at home. Dark brown/black pour with a bubbly tan head that fades. Smokey, herbal, vanilla nose. Chocolate roast malts also. Palate is rich sweet saison with a real chocolate note. Finish is yeasty and long. Never had a dark saison before, and I love this!

Pours black and opaque. Head was tan and thick with lots of lacing. Pepper and spice hoppiness with some bread notes. Bitter and astringent. Some toasted flavor and black malt but not overwhelming. Spicy and lingering finish. I’m not a saison fan and I think this one meets the average.
Not a typical beer I drink but really enjoyed it.  Chocolate and malty aroma, dark but clear pour (if that makes sense) like poring pop onto a glass.  Can taste the pepper. Will have it again

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of cookie, nutty, roasted and milk chocolate, herbs and cooked orange for the hops, light to moderate dough, earth and musty for the yeast, with background notes of raisin, date, brown sugar and pepper. Head is large, creamy turning rocky, light tan with excellent thick lacing and is fully lasting. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly sweet, acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, creamy with a lively to fizzy carbonation. Nice dark dried fruit aromas with a complex yeast component, a very tasty Saison.

12oz bottle from rozis and the head on this is huge and settles slowly taste is dominated by the Belgian yeast, all I taste is that yeast no farmhouse no blanket nothing but that Belgian yeast not my fav style and certainly on the downside for GI

Bottle.Pours dark amber with an off-white head.Aroma of spices, malt, fruitiness, chocolate and vanilla. Flavor is sweet and malty with some vanilla oak, chocolate, yeast  and roasted grains.Medium body, lively carbonation.
Great beer. first dark saison, wouldn’t have known if I disn’t see it on the bottle. Dark brown, with an almost fruity smell. Tastes of Smokey vanilla. One of our new favorites!

12oz bottle from Pick’s poured into a snifter. 2011 vintage bottled January 3rd. Pours black with about a finger of white head. Aroma of smoke, light chocolate and a bit of rye spice. Taste is light bitter. Taste of smoke, chocolate and spicy yeast. Medium bodied with a thick texture. Very lively carbonation and a long, very dry finish. Overall, not too bad. Nothing I would drink again but pretty good for a style I really don’t care for.
Pours a really dark brown.  the nose is a combination of sweet treacle and peppercorns. Yeasty flavour.
