Dark brown with fluffy head and awesome lacing in my chalice.  Roasted chocolate aroma and flavor with zingy Belgian yeast and some light fruit flavors.  This sill works together for me.  I loved it.  Chalky thick mouthfeel.  Great beer.

Date: November 4, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Zipps Appearance: Opaque  dark brown with large amount of head. Aroma: Belgian yeast, malt and spice. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, medium bodied and smooth. Other: Bottle was aged 8 months and I would like to try this aged longer next time.  Very interesting and excellent beer!

3/4/11 Bottling... Poured near black with an off-white head.  Nose hand some smoke, and rye spice.  Dry, estery east with loads of rye spice and bitterness, cocoa, phenols, and hits of campfire smokiness. A little bit drying in the finish.

Bottle: Poured a black color ale with a medium brown foamy head with average retention and light lacing. Aroma of light spicy yeast notes with some Belgian malt with light notes of spices. Taste is an interesting mix between some solid Belgian rustic malt notes with some peppery notes and some spicy yeast. Body is about average with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very solid offering with an interesting mix between the rye malt and the spicy yeast strain.

650 ml. bottle. Bottled 03/04/11. Pours a fluffy, lasting, light beige head, with attractive lacing, over a clear, brown (SRM 30) body...nose is light smoke, spicy rye, bit of citrus....taste is light smoke, touch of toffee/caramel, bit of citrus, finishing with a medium smoked pepper, dry throughout...mouth feel medium, carbonation adds creaminess. This is really a Smoked beer rather than a Saison. The smoke dominates the aromas and flavors, not unpleasantly, but helps to hide the more subtle Saison style. Additionally it most certainly does not look like a Saison. To sum up, this is a rather nice beer, but it is NOT a Saison. BJCP 7/3/14/4/6

Dark cola colored pour with a massive persistent khaki head.  Faint aroma of toffee and caramel with a hint of pear ... and something else ... root beer?  Slight malty nutty flavor with a hint of leather and a touch of sweetness.  Pepper is subtle but there.  Finishes nice and dry.  Medium/light bodied mouthfeel with a nice effervescent creamy carbonation.  Wonderful subtle champagne like beer!

0.33l bottle @ Monk’s Café Sveavägen, Stockholm. Pours a deep brown-red body with a small quickly fading and sidesticking off-white head. The aroma has dark malts, licorice, burned and smoky tones and some cardboard as well. Lively to aggressive carbonation levels and a nice fizzing-oily mouthfeel. Flavors also light dark malty, some licorice, more burned tones, nuts and it ends with a dry bitterness and a subtle smoky aftertaste. Quite delicate and nice stuff indeed.

Appearance: beautiful cherry and mahogany woods, old, polished, and deep. Voluminous tan head resembles freshly frothed cappuccino. Head is dense mousse which caves in slowly like a reverse donut – thick. Lace sticks full circle.


Nose: dry, earthy, twiggy, and rich with dense dark fruits – plums and grapes. Acorns and almonds. Grape seeds bitter and tannic. Haystacks and stable dust with a faint and pervasive essence of saddles and blankets. Old leather.


Palate: plums and raisins. Earth, twigs, and fall leaves in the finish – crispy and crunchy. Soft frothy smooth mouthfeel. Raisins and figs lead into cakey fig newtons in the back. Oiled leather and saddles. Dry nutty stones also in the back. Dry tannic thirst-inducing quaff to quaff. Dried leaves and twigs. Spice in the breath.


Final Thoughts: loved this beer! No. I really did. I love rye and saisons and Goose Island beers in general so twas no surprise the Pepe Nero was a divine treat. My only regret was that I had but one bottle to enjoy.
Bottle. Pours deep brown to red. Dark fruity malts and belgian yeast on the nose. Lots sweetness and spice. Quite good.
Pours black.  Aroma is of yeast coffee smoke and malt.  Flavor is pretty much the same.  I’ve been drinking dogfish fort for the last hour so you must forgive me if I’m not in my right state of mind.

Bottle 2011. Big  slice of brown head on dark liquid. Moderate spice and Belgian yeast aroma. Very nice warm spice flavor rolls and bounces around the mouth. Light drinkable Belgian with a sweet honey note.  More nut and chocolate than Belgian Saison funk. Tasty enough.
Sample at KC Beerfest 10-22.  Comes a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of spices, yeast, malt and some chocolate.  Taste is roasted malt, spices, smoke and coffee.  Very interesting.
Crushed with TheRon.  Pours a dark brown with a dissipating head that shows high carb. Fruity, spicy, musty nose. Medium bodied with a nice fruity flavor with some esters coming through. Nice brew.

wow! what a strange but wonderful beer!
pours a really really deep dark red,  looks black until you hold it to the light.
the aroma and taste are something i have never come across in a beer.  the smell is packed with black olives and a sense of vegetable that i couldn’t pinpoint. in the mouth it feels silky smooth with a really soft carbonation.  the flavour packs more black olive but there is so much more in there and the final lingering peppery dryness finishes a very distinctive beer.

355ml bottle from Mybrewerytap



Pours dark brown/black with a small brown head. Aroma has weird murky notes with hints of rye and smoky ash. Taste is slightly smoky with some spicy and fruity notes. Finish has a lot of rye and murky notes. Very untypical saison, but unfortunately quite unbalanced and slightly strange taste even.

355 ml bottle.

Pours a reddish brown colour and a small white head. Aroma of smoked malts and dried fruits. Flavour of musty smoked malts, dried, almost rotten fruits, pepper and light citrusy notes. Yeast is there as well, maybe a bit too much. Medium bodied, dry mouthfeel and a malty, spicy finish. Weird musty saison, not refreshing at all.

Bottle 355ml @ Papsoe

Pours cloudy dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, wheat and pepper. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

cloudy red amber, smooth offwhite head.
yeasty fruity aroma, also dark malts.
flavor is roasted malts, hops, very faint spices. while the aroma is saison like, the flavor is more like a dark ipa.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Pours a hazy reddish brown with a huge and frothy beige head leaving a solid lacework. The nose has quite some brown sugars  - and yeast. Medium body, overripe dark fruits and spice with a subtle yeastiness and some late hops. Not too shabby. 131011
Pitch dark brown body with an off white head. Very nice yeasty and spicy aroma with lemon and smoke. Very nice spicy flavour with chocolate, caramel and fruits, with a dry finish.

Bottle, 2011 vintage. It pours a nice, dense, beige head over a very dark reddish brown body, with some lacings left too. Looking very cute. The aroma is smoke, sweetish and lighlty smoked. Some peppery notes and citrusy hops escapes too, and also a little yeasty touch. It’s smooth on the palate, although a bit too carbonated. Full-bodied and semi-dry. Some Belgian-style fruityness, along with roasted malts, smoke notes, citrus peel and a spiced hint. Quite bitter finish. Although I don’t identify this as a saison, it’s a nice beer indeed. 111012
Bottled. A deep red beer with a huge tan head. The aroma has notes of malt, caramel, and fruit. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, esters, fruit, and caramel, leading to a dry yeasty finish.

Sample from Augusta Bottoms Beer Fest. Poured a mahogany color with a smaller but decent head. Aroma was spices, black pepper, and some malts. Flavor was spices and some hop bite in the finish. Floral, banana and pepper. Great beer.

Brown coloured and hazy. Has an off white head, mostly lasting. Roasted aroma, crisp, hoppy. Flavor starts moderate sweet, lactic notes, roasted, faint smoke, moderate bitter finish. Creamy texture and soft carbonation.
bread, toast, roasty, brown, clear, light brown foam,light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Bottled@Monks Cafe Sveavägen, Stockholm. Quite much pitch black colour, small beige head. Aroma is very much quadrupel like even though the low abv. Also quite spicy notes. Flavour is toasted, mild roasted malts with some herbs, spices and quite raisiny and plummy as well. Like drinking a light quadrupel!
Bottle ourtesy of Drowland: Poured a dark brown with thin tan head. Aroma was glowing with clove and spice. taste is similar with a spicy barnyard grit and roasted malt.

Bottle, 12 oz, bottled 02/24/11: Very dark brown beer with a reddish hue and a slowly diminishing cappuccino-foamy head. Very fresh, spicy, slightly sweet and rather funky aroma with roasted, nutty notes of caramel and cacao and some delicate tartness from the belgian yeast-strings. Taste is medium sweet, fruity, medium bitter, light sour with an oily mouthfeel and a dry, bitter, astringent and very spicy peppery finish, that really tickles the tip of your tongue. Lively carbonation. An usual but well executed mix of styles: Yeasty saison-notes, a dash of Orval-funk and hints of an american styled brown ale.

A dark brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of fruits like prunes, malts with hints of chocolate. The taste is fruity, a lot of fruits, some sweet chocolate with a nice bitter. The aftertaste is sweet bitter.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a dark cola color witt a huge bubbly tan dark tan head.  The nose smells faintly of cocoa, roasted malt, and yeast.  The flavor is impressive with light notes of toasted coconut, yeast, smoke, a slight nuttiness, and some mineral notes.  I really like this brew.  Medium to full body that’s lightened by an abundance of carbonation.  A light roasty bitterness lingers.  I really enjoyed this brew and highly recommend it.  Definitely different for a saison.
Bottle from Euston Tap. Dark brown, smallish head. Fruity and peppery aroma. Semi-dry, some tart wheaty fruitiness. Overall, quite drinkable, but not revolutionary.

Bottle in a pint glass - pours dark and clear brown with lots of beige head and provides lacing. Nose is coffee malts and smokiness. Aroma is fruity and pruny or plums with traces of candy flavors. Taste is sweet and a tiny bit sour. Aftertaste is medium in length and sweet. Makes me think of a homemade remedy to combat constipation - not necessarily bad but odd nonetheless. Far better than its  granddaughter Sofie overall despite it bein the same style.

(12oz bottled 1/3/11) clear rich brown/amber with lasting fine tan head. Nose of Belgian yeast, chocolate, stewed tomatoes and cinnamon. Taste of stewed tomatoes, tons of spices, just gross. Very carbonated and a dry finish.
Bottle. Pours a black color with a small off-whit ehead. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty caramel aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty finish with hints of caramel.
Bottle at GBBF. Black body, brown head. Aroma has light smoked malt, berries and some lactic notes. There is definitely some fruity sweetness normal to rye beers. Leaves quite dry aftertaste.

deep brown, tan head, light lacing... belgian yeast, light spice, light smoke, very spicy... good flavor, creamy, roasty smoky, spicy, though a bit muddled, lively, medium bodied, great flavor, spicy....
Very dark + red with a decent head. Smells flowers, roasty and coffee. Tastes spicy and bitter. Lots of carbo, full body.
Dark brown pour with a small tan head. Lots of Belgian yeast in the aroma, along with grain, brown sugar and light funk.  Spicy, yeasty, funky flavor.  Very nice!

Bottle @ Joes Tasting shared with Joes and Dutchdrebus. Small to medium sized beige head. Nice dark brown color with a dark red glow coming through when held into the light. Smell smokey, pepper, light roastyness, weird. Taste only some spices and bitter. Firm carbo, medium body. Saison beer??
Great refreshing Saison - just a hint of funk and a strong malty taste. Really enjoyed this.

tart aroma, that changes to a roasted aroma quickly. Pours an opaque black, with a huge light tan head. Mild rye taste, with hints of smoke and roast. Slightly slick mouthfeel, with good level of carbonation. Very light on the palate, and very drinkable. I’ll be grabbing a couple of bottles of this to cellar and see what happens

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting light brown head. Lovely. Very dark red body. Herbal sweet roasted malt aroma., Mildly peppered smoke roasted malt choccolate flavor without much hops bitterness but the beer is not exactly sweet. High carbonation. Dry finish. Short aftertaste.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Tulip. Bottling date of 1/3/11.

Appearance: Very dark ruby with nice tan head, but does not leave much lacing.

Aroma: Banana, molasses, clove and pepper. Not as pungent as most Saisons, as the roasted malt may temper the classic crisp Saison aroma.

Taste: Tastes like a mix of banana and molasses upfront, with hints of chocolate and ripe fruit. Finish is more spicy, with clove and pepper, and a light roasted bite.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, fairly smooth body, dry finish. Creamier than the typical Saison.

Overall: Comes across as a more mellow Saison with just a touch of roasted malts (most noticeable by the molasses aroma and taste). Also, reminds me a little of a Dunkelweizen. Overall, mellow but very drinkable and enjoyable.

From Skjold Burne, Aarhus, DK.
Bottled, 010911.
Brown with beige head. Aroma of fruit and yeast. Flavor has some roasted malt and smoke notes.

Bottle.  Reddish brown beer with a strong frothy head.  The aroma is malty and spiced with a touch of sourness, and the flavour is particularly malty and slightly sherry like with a mildly bitter and spiced finish.  Overall a nice strongly malty and spiced beer.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, nuts, tart fruit. Taste is malt, yeast, caramel, sweet and tart fruit. Thin body, highly overcarbonated. 030911

2011 vintage, bottled February 25, 2011. 22 oz bottle from Chevy Chase Wine & Spirits in Washington DC, served in a tulip. Pours hazy chestnut with a tall, frothy tan head. The head mostly remains and leaves lots of fine lace. On the nose, there are notes of roasted malts and smoke, along with grass and pepper. The flavour begins moderately dry with smoke and roasted malts. Slightly sweet malts begin to come through towards the end, along with a peppery note. The finish is long, dry and roasty. On the palate, it is medium in body with a dry, acidic texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice saison with roasty and peppery notes. A little too smokey for my taste, but well made nonetheless. 2011-09-02
Just what you’d expect from a black rye saison: toasty, tangy, pleasantly bitter, with a slight peppery snap.  Has a bit of a homebrew funk to it.

Bottle in Euston Tap. Pours black with virtually no head. Nose is yeasty, estery, fruity hops. Taste is like a swartzbier with belgian yeast. Black sugar sweet, with yeast, and bit of pepper. Body is fairly thinnish. Not sure about the combination of styles and flavours here.

A deep dark saison with a thick brown head. In aroma, a nice peppery chocolate with notes of orange peels, coriander, very Belgian. In mouth, a nice smooth chocolate with herbal qualities, quite smooth and nice, lighter than expected but good. On tap at Oregon’s Brewers Fest July 29 2011.

Dark pour big brown head thick lace 5
Spicy but really light touch of nut 7
Full rich pal4
A little nutty a little bitter coccoa a bit flat flavor 6
Ok nothing special 12 odd touch of smoke in the aftertaste

Bottle at Chris O’s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2011. Dark brown color. Sweet aroma with raisins, licorice, vanilla and restrained pepper. Flavors of vanilla, raisins, pepper and chocolate. Roasty and spicy notes does not combine well here.
Not as black as I expected.  A lightly fruity (dates) and spicy nose.  Dry and spiced in the mouth with some interesting esters.

Rerate: Well I bought it again "by accident" at Fermentoren, Aarhus. The fruity acidity is still there, so it is probably intended. Not a bad beer though. Original rating: 355 ml bottle, from Ølkonsortiet, Aalborg. ABV is 6%. Dark brown colour, nearly black. Huge and lasting beige head. Pleasant "Belgian" ale aroma with spicy / peppery and fruity notes. Hints of coriander, banana, citrus and cloves. The  flavour is citrussy, possibly a bit more sour than intended? (slight infection??), moderately spicy / peppery, just a hint of dark malts and coffee. Okay, but not as great as I hoped. Won’t buy again.

Flaske: Sortbrun uklar øl med et kæmpe skumhoved. Let røget duft med en god del malt. Smagen er meget frisk, men stadig en fin blanding af belgisk øl med amerikansk nytænkning. Meget kraftig karbonering, gør øllen meget frisk.

Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark red-amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy and yeasty aroma. Lots of wonderfull fruity esters. Almost ABT quality. Moderate bitter nice powerfull flavor. Long moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Nice well balanced beer.

12 oz bottle.  Enjoyable but I have a difficult time with it being labeled as a Saison.  Dark pour but not pitch black.  One finger of off white head.  Not much retention.  Nose a earthy, yeasty barn yardy, and spicey.  Taste follows the nose.  I know it was made with peppercorns but their presence is really not that noticeable in the nose or taste.  Taste follows the nose.  Nice and light on the palate.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.

Clear dark red brown colour with a large, frothy - creamy, good to excellent lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, rye, moderate yeasty, fruity, spicy - peppry, sour malt - yeast notes. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, yeasty, spicy, peppery, chocolate, licorice notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110727]

33 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK via The Dram Shop. Cola-like deep brown appearance, lingering beige head. Sweet aroma of stewed raisins with some background resin. Velvety texture, thick and sweet, then a warming clove finish.

A bizarre beer, and somewhat of a disappoint considering the excellence of Goose Island’s other belgians. Pour jet black. Yeasty peppercorn indeed gives it a very smoky taste though a weak aroma. Tastes MUCH lighter than it looks though.

Served on draft at Madison’s in Madison, WI at the GTMW pre-party. Pours a dark brown color with a medium sized creamy tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of faint roasted malts, tart fruits and coffee. The taste is roasted malts, citrus, earthy notes and a bit of smoke, Slight tartness. Medium bodied.

Bottle bought at GBBF 2011. A darkbrown/ruby almost balck coloured pour with a decent beige head on top. Sweet, fruity Belgian aroma. Tastes sweet, fruity, yeasty, roasty, malty, spice. A reasonable Belgian clone.
Bottle. Very dark brown with medium tan head. Flavour is malt, chocolate, little coffee, roasted malts, smoke, yeast, hops and a little bitter and a little pepper.
Clear dark ruby with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, yeasty and smoky - bacon. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 110811
Bottle courtesy chrisv10. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are roast malt, smoke, caramel and hops.
Bottle at Chriso’s. Spicy nose, licorice, dark chocolate, dry. Medium sweetness, fruity, spicy, eith dry chocolate falvors. A nice Saison.

Bottle, bought @ Bishop’s Arms,Cph.

Pours opaque red-black with a lovely, frothy, staying, beige head. Aroma has soft nuttiness, roasted malts, sweet milky chocolate. High carbonation, light and quite dry mouthfeel. Flavour starts a bit anonymous, turns mild roasted, some nuts, chocolate, mildsmoke and peppery coriander. Not bad, just not that spectacular either.

My first black saison beer. Poured a very deep dark brown color with a light tan 2 finger head that lasted all the way down. The aroma was yeasty with spicy  berries or even a red spicy zinfandel aroma. Also some blood orange and rich reduced fruit juice smells. The taste again brings forth that Belgium spicy yeast along with coriander.  The finish taste is a touch of roast malt and chocolate. Palate is a very fine carbonation that cleans the mouth. Another stunner for Goose Island brewery.

Bomber.  Light black pour, large light tan head.  Roasted grain, rye, hay, slightly herbal, and light notes of sweet fruit and pepper.  I am not enjoying to much, I am not a big fan of these rye "saisons".

12oz 2011 bottle, pours black with a decent tan head and spotty lacing, the aroma has a nice amount of roastiness mixed in with the rye and malt, the flavor is most of the same with a sweetness in the finish, meh.

Pours black with a huge mocha head...decent retention.  Aroma is very faint...light roastiness, milky, notable rye.  Flavor is much different than the aroma...still has rye but much more like a saison with dry peppery and spicy notes and a pleasant tartness.  Mouthfeel is lively and a bit thicker than many saisons with a very dry lingering roasted spice finish.  Interesting and tasty!

Bottle from Stirchley Wines drank round The Jenners, 30/07/11. Deep ruby with a fine, unshrinking beige foam. Enticing Belgian yeast on the nose; blackcurrant skins, nectarine, cranberry and wine gums. Elegant beer softly oozing class; orange wine gums, gentle pepperiness, oak and vanilla, softly roasted afters. Beer of My Birthday.

12oz bottle. Deep dark brown with a tan head. Light sourness in the aroma, with some yeastiness and roast as well. Flavor is also slightly sour, some dark fruits, spice, and roast. Lighter body with tiny, bubbly carbonation.
Bottle.  Spicy apple malt aroma.  Brown color with moderate head.  Brown sugar malt and mild alcohol flavor.  Very nice and unique.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Faintly sour aroma, with wholemeal. Bready flavour, with some sweet cereal. I didn’t peg this as a Saison, it seemed more like Leffe Brune or similar. Wasn’t great when chilled, but definitely better when a little warmed.

Bottle.  A dark brown color with a thick tan head.  A roasty malt aroma with a light spice that increases in intensity as it warms.  Almost a light fruit flavor on the well balanced malty base.  An interesting and delightful saison.
Pours a lively dark brown with a dizzy head.  Yeast, yeast and more yeast.  The yeast kicks you in the balls.  Pretty good, though, even with all the yeast.
Bottle at Chris O’s pre GBBF shindig. Brown pour with a beige head. Licorice and caramel aroma. Very sweet flavour. Sweet spicy finish.

Bottle at ChrisO’s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2011. Pours rich brown with a foamy, tan head. Bit of Belgian yeast in the nose, some toffee. Lovely flavor, sweet with candi, bit of roast. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Faintly dry finish, some yeast, cake and bread. Really nice. (3.8)

Bottle at the Funky 8 - Barcade, Brooklyn, NYC. Plenty of dark malt character: cocoa, roasted malts. Very nice. (3.7)
Bottle from BoE, at chriso’s Pre-GBBF Shindig ’11. Dark brown. Faint, sweet aroma. Sweet, leathery, leafy taste. Sharp bitterness. Fair enough.

A Mes rate. At Chris O’s pre GBBF.
Probably not quite worthy of our 7k but there we go. Dark brown with a thin off White head. Fruity brown beer in a very Belgian style. Spritely yeasty notes and a good rounded malty finish. Nice enough.
Chris pre Gbbf shindig 2011.  Very dark brown colour.  Dark Belgian stylr beer.  Some esters.  Some decent esters and fruit salad.  Ok.
Pours almost black  with a nice lasting off white head, Aroma is earthy, fruity, roasted. Taste is dry and lingering. Some bitternes and fresh sour-ish finish. High drinkabillity!

Bottle @ Den smagsløse, Odense. Pours dark unclear amber with a creamy white head and lacings. Quite yeasty. Some tart barnyardy notes. Peppery and malty. Hoppy and smooth flavor with a find yeast character. Ends dry.

Pour is darker brown with a finger-wide light tan head that fades very quickly. Belgian yeast and peppercorn break through the aroma with a strong backing of roasted malts. Flavor is more on the smoked side with hints of chocolate, molasses, and burnt wood. Some Belgian spice in the finish. Interesting beer.

Bottle, 6%. Very slow gusher. Light fruity nose, slightly roasted. Very dark brown colour, seems clear. Quite stable light brown head. The flavour starts off slightly roasted, turns a little yeasty. Finishes with a sort of citric note.

I picked the right glass for this foamy pour - a widemouth Belgian goblet.  Slightly irritating aroma of yeast and lemon peel - but it tastes very good.  Fairly sweet and complex flavor - molasses, dates, apricot, a bit of citrus, and a lightly sharp finish.  The label says it is a Belgian ale, but here it is described as a rye saison.  Either way, it is good stuff.

Pours medium  brown with a lofty lingering head. Smells of coffee bean and mocha. Medium nectar with ample residual effers. A mild to moderate roast intertwined with cocoa and a bit of spice. The finish lingers and has a nice bittering component. The brew is a bit fizzy with insignificant features.

Bottle from Mybrewerytap.com. Pours black as Coke with a thin layer of bubbles. Aroma is yeast, roasted caramel. Taste is sweet malty,light roasted to start with, before it turns sourish, farmyard and dry hoppy at the bitter end
@Victors Fantasy Tasting-12oz bottle-pours a tan head and dark copper color.  Aroma is medium/dark malt-roasty, yeast.  Taste is medium/dark malt-roasty, yeast, secondary earthy hops.

Bottle from State Line.  Pours burnt sienna with 1-finger splotchy off-tan head.  Nose is nice; apple, cacao, spicy peppery, hops, a combo that shouldn’t work but does.  Tastes medium as far as complexity and palate heft, with dark malt, cacao, black pepper, spicy florals, slight funk, and hops.  Altogether works as well as any dark saison or dark hoppy beer of any style that I have yet quaffed.  Well done.
Pours deep brown-black in color with a tan head that settles quickly.  Roasty porter-like aroma.  Roasty with a belgian yeast note and hint of the pepper corns...interesting.
Bottle thanks to Victor at Paul’s. Pours dark brown. Off white head. Nose/taste of dark fruits, yeast, caramel and sweet malts and grapefruit rinds. Medium body.
Pours dark brown with a creamy beige head. Aroma is belgian saison yeast, dark dried berries, ripe plums, caramel and some fruity notes. Taste add some hops, grapefruit and light metallic..

Bottle. Deep brown, cola colored body. Pillowy beige head. Aroma is smokey with notes of char, tobacco, toasted grain. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet, moderately bitter and tart. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Taste of roast and char. Dry finish. I had this a twice, a couple of months apart. First round left me with the impression of a strange, overly smokey saison. Second time was an improvement. Seemed more balanced and more interesting.

Pepe nero @ pap 4/14/11

6.5/4/6/3/13
Dark brown small tannish head.

A is slightly smoky, bananas, spice, moist/damp, malt, a touch sour, red grape juice.

F shares the same with a weird sourness and too much malt sweetness. Straw notes and a dry herby at... A bit too sweet...odd
.
Crisp but a little sludgy sweet.

Pours dark brown with a very large belgium head.  Aroma of sweet molasses and spice.  Flavor is a bit boring.  Very drinkable but not a lot of flavor.  Not the best offering from Goose Island but by no means a bad beer.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours deep brown with a thick, beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, some roasted malts, and a hint of hops.  A little light on the palate, but a nice roasted flavor that’s rare for this style of beer.  A pretty interesting beer.

My first reaction was, "What the hell, I thought this was a saison." Pours dark brown with a dense creamy light brown head that seems to last forever while continuously building in my New Belgium globe glass. Aroma is hard to find in all that foam but I do get light spice, toasty malts, after it fades I get more tobacco and ripe dark fruits. The taste is excellent crisp and yet insanely rich and dense feeling in the mouth from the creamy carbonation. Very nice beer.
The aroma is chocolate, yeasty, peppery.  The appearance is deep brown, tan head, like a stout.  The flavor is chocolate, spicy.  Medium in body.   The finish is piney hops.  Quite good.
Bottle.  Clear brown pour with a white head.  Hops and fruit esters on the nose.  Bland hops, yeast, and ass flavors.

Bottle. Pours clear cola-black, thick pale tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is herbal, soapy, nice light roast and Belgian yeast notes; Flavours of tart berries, soft tar, very lovely "plug tobacco" flavours here as well. Soft, round, slightly soapy, always interesting: I enjoyed this.

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of joergen. Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is yeasty, roasted and slight peppery. Bitter, estery, phenolic and slight peppery. Dry peppery and yeasty finish.
Brownish in color, thin off white head, and clear. Fruits, plums, rye, yeast, and pepper in the smell. The taste is fruits, spice, pepper, more fruits, and yeast.
Deep brown in color with a small off-white head. Aroma is of rye, chocolate, light roastiness and yeast. Taste is of toast, yeast, dark fruit.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark brown colour, tan head. Nose is yeasty, fruity, bit of spices. Flavour is yeasty and fruity, spicy and candy sugar. Medium carbonation.

Bomber poured a clear dark reddish brown with a large lasting tan head. Aromas of burnt carmel, toffee, light fruittiness and light earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of burnt carmel, toffeelight coffee and a hint of earthiness with a smooth dry lingering toffee finish.

Bottle at home.
Dark brown coloured with a small beige head.
Fruity aroma of caramel and spices with notes of yeast and roasted notes.
Fruity flavour of caramel, spices, yeast and dark chocolate with roasted notes.
Fruity and spicy finish.

In short: A fun earthy, fruity and peppery dark ale with a light rustic twist.  Good beer

How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed relatively fresh, 4 months after first bottle rating.  Bottle from J2601, thanks a lot Jay

The look: Dark ruby-mahogany body topped by a medium beige head
 
In long: By the color I was expecting another Saison-by-name-only, but I was wrong.  Nose shows a strong rustic yeast character, fresh black cherries, liquorice, more...  Taste of burnt raisin pie, black pepper, root beer, liquorice, some barbecued red meat notes, earthy peat, some roast, rustic yeast.  All that ends on a rather dry notes leaving an earthy peppery astringent after-taste.  Clean non-belgian mouthfeel with the medium body and medium carbonation.  In mouth the rustic yeast is buried under all those strong flavors and the beer doesn’t really taste like a Saison and only the dryness of the finish reminds us that we are drinking a Saison-ish beer. This is yet another Saison rating for me.  But I’m starting to think that this ratebeer thing is a big waste of time.  Ratebeer has more users than ever and the people with no jobs in USA is an all-time high.  Coincidence?
Black of colour with a beige head. An aroma with roasted notes, spice and dark fruits. A flavour with dark fruits, roasted, spice and sweets. A very nice oily texture!
Bottle.Dark brown colour with medium head.Aroma is spicey and malty with slight hint of pepper and dark dry fruits,still with a smooth mouthfeels and dry finish.

Bottle pours very dark brown with brief beige head.  Nice spiced aroma with slight funk.  Complex taste of roast, malts, wood, spices, dark fruits and pepper.   Palate a bit thin with moderate carbonation.  Finish slight roast, yeast and pepper.  Alcohol not apparent.  



Lots going on but it doesn’t come together that well.

12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Black pour with a creamy eggshell colored head.  Roasted malt and spices in the aroma, Refreshing taste to it... a bit of citrus a bit more maltiness, slightly tangy finish.  Very good unique beer.

Bottle from Redmonds, Dublin.  Poured a deep dark brown colour with a fading tan head. Nose was caramel malt, spices and dark fruit. Flavour was rather sweet with some earthy malt and yeast notes, and lacked any real definition or balance. Underwhelming and a bit of a failed experiment this one.

Bottle from Westholme Stores, Goring-on-Thames, 16.06.11 Oxon consumed at Haro campsite outside Frank (camper), La Rioja, Spain 29.06.11 listening to Richard & Linda Thompson & eating Squid Marvellous   Pours dark brown with a light beige head, bit malty (don’t get the smokiness) with plenty of dark brown heavy sugars, a little bit of farmhouse character but to be honest I tend to get mostly dark sugars. Nice in the mouth but I think a bit too sweet for a saison, touch of earthiness maybe but to be honest could be ruined by the Crianza that I’m also getting stuck into. Nice beer.  A6 A4 T7 P4 Ov14  3.5

Pours a rusted copper with a medium sized beige head.  Aroma is oaky with a light pepper spiciness.  Taste is not overly sweet and lightly bitter.  Palate is smooth & creamy with medium to soft carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Clean dark copper with one finger of tan head. Lots of Belgian yeast in the nose, raw fruity character and kind of funky/off. Same in the favor, yeasty with some grainy notes. Dry palate and well carbonated.
A little bit of everything in this one.  Burnt wood, coffee, grass and funk.  A bit of sour cherries thrown in.  All over the map but decent.
Nice lively brown type ale.  Dark brown pour with a small head.    Aroma is roasted malt.  Taste is a little smoky.  The only pepper  I get is in the description.

12oz bottle shared by emacgee - thanks, Ethan! Pours like most black saisons, but there’s a really earthy dry taste, some mineral, some rye, only a hint of spice. Pepper and raw yeast in the nose. A bit underdeveloped overall, and therefore just okay, but would like to see what age does.
Bottle, shared by emacgee.  Yeasty, light pepper, light roast, dark fruits- prune and date in particular, a little spicy from the pepper.  Overall, pretty forgettable.
I just finished a Goose Island Bourbon County Vanilla, so this rating is probably screwed. Def a smooth beer and good hoppy flavor.
Bottle at Ølbaren. Almost black - offwhite head. Herbal. Roasted. Coffee notes. Peppery. Crispy. Sparkling feeling. Clean. Light hoppy.  Nice.
Pours pitch black with espresso head. Initial burst is piney hop aromas. Tast is spicy but also watery to an extent. Some slight cherry notes. Some caramel too.

12 oz bottle from a 4 pack. 2010 vintage.  Malty, fruity nose with caramel, dried fruit and dark rye bread. Tastes like Malt with light citrus, yeast, and light spice (pepper mostly). Medium bodied. Malt and caramel lingers in the finish. Has an almost smoke like element in it as well. This was a interesting brew. I drank 2 bottles with ease. I would drink again. I have no idea how the 2011 version fairs.

Dark and smooth malty flavors, too smooth,there should be some kind of spice note,that pepper really not coming through in the aroma or taste,but I do feel a minor pepper like tingle in throat, pleasant enough ,but non-distinctive

Big peppery nose with some kinda sweet saison notes. At first tasted like a regular saison but quickly dropped some soft chocolate and lighter roasted or singed flavor. Had all of the quirky spices you’d expect and a very nice yeast that sticks to your tongue, and plenty of hops. I liked it and it was very interesting to combine the flavors. Would pair well with food, by its self it is nice. When it warmed up the rye gave it a weird flavor, much better cold.

I was a bit dissapointed by this beer.  It wasnt bad but it wasnt really good either.  I love saisons and by the description this sounded amazing.  The flavors were light very very light and watery.  I didnt get much of the roasted/smoky malt character described in the description.  It just tasted to me like a below average saison that happened to be black in color.

tap and bottle-dark amber hue with a small tan head.  nose of chalk, belgian yeast twang and some dark spices.  very robust for being 6% i would have guessed at least 8.  a lot of belgian funky yeast on the finish but not really in the beginning of the palate.  some dark fruit becomes apparent as it warmed a bit.  some sour grains as well.  the saison notes come out more with a warmer temperature.    decent beer and glad i got to try it.
standard malt and yeast in aroma along with a hint of bubblegum.  peppery taste with berries, smoke and rye.  a bit of alcohol at the end. a very enjoyable beer.

On tap at the ACBF. Dark brown with a tan head that leaves a nice lace. Roasted coffee and an almost meaty smoke quality, licorice. Deeply roasted coffee on the palate with a nice funkiness. Finishes with bitter coffee. The body was a little light for the taste.

12oz bottle. Just checking things off my Chicago trip and Goose Island was up there. This wasn’t a tradition saison. Dark brown pour with a thin head. Peppery aroma with hints of spice. Easily drinkable and not tough on the  palate. Would try again.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (dark chocolate, roasted grain), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, apricot), with light notes of gum, clove.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Reasonably pleasant, but forgettable.  Not the best mouth experience.

22oz bottle.  Pours dark like a porter with a large tan head.  Not a lot on the nose...subtle cocoa, spices, yeast.  More chocolate on the tongue with roasted malts and a slight bitterness.  Dry finish.  Very unique beer.

(Bottle, Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm) Black colour with lasting, frothy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with caramel, dried fruit and dark rye bread. Malty, roasted taste with notes of dark rye bread, dried fruit, raisins, prunes, brown sugar and hints of black pepper. Hints of yeast shining through. Slightly more than medium body, sweetish, with some spicy bitterness. Quite a nice beer, but far from a saison in my book.

pours  black with one finger khaki head. roasty, funky smell. really striking fine carbonation. very well constructed beer. slight pepper. roasty barnyard flavor. essentially a black saison. unique, smart, and very nice beer.

2011. Pours deceivingly - darker black brown, yet somehow has a transparent appearance. Small, light head that quickly disappears. Really not a bit of lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, spicy with cardamom and clove and a touch smoky. Thankfully for me, the smokiness is not like burnt bacon and campfire...just a light, toasty smoke. Flavors are sweet raisin, caramel malt, I do taste faint peppercorn. Light and crisp on the palate, nice carbonation that cleanses the palate. A very interesting saison.

Dark brown pour, clear at the edges but hard to tell if there’s any haziness to it, tan head, good retention, not much lacing in a beer-clean glass. Aroma is baked dark fruits, slight smoke, slight spice, clove. Starts off sweet and slowly fades to a moderately dry finish. Tingly carbonation. Kinda one dimensional on the palate - not much going on there. Nothing special, overpriced a bit.

Pours almost black with a bit of beige head. The aroma has some ashy, smoke notes followed by a yeasty banana and clove character. The aroma has a peppery spice to it that complements the yeast taste well. Earthy with a dry finish. Interesting beer, not at all what I was expecting.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small white head. The aroma is sweet chocolate, dusty and fruity. The flavor is a lot like a Dubbel; very fruity, dry, caramel and chocolate, smooth. How is this a Saison? Am I missing something. Certainly peppery and yeasty, some phenolic, bananas. Still quite nice.

Bottle… Pours dark brown with a small, creamy, khaki head. Good retention. The aromatics provide deeply roasted malts, caramel malt and a clove-like phenol. Full-bodied with a buttery mouthfeel and timid carbonation. The flavor is well-balanced and quite roasty, but there is not much else going on. Finishes lightly minerally and fairly bland. Is that Dupont’s saison yeast, I detect? Maybe not. Bottle courtesy of darkguardian!

Excited to see these on the shelves.  Dark mahogany that nears ebony with a 1/2 inch latte head.  Lots of ash, char, and smoke accompanying dark fruit like raisin, plum, and grape.  Spicy...including cracked pepper.  Little bit of yeast and even a bit of banana sweetness with the lemongrass, citrus rind, and pith.  Earthy.  Overall good.

12oz, 2011 vintage received as an extra in a recent trade with lurchingbeast. Thanks again Frank!

Pours a very dark chestnut brown color that appears near black in the glass and completely opaque with a one finger frothy yellowish beige head. Very good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that streaks the glass with rings and splotches of soapy lacing.

Slightly earthy vinous aroma with an interesting combination of roasted malt, dark fruit and zesty spice. A touch funky with a slight vegetal character as well as hints of grape, raisin and plum. Maybe some candy sugar along with some zesty pepper. A bit of chocolate and chili in the nose.

Medium bodied and a bit creamier/fuller than expected with some tight carbonation up front that fades toward the end of the swallow. The spicy/peppery presence from the aroma is very powerful and dominates the flavor, lingering throughout into a spicy dry finish. In addition to black pepper I’m picking up some chilies that give the beer some heat in the finish. It’s also slightly earthy and funky but not as much as the aroma suggests. A good balance of roasted malt, dark fruit and spice. Hints of roasted chocolate, toast, grape, fig, raisin and plum. Slightly sweet and vinous but the dark malt notes and spicy peppers even things out. It could be to heavy on the spice for some but I enjoyed it.

12oz Bottle. I don’t know why, but I’m often skeptical and dubious about dark Saisons. I do appreciate some more complex malt depth to examples of the style, but  there’s a darkness threshold, in my humble opinion. This one noses in the fruitier raisin and Dubbel-like tones. Flavors same too, except heavier banana and clove esters and phenols. Solid dryness, slight toasted complexity. A good spring sipper, I think, but departs from the base style a bit too much for my tastes, without a farmhouse-like rustic quality.
Bottle from Kris Wines. Amber beer with a big beige head. Yeasty and fruity aroma, banana notes. Malty yeasty flavor with some sweet fruits.

Bottle [650ml] shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry. Pours a dark brown with ruby-red hues and a large lasting frothy tan head. Aroma is yeasty along with lightly roasted dark malt, some light spices, coffee and a hint of herbs. Flavour is malty and yeasty along with light spices, mainly pepper, and some citrus fruit. Medium bodied. It’s not a Saison for me at all but regardless, I quite like it.

Bottle, shared with Parksy. Dark brown with mahogany highlights and a creamy tan head. Musty dark fruit, lightly smoky, lightly yeasty.  Lighter mouthfeel with fairly high carbonation. Leans toward a Baltic porter style, but the lighter body, the carbonation, and the yeast steer it away. Interesting.

Pours black with a rich white head. Aroma is mild slightly sour with a mild roasted malt aroma. Very nice great body. Very porter like flavour with a nice slightly sour funky flavour. This is a very nice brew. Very nice.

22. Pours an opaque dark brown with a dense and creamy burnt tan head. Looks very stouty. Big tangy bread dough nose, bits of aluminum and molasses along with caramel. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Cola, molasses, brown bread, and a bit of aluminum on the mid palate. Mild tangy sweet finish. Not bad. A bit cloying and metallic.
draft. pours brown with off white head. aroma is yeasty, pepper. flavors of pepper, yeasty, and brown sugar finish. thin body. i still haven’t gotten into the dark saisons.

bottle from trade with ughsmash. bottled 01/03/11. Real good aroma, sweet & spice. fig, date. clove, pepper. little red berry. Dark orangy brown color, good head and lace. Bitter sweet flavor. Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, sweet dry finish. Very nice. good range in aroma. easy to drink, went down fast. thanks ughsmash
This is a pretty good beer. Nice appearance. It’s a bit spicy, but mostly this is pretty indistinct. On par then for a saison, but I thought this could’ve been a bit more unique and interesting.

Attractive pour...dark murky brown with brown head.  Aroma is spicy caramel malt.  Nice taste...big belgian malt; notes of caramel, spice, dark fruit, clove and black pepper.  Oily & creamy texture but dry aftertaste.  Mellow yet full flavor.  Very good.
Like a porter crossed with a smokey thin stout.  Pours rootbeer brown with a thin head.  Subtle notes of coffee and spice.  Malty smell and lingering aftertaste of malt and barley.
Smell is rather spicy, the appearance is dark brown/amber and cloudy.  The taste is rather unique, dark malt mixed with Belgian yeast mixed with rather spicy hops.  Very good ale overall.

Pours a dark brownish black with 4 fingers of sticky light brown head. Aroma is roast, chocolate, yeasts, spicy hops candi sugar, esthers. Flavor is spicy grassy floral hops, roast, chocolate. Interesting take on a Saison, but ultimately i’d rather just have a regular saison than a black one.

Bottle. Dark brown beer with a tan head. Yeast and light citrus aroma with light spice. Malt and caramel flavor with light citrus, yeast, and light spice. Medium bodied. Malt and caramel lingers with spice and yeast.
Pretty tasty stuff, pour was from a growler and it was quite herbal, the colour is dark as night, Tastes right a long the lines of what you would expect from a belgian beer. Pretty tasty stuff

Mahogany black. Gentle pour raises a two-finger grayish head which eventually disperses. Unsweetened chocolate, green banana, rum-soaked plums, clove, and bubblegum comprise the nose. Mild notes of smoke, banana taffy and cola. Firm carbonation expands as it hits the tongue. Initially soft with a floral Saaz punch and prominent bubblegum. Quickly relinquishes its brightness to the yeast which contributes unpleasant notes of damp cellar and concrete. A smidgeon of cola and medicine exudes strongly enough to exacerbate the subtle presence of alcohol. Flash of peppery spice remains potent enough to withstand the sturdy base of roasted-nut-tinged malt, yet behaves with admirable grace. Downhill from there as the malt takes on a peculiar slickness reminiscent of chamomile and Red Delicious apples. Black malt produces a smoke and burnt cookie effect, counterbalancing some of the slickness.  Closes with a a semi-dry flourish capped with floral and grassy hops, plum, and red licorice. Despite this not being quite as wet, sweet, and banana-laden as many American-brewed Saisons tend to be, this still comes off as a fairly generic rendition. Has that slippery texture and wet pavement thing going on which happens to plague many of the Goose Island Belgians.  Not very clean.

(Bottle, 2011 vintage, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a deep amber body with a small beige head.  Aroma of caramel, citrus, pepper, and pineapple.  Flavor of stewed tomatoes, citrus, light pepper, nuts, and yeast.
Bottle at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the share. Dark malts with some floral and lighter notes up front. Very yeasty. Would like to try again since my sample was tiny.
bottle at jens ... dark brown ... thin tan lacing ... yeasty spicy lemon ... and roast toffee malt nose ... bubbly gum bananana ... toffee malt ...   hint of chocollate

Tasted 4/29/11. 12oz bottle. Bottled on 01/03/11 2147. Sedimented yet somewhat filtered with a deep reddish brown hue. Finger width of dense bone white head. Aromas of caramel and burnt sugar. Spicy and peppery with a candy, floral yeast character. Subtle cocoa undertone with a bit of grassy hops. Medium to full bodied with a great complexity and a barrage of flavors. Wow! Sticky body with hints of tea and dark fruits. Good citrus  and floral character. Dry bitter peppery spices that mix nicely with both the yeast and the hops. The malts are surprisingly toasty with a good cocoa undertone. Faint cola sweetness with a grape soda nuance. This hits all the aspects of the palate and still leaves a cloying finish. Goose Island has always done a superb job on its Belgian styles and this is no exception! Well done!

Pours a deep dark brown that I wasn’t expecting with a nice head that shortly dissipates. Faint aroma of cocoa and caramel. Malty sweetness gives way to bitter/sour... more cocoa and cola. Cleans up quick with lingering cocoa and tobacco ash. It’s an okay beer that I won’t be trying again.
Nice pour with a tan head. Good aroma you can almost smell the pepper and some nice funkiness. Beatiful lacing the bubbles seemed to shine, nice dark color.

12oz bottle 4/27/11 (Binny’s Downers Grove)-40° in Snifter-Pours a deep brown with a big tan head. Aroma of yeast, banana, pepper, and spices. Taste of the same with smoke added in. This full bodied brew is well balanced and is different but definitely worth a try.

Pours deep brown into a snifter. Mocha head with medium retention recedes to skim rim. Honey, nutmeg and smoky pepper aromas. Sweet honey and spiced nutmeg from front to back.  Lasting smoked resin pepper finish.

Bottled 03-11.  The beer pours a muddy, dark brown color with an average, foamy, dark beige head which is mostly lasting leaving a thin foam throughout and similar lace.  The nose is seemingly simple for a saison but quite enticing with peppery notes from the rye and phenols, smoky and roasty notes you might expect from grilled meat but without the meaty notes (like you would get from a smoked beer), some dark breads, and maybe a raisin-like tartness; come to think of it, I do not get much saisonish notes.  The flavor is similar with lots of smoky grill notes (think of how a prime rib might smell if slow roasted on a charcoal grill...), dark breads, still black pepper all over, a slight raisin note with a moderate acidity, and maybe a bit of toasted caramel in there somewhere.  The palate is seemingly bigger than most lighter, more typical ’saisons’  but still fitting to this beer; medium to full, lively, and both quenching and dry.  The beer finishes dry with the smoky/roasty notes diminishing slightly allowing the pepper to balance and the quenching acidity to present itself.  Not your everyday saison...  I usually find that dark saisons dry out to much and taste ashy or chalky but these one was neither.  And the way the smoky notes were used was quite interesting to me; tasting like notes you would expect from grilled meat but not meaty tasting, if that makes any sense.  I have not been a fan of Goose Island’s Belgian beers but this one was a pleasant surprise, especially if you are looking for something out of the ordinary.

22oz bottle split with McBerko. Pours a jet black tan head. Burnt tar aroma. Taste is burnt malt, rye, dried leaves, certainly a peppery note near the end. Alcohol seems hot for 6.0%. While black IPA’s seem to work in general a black saison doesn’t (unless there are better examples of one).

Really dark much more so than I expected. Some good lacing after the head finally disappated. Taste is banana, esters, some candy, and malts. I like this and it seems very different from a normal saison.

January 3rd, 2011 (Pre-AB) 12oz bottle. This was an interesting beer. Poured a dark brown color, with a light tan head. Aroma was, well like a Belgian ale, touch of pepper and roasted notes. Flavor was a tad pepper, saison-like qualities. Would be an interesting beer after a few years.

650 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours an nearly opaque dark brown-black color with a small beige head that slowly recedes to a fine film. The aroma is moderate in strength with Belgian yeasts and dark roasted malts. The flavor is complex with roasted grains, mixed fruits, cocoa and mild spices. The palate is silky smooth and the carbonation is lively. Finishes medium in duration and dry. Overall: I thought that this was a fair black saison.

22 oz. bottle, split with manuchampions, pours dark brown / black with a small beige head. Aroma of rye, peppercorn and dark malts. Flavour of iodine, ash / burnt notes, rye and pepper. No idea how this is a saison. Not too stimulating.

Black in color with an off white head. Outstanding lacing. The aroma consist of vanilla, caramel and grains. Watery on the palate. Has lively carbonation. There is a spicey finish to the beer. I was hoping for more of a peppercorn spice to it. It was a good beer though.

22 oz. bottle- Pours almost black (weird for a saison) with a nice creamy tan head, again is this a saison. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee (again is this a saison?), there maybe some funky aromas in there, but it could be in my imagination. The flavor is more Belgian, yeast, banana esters, pepper, roasted malts, coffee. The description says roasted black saison, and I guess it matches that description, nice beer. Budweiser sucks!

Reviewed from notes. Pour yields a nearly-black beer with a mocha-colored head and some nice retention. The nose has a bit of earth and pepper along with some Belgian yeast spiciness. The peppercorn really stands out in the nose, and that carries over into the flavor. A bit of roasted malt in the flavor along with some earthy woodiness. Mouthfeel is medium with a bit of spice and good carbonation. Drinks fairly well.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-15-2011
Pours porter-like, red highlights.  Head runs away.  Ester/banana nose.  Relatively flat, lots of malt.  Careful hopping but interesting finish.  Very nice
Bottle pours dark brown with ruby highlights. Aroma is fruity sweet and  roasty malt. Flavor is light roast malt, light banana, earthy, Belgian spice, and a bit of sourness.

Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm.  Black, minimal head. Careful roasty nose with some black pepper. Dryish with clean mouthfeel. Rather tinny with markes coffee-like roastiness. The clean, hard malt is surrounded by sloppy syrup. To hard malt character for any flavours to come out, making it feel unpleasantly metallic - like licking a lamp post. Fades out with low bitterness. Rock hard malt in a saison = FAIL.

22oz bottle shared with blankboy and garthicus.  Deep cola red pour, huge fluffy lasting tan head.  Aroma - saison?  dunno, but it’s roasty, green grassy hoppy, a bit pungent.  Taste - sharp, spicy, deep roast, moderate alcohol - pretty yummy.  Solid body, average carbonation, decent spiciness ... can’t express it, but pretty solid, if not "on style" for saison.

Thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: Cola black, medium brown head. Aroma: ’Farmhouse’ , malt, Harry may have mentioned it but it "smells like Quebec" spicy too ! Flavour: malty, quite spicy, tangy, yeast with a long peppercorn flavor.

"Had this a couple times now, first time was at Goose Island in Chicago, but now it’s on tap at the Malt House. Pours a dark cloudy brown with a decent sized tan head. Aroma is nice and roasted, some light cinnamon and pepper on the nose. Taste is full and creamy, well intgerated spices, slight yeastiness. Very easy to drink brew."

The beer pours black with dark brown edges.  The head is tan and puffs up nicely, before dissipating to nearly nothing.

The aroma is cola, chocolate, roasted malt, pepper and bananas.  There’s very little saison yeastiness.  It’s a nice beer but not particularly compelling.  It smells a bit like a bland saison mixed with a stout.

The taste is relatively sweet.  There’s more pepper and cocoa.  The cola flavor creeps up a bit much in the finish.

Mouthfeel is pretty middle of the road.  It’s a bit effervescent but tends to sit rather heavily on the palate for a saison.

22 oz bottle, pours pitch black with a tan head....very stout looking.  I found this one to be a bit lacking, something I rarely find with Goose Island beers.  The appearance and mouthfeel were great, but the flavor was kinda thin, save for a bit of chocolatey finish.  Reminded me a lot of Ithaca’s Cold Front, although I think that one’s better.

Bottle, mybrewerytap.com. Pours reasonably thick, with a deep ruby hue. Aroma is fairly low, but the flavour is smoky, woody, rubbery, yeasty, slightly astringent, verging on sour, but it then softens out and has a nice smooth finish. Blackcurrant aftertaste, good carbonation.

16oz draught, $6 at Mission Delores. Take that, RnH! Deep, deep Ruby with a one finger mocha head, coating with pretty decent retention. Spicy banana yeast in the nose, folowed by some earth and roast.  Flavor has a the typical saison yeast pushing against some roast, slight vanilla, and and earthy peppery spice--not necessarily getting any peppercorns. I do agree, it is slightly smoky in the semi-dry finish, earthy bitterness peaking at a 3.  Medium body with creamy light to moderate carbonation.  Not overwhelming,  but I feel this is par, as darkening traditional styles (IPA, saison) don’t really work for me.
Black with a creamy white head. Coffee and Belgian yeast aroma and taste with nice roasted grain notes and toffee.

rounded chewy and syrupy body with a watery thin mid-palate presence and finish. medium-high acid throughout with copper/wet penny metallic astringency. unpleasant notes of char and heated rubber thrive on top of spicy overblown phenols.  even with the moderately high acid the beer has a surprisingly flabby body. in fact everything about this beer, from the astringent malt to the solvent-like phenols to the burnt rubber notes, comes across as lazily concocted and executed.

355ml bottle. Pours a dark brown with just a little head. On the nose, there is a hint molasses or maybe treacle scones. On the taste, there is rye bread or barrabrith. The palate is at least medium in structure and has a nice medium texture and the finish drops away gently.

Did not care for this one.  First of all, where did Saison or farmhouse ale come from re this beer.  I don’t always judge a beer by comparing it to the style.  Its not even in the ballpark.  Very dark brown.  Burnt and roasty nose with a slight sour dark fruit.  Surprisingly thin palate.  Flavors very subdued, burnt malts, earthy.  Astringent mild sour and dry finish.  Didn’t work for me.

pitch black with large tan head.  nose of some dark malt with belgian esters and tropical fruit intermixed.  carbonation is medium for style.  some bitterness before lemon and more tropical yeast notes prior to a smokey and likely special b malt lingering flavor.  a dry finish with a long taste.  i am somewhat surprised to see it’s a black saison, as i thought it was a dark strong ale, but it makes sense and its a wonderful beer

Thanks to Pawola22 for sharing this bottle. Always happy to try a new beer from Goose Island. 

The beer pours a dark brown color with red highlights and an off-white head. 

The aroma is caramel and Belgian yeast, with some spiced notes and a little bit of chocolate. 

The flavor is similar. I get some chocolate notes, as well as quite a bit of dark fruit, Belgian yeast, pepper and some light Belgian candy sugar. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Pours a murky brown with a creamy tan head.  Roasted malts with fresh bread, sweet apples, a nice barnyard aroma, toasted biscuits, and a slight smokiness all in the nose.  Wonderful aroma!  The smokiness is evident in the taste, but mostly the fresh bread really kicks in.  Nice cereal grains, sweet and slightly acidic fruity esters, and the best part...the barnyard/funk taste.  Excellent saison!!

Bottle.  This pours black with a nice welcoming off white head.  Good head retention along with a healthy carbonation level.  The aroma is much more fruity than spicy, welcoming the drinker with mild banana & some ripe red apple.  This aroma, however, is deceptive and is a virtual paradox as the flavor is quite different from the aroma.  Interesting blend of ripe fruits and an almost smokey flavor.  The blend of flavor had me perplexed at first, but then I started to find it quite welcoming.  It is almost like a banana split.  Chocolate and ripe banana with a nice depth.  As far as saisons go, I think this is only like a Saison when the yeast comes to the forefront.  Other than that, just a very nice departure from the norm.  But isn’t that what Saison is all about anyway.
Once again, Goose Island goes deep. I will enjoy this for the rest of the night.  Delicious, delicious beer.
Bottle from Half Time. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Slightly sour malt aroma. Med. body. Hint of banana, some spice. Peppery spice. Gently earthy.

Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours ruby with an attractive beige head and a candi sugar aroma. There is a peppery malt flavor with some banana ester and a bitter slightly acidic finish.. A nice barnyard flavor.

Cloudy brown, big off-white head. Coffee and nutty aroma, plus some black pepper. Light and crisp palate. Flavor is nutty and peppery, with some lightly sweet notes. Some cherry, fruity notes as it warms. Pretty tasty, actually.

[355ml bottle, Appellation Wines, Edinburgh] Pours like a glass of Coca Cola, albeit without the carbonation. Pretty much totally flat. Aromas of Belgian yeast and clovey spice - not much pepper evident on the nose. Some rye notes on the palate. There’s a herbal spiciness rather than a pepper kick, but it may not have been added in large amounts. To be honest I was expecting interesting stuff from this given the ingredients and the pour - but it’s an average Belgian beer. Still above average of course, compared with other beers [11042011]
on tap at the Saucer(LittleRock) pours black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is roast with rye and thin maple notes.  Flavor is roasty, dry, pine, wheat, fruity yeast and a spiced finish.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours brown that allows no light to pass through with a thin-moderate tan head that lasted through the first two sips and left very little lace.  Pleasant fruity aroma with some spice notes in the nose as well.  The flavor is malty and fruity along with some mild spice.  Mild bitterness at the finish.  Medium bodied.  Enjoyable.
Dark pour. Aroma of malt and pepper. Medium bodied with just the right amount of carbonation. Pepper very prevalent on the taste but a little to much for my liking, but a fine beer otherwise.

Bottle.  Black with red tints and a beige foam.  Aromas are bready yeast and liquorice with coffee and burnt toast.  Leather with oil and dark Winter berries.  Flavours are blackberries with coffee, dark chocolate and herbal notes.  Dark cherries with spritzy yeast.  Likeable.

5 April 2011, bottle. Black rye saison certainly seems to give it an odd colour. ruby brown colour, clear, steady bubbles w/ slight lacing. nose is not a barnyard saison either. wet bread yeastiness w/ soft, dark fruity yeastiness. med body and fairly fizzy. nice taste! rich cherry cola, soft chocolate, MAYBE some pepperiness. actually, there is something spicy about it. I think this is a great beer. i have serious problems labeling it a saison, regardless of the "black rye" delimiter. this is more a black rye strong belgian ale than a saison of any kind. but it’s a nice one!

12oz bottle from Archers. Pours brown with a medium, tan head. Aroma is fruity with hints of yeast and spices. Flavor is sweet and fruity with sugary, peppery, and malty notes and some nuts, rye, yeast, and caramel as well. Light bodied and medium carbonation.  Easy drinking this brew.

Bottle thanks to CanIHave4Beers.  Pours dark brown, nearly black, with a thinnish beige head.  Light showing through the edges.  Nose shows the spice of the rye, roasted malts, interesting Belgian yeast, and chocolate.  Similar taste.  A bit thin.  Interesting, but not blowing me away.

draft - Pours near black with a lasting light tan one finger head.  The aroma is of roast malt, chocolate, and spicy yeast.  The flavor is of roast malt, chocolate, yeast and spice.  It’s medium bodied and lively on the palate.  Interesting.
Pours deep black with a tan fading head.really malty in taste. The smell is sort of wet doggish.refreshing and mild in flavor and body.

2011 vintage.  Bottled 01/03/11 and reviewed 04/04/11.  Poured in a port glass.

Pours a dark, clear mahogany with a thin, light tan head.  Rye malt aroma.  Slightly smoky.  Taste is of spicy rye.  Piny hops in the finish.  Medium/full body with a long, slightly sweet finish.  The bottle says it will get better with age to 5 years.  I’ll have to remember to hold a couple back... if I can.

Bottle picked up at StateLine. Shared by Robert the Bruce of SL.... This bottle was consumed at home. Poured aggresively into a snifter. Good creamy colored head. Nose of slight smoke, malt and some peat moss. Taste is nice little smokiness with a touch of sweetness. Rye and some pepper as well. Dry...Unique. Medium body, creamy... Overall... A unique saison from AB (hahahhah) just kidding stuff from GI.
bottle, thanks to pawola22 in trade, dark black brown pour with tan foam, aroma is chocolatey, dark fruit with a cashew, caramel, belgian fruit flavor

On tap:  The aroma consists of chocolate, roasted coffee, banana, and faint apple.  It’s a dark brown with a minimal off-white head that fades to nothing.  The flavor starts with chocolate and light roastiness.  There’s a hint of banana in the background.  The finish has light apple and roast.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation.
Dark ruby pour with medium tan head. Aroma smells like prunes, figs, plums. Flavor is smoky, peanut butter, almonds, bananas.

Mmm BMC.  Seeing "Goose Island (A-B InBev)" as the brewer brings a tear to my eye.  Well not really - I’m not a crybaby, I’m a ticking champ - but it’s a shame.  This beer pours dark brown, or maybe light black, but either way it’s a lot darker than many of this brewery’s other beers (Bud Light, Bud Select 55, Budweiser Chelada, etc).  Small tan head on top.  Pepper and roast on the aroma, along with a very subtle level of saison funkt.  The flavor is peppery roasty with toasted nuts and milk chocolate, as well as a slight saison aspect.  Medium-bodied, maybe just a tad on the thin side, with average carbonation.  A pretty solid beer overall, and great for BMC.
3/18/11. Black pour with a tan film and ring. Roasted malt aroma with a hint of sour Belgian funk. Light funky flavor with a hint of sour and big lingering roast. A bit odd.

A: The pour is dark brown in color with reddish hints to it and a fairly large off-white head.

S: Not the most fragrant beer, but the aromas are mostly imparted by the yeast. Banana and hints of clove with a definite peppery quality. Touches of roasted malt and sweet wheat bread in the background.

T: A fairly similar story on the palate. This beer is decently dry with tons of banana notes to go along with some of the other spices, and it’s quite peppery as well. Somewhat roasty, but more earthy than anything.

M: Medium in body with a moderate carbonation.

O: I wouldn’t have pegged this as a saison type of beer just from drinking it. It’s not bad, but fairly uninspiring.
The smell of this beer reminds me of GABF.  Dark fruits, toasted walnut shells, and maybe some kale. It’s a weird one, but I like it. Nice mouthfeel.  For a dark colored beer, it’s pretty refreshing.

Starts with a bit of a tart aroma, that changes to a roasted aroma quickly.  Pours an opaque black, with a huge light tan head.  Mild rye taste, with hints of smoke and roast.  Slightly slick mouthfeel, with good level of carbonation.  Very light on the palate, and very drinkable.  I’ll be grabbing a couple of bottles of this to cellar and see what happens.

A - Pours a fairly deep black color with a touch of brown around the edges with a finger-plus of off-white head slightly off-white head. The head has pretty good retention and laces nicely.

S - Aroma is a blend of some toffee malts and some light sweet fruit (pears). A bit of yeast also in the background.

T - Starts off with deep caramel malts and some peppery spices. Also a touch of light fruits and a bit of darker fruit flavor (plum). Through the middle some more sweet fruit flavors come through alongside some smoked tastes. Bit of yeast also. The finish is a mix of yeast, some smoky flavor, and some peppery spices that lingers a bit.

M - Medium bodied with moderate-low amount of carbonation. A touch watery, but otherwise feels fairly smooth and a touch smoky and spicy. Fairly dry finish.

D - Fairly drinkable. Taste is a bit different than most saisons with the smoky flavors. Otherwise, interesting and different and fairly tasty. Pretty decent balance.

Dark mahogany with good, foamy, tan head / Creamy, smooth,  nose of roast barley, banana / Medium body, creamy and grassy, moderate acidity, with good balance and finish / Elegant, subdued, flavors of cocoa, plum, smoke, tobacco, and banana, with spicy rye finish / A smooth, easy drinker, with a tasty, mellow, flavor profile.

Bottle from MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours murky cola color with a small off-white head that doesn’t last too long. Smells of rye, tropical fruit, light floral hopping, and just a touch of the peppery yeast from the description. Taste is light spice, rye, and a touch of floral hoppiness. Crisp and fresh, with a bit of sweetness, and a finish that has a clove spiciness throughout. Well-carbonated and smooth, I like this one.

The beer is black with a light tan head, ok retention, really good lacing.

The aroma is pretty light, only gives off a little floral hops that’d you expect in a saison. The finish has a tiny bit of chocolate. 

The taste is a complete reverse of the aroma, tons of sweet chocolate throughtout, you’d never guess this was a saison, more a light chocolate stout. Its really smooth and easy to drink.

This beer is really good to drink, just don’t call it a saison or drink it expecting to get that.

Sampler at the W&C in Ballwin, Mo. It poured a brownish color with a nice head. The aroma was a bit chocolatey and nice fruitiness with some peppery notes that had light earthy presence. The flavor was very bready like a nice loaf of bread with some peppery flavoring. Very good overall.

Pours dark brown with a thin, creamy, long lasting beige head. Aroma is roast, dusty grain, floral and fruity notes, pepper, nice rye, sweet bread spice, a touch of smoke and hints of soured grain. Flavor is pepper, dried stone fruit, a little smoke, earthy root vegetables, more grainy almost fresh tasting rye than the aroma lets on, a touch of chocolate sweetness, yeasty bread and a little dried orange peel and pepper for the finish. Palate is light to medium bodied (a little more viscous than I expected), mostly dry, but slightly creamy on entry gradually drying to the finish to have a fairly crisp, slightly chalky finish. Good stuff, interesting take on the style.

22oz. Bottle (Bottled:1/7/11. #: 1143.):  Aroma of malt, spice, light pepper, light birch beer, slight rye, slight Marsala wine, and light yeast.  Poured dark brown/mahogany in color with a large, creamy, brown head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Good lacing.  Complex flavor of malt, pepper, yeast, slight to light rye, light roasting, and a hint of chocolate.  Also had a kind of general Saison flavor to it.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, light pepper, light rye, finish is lightly dry.

Pours a cola color, black in the glass, with a small light tan head. The aroma is mostly Belgian yeast with banana and clove, but also has some black pepper, bunt rye toast, and a dash of funky citrus. The flavor has a lot less potency than the aroma. There is not much going on, seems very muted compared to the aroma. Sweetness becomes toasty bitterness, with a touch of soap on the finish. Light on the palate, with a small amount of frothy carbonation. All in all I’m not really impressed with this one.
Pours a cola covered body with a lasting ring of tan head.  Aromas of banana and roasted malt.  Flavors are the same with a caramel note.  Some spice and vegetal notes on the finish.

Poured from a 12oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with a finger of beige head, lots of lacing on the glass.   Aroma is heavy with Belgian yeast and some spiciness.  The taste is a bit odd.  There is lots of abbey taste in there, but some strange spiciness that I can only describe as funky rye.

Bottle. Poured a clear dark brown color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted malt, spice, and yeast aroma. Medium body with a dry smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy spicy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. I enjoyed this beer.

Tap @ Crescent Moon in Omaha. Dark orange/brown appeaance with a light tan head. Sweet rye, Belgian ale aroma with a slight burnt character. Peppery, barnyard, wild yeasty, Belgian flavor. The rye and burnt characterisitics really add some interesting flavors. Dark saison finish.

[3645-20110314] 650mL bottle. Odd fruity hint in the aroma. Black body with a quick bubbly tan head. Fruitiness continues in the flavour with a light roasted malt. Medium body. Average. (5/3/5+/3/10) 2.6

Overheard: "I got some sheep if you have some wood."

(c/o DuctTape, w/ him, jerc)



[6102C-20130214] Tap. Mildly roasted wood aroma. Brown black body with a quick foamy tan head. Roasted egg wood flavour has a mild grape and cigarette butt finish. Medium body. Interesting, apparently this makes for a good marinade. (7/3/7/3/13) 3.3

(@ Abraxas, Miami, FL)

12 oz goblet draft at Waldo Pizza in Kansas City, Missouri. Pour is a dark brown black, hazy opaque with a pretty light tan head. Aroma is grain, rye, black pepper, and some aged leather. Taste is quite spiced, more than I was expecting from the nose. It’s clovey rye grain, decent amoun of roast, earth dirtiness, and lightly sweet in the finish.  Palate is medium bodied, higher levels of carbonation made this easy drinking. Weird but interesting and well executed. As it warmed, really picked up nice integration in the flavors.

12oz., bottled on 1/3/11.  Sweet aroma of banana, brown sugar, light spice, dark, faintly roasty malt, black bread and perhaps a hint of the pepper.  Deep, dark brown in color, showing mahogany highlights when held to the light, head is pale white and very fine.  Flavor profile is gently bitter and spicy up front, becoming sweeter and more peppery about midpoint, and finishing with a blend of fruity yeast esters and peppery spice, along with hints of roast and cocoa.  Mouthfeel is generously effervescent, a tad sharp and dry, body is medium.  Would perhaps be interesting to try after a while in the cellar, but certainly doesn’t seem to require aging at all since it’s pretty tasty as is.

Black pour with a tan head. Aroma is full of peppercorn, rye, dough, and a bit of roasted malt. Flavor holds more spice and dough, a touch of citrus, and maybe the lightest touch of mesquite. Interesting, and pretty damn tasty.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark brown color with a medium sized beige head.  The aroma is a nice combination of mild cocoa, lively peppery spice, herbal with hints of fruit.  The flavor has some roast, peppery spice, herbal, with citrus at the back.  This is a little all over the place.  Not bad, just confused.  Medium body, dry, and decent.
22oz bottle, courtesy of Drowland. Sweet, caramel aroma, not really much of the doughy, earthiness that I expect out of a saison.

330ml bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a small head.  Aroma is peppery yeast and some banana.  Some pepper to start.  Cloves and banana in the finish.  Peppery aftertaste.  Very full and thick in the mouth.

2011-03-14. Black body with a  modest tan head. 3+ Yeasty aroma with mild roast malt character, and hint of not quite bubble gum like character. Flavour is stout like up front, dry roasty bitter malt, mild yeasty accents throughout. Almost a dunkelweizen like under current. Dry roast pipes up again in the aftertaste. Light alcohol as it warms up. 7+ Average plus bodied palate. Interesting, I enjoyed it but found it a bit unusual. Not sure I would return to it. Bottle shared by DuctTape

Bottle shared by dcshiller at RBWG 2011, thanks 

Appearance: Dark brown with a nice beige head and good lacing 

Aroma: Dark fruits, toasted malts and spices 

Taste: Sweet ripe fruits, caramel and spices 

Ok
Draft at Churchkey.  Dark brown, huge brown head, great lacing.  Aroma of cocoa powder.  taste has pepper, coffee grounds, chocolate syrup.  Nice.
On tap.  High carbonation but very drinkable.  A lot of rye and it tastes a bit smoked.  Not much fruit but some type of candy sweetness.
Tomthompson’s bottle,  A dark body, above average mouthfeel, a sipper of chocolate, coffee, spruce, pepper.  Cross-style with a shwartzbier. Wonderful aroma.

Pours dark reddish black,  tan head.  Aroma has notes of rye spice, fruity esters, some tiny bit of funk, and earth.  Taste is nice and refreshing, nice balance of rye spice with the fruity and earthy saison notes, finishing dry and spicy.  Nice beer.
12 oz bottle.  Poured brown with a small off white fizzy head.  Smells of fruity candy and bubble gum.  Flavors of bubble gum, sweet light fruit, some fermented dark fruit, brown sugar, and vanilla.

12 oz pour at Captain Mike’s in Kenosha, Wi.

It poured into the snifter a dark dark brown, pretty much back, with a frothy off white head. There is some lacing as it recedes.

The smell is spicy, there is a lot of clove and some dark malts.

The taste is pretty spicy. Tons of white a n black peppery notes, some clove, some cocoa, and some dark fruit

This is something like what Fantome is doing, but much cleaner. It isn’t bad.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-09-2010 20:47:25

Marvin’s, DC tap ($9): Pours a mahogany color with a brownish head that leaves some lacing. By the looks of this, I wouldn’t have known it is a saison. The aroma is of spice, some butterscotch, a wee bit of smoke and some yeast. The taste is pretty good, but again I wouldn’t have guessed a saison could be like this. In any case, like many Belgian inspired American ales there is a little bit of hops. Good amount of spiciness and some minor malty sweetness. An interesting and somewhat unique beer.

Draft at high di ve. Pours a black color with no head. Some faintly on the tp left. Smells of roast malt and lemons. Tasye is smoke. Toasty and lightly sweet. Very interesting saison from goose island

Very belgiany, cannot taste the peppercorns, very smooth and tasty, not complex though, worth a try

Retaste: Not a very good saison yet an interesting beer. The roastedness of the malts slightly overwhelm the light flavors of the saison style. Very delicious light porter. Lawlerskates.

Location: Draft at RnH, 2/19/11
