Aroma: The nose has some spice, yeast, floral hops, roast, and earthy notes


Appearance: The pour is fairly black with a lasting beige head atop it


Flavor: The taste is sweet and spicy with a light hoppy presence as well


Palate: The carbonation is average to lively, feels dry on the mouth and fairly clean as well


Overall Impression: 
I took jcos on his first trip to Rattle ’N’ Hum, and we had quite a few interesting beers there.  This was one of them, and I’m pretty sure I enjoyed this one a bit more then he did.  Overall, I found this to be a fairly solid dark saison that I enjoyed drinking.
Sweet aroma. Sweet and lightly tart taste with a fruity dunkelweiss-like flavor. Tastes like a dunkelweisse except a tad less fruity and with a drier finish. Nice dark saison.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep red brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is heavily yeasty with bubble gum and spices being the main aromas, a touch of red apple and molasses in the distance.  Bubble gum leads the flavor as well, leading into a more earthy, nutty malt base with some peppery herbal flavor and red apple.  Quite a nice rendition of a dark saison.

Pours dark mahogany with a medium head. Really takes its time to recede, the bottle conditioning really shows.  Lacing is thick and sticky.  The nose is full of spice, yeast, peppery, rye.  The rye is the first thing you notice on the palate, then the estery yeast notes, and the hint from the peppercorns on the finish. The roasty notes are kind of obscured behind the rye, yeast, and pepper, but they’re there. Dry, but not bone dry, just fairly devoid of sweetness.  This is an interesting brew, not wholly up my alley, but it gets points for being a bit unusual and unique.

12 oz. Bottle, 
this beer has a brown-black pour, and made a half finger head of light tan colored bubbles that deflated quickly,  
left nice spotty lacing on the glass when swirling the glass, and there was a very thin film of light colored sediment in the bottle, 

the aromas were earthy malt and roasted malt with a faint smoke aroma in the background,  

the flavors were of roasted malt with a hint of dry chocolate, earthy and dark malt in the background, a little dark malt-dark bread like sweetness that lasts just for a moment on the palate, finish has some malt flavor trailing with some dryness, 
and there is a little pepper spice at the finish to, 

mouth feel is about medium, and does not feel like a traditional Saison, 

an ok drink, I was expecting a little more from this beer.

Thanks to whomever brought this to Beachwoodshop

This was a nice beer to try. I liked how the pepper complemented the other flavors of the beer.
Yummy - a dark dry saison with just a tiny bite at the end.  Had this last season and was excited to see it back at the bar!

(12oz bottle courtesy of jcnd9803!).  Pours cola color with thin off-white head.  Aroma of candied sugar, belgian yeast and spice.  Taste is malty sweet with a slight punch of spice.  Medium bodied with a creamy texture.  Fizzy on the tongue.  A pretty tasty beer!

A different, interesting Saison. On draft at Rattle & Hum. Pours dark, looks almost like a porter or stout.  Nose is heavily on malt and roasty.  Quick finish. Interesting beer, but I prefer a traditional Saison.

Bottle thanks to someone. Pours with a black body and a tan head. Aroma of peppers, apple, spice, saison yeast, rye and elderflowers. Flavors are a bit watery and bitter. Floral and peppery. Good. Lively and dry.

Pours brown with a chestnut color and small beige head.  The aroma has estery banana, toasty malt, nutty Belgian brown ale malt, fruity yeastiness and some black pepper.  It has a medium crisp grainy body with somewhat harsh carbonation.  The flavor starts very peppery and spicy along with figs, dates and the rest of the aroma traits with a sour slant.  The finish is malty, spicy and dry.  Good beer, but not quite what I expected.
Blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah.  I’ll update it later.
Pours a dark brown color with thin light tannish head.  Aroma of light fruity, clove, light peppery spice, and roasted malt.

Bottle. Deep translucent orange-brown body, thick creamy beige head. Interesting nose, leathery and spicy with clove, banana, dark fruit, brown sugar, and toast. Estery, fruity body, with pepper, clove, dark fruit, berries, and brown sugar, slick, sweet, and somewhat salty/tangy. Medium-bodied with fair complexity. The sweetness is a tad cloying, but overall this is an enjoyable beer.

Bottle.  Bottled on:  01/03/11.  Pours a dark mahogany with a thick beige head.  Some sweet caramel, brown sugar, oranges, lemons, citrus rinds, bananas, cloves, nutmeg, and pepper in the aroma.  Goes down medium to full-bodied with a crisp bite.  Mildly sweet upfront with some toasted caramel, brown sugar, and bananas.  Some oranges, lemons, and rinds in the semi-bitter finish.  A peppery bite at the end.  Cloves, nutmeg, a yeastiness, and a moderate amount of warming alcohol throughout.  Very tasty.

Tap. Deep dark brown with a tan head. Light sourness in the aroma, with some yeastiness and roast as well.  Flavor is also slightly sour, some dark fruits, spice, and roast.  Lighter body with tiny, bubbly carbonation.  Not bad, just doesn’t really come all the way together for me.

This was a nice black ale. It is a saison style which had many spice and flower notes in the aroma but had a nice pour that laced all the way down. Taste was smooth with a bit of malting and an even hop palate. Enjoyable.

Bomber bottled on 01/07/11 (1139), here on Valentine’s Day 2011.  Nose is sour and tangy, floral and acidic and dusty.  Chocolate porter pour with a tiny-bubbled tan head.  Strong floral bolt with sweetish malt and pepper, has a nice ashen aftertaste that is unpredictable from the smooth chocolate up front, just rich and viscous and a round, sumptuous full body.  Just an amazing mouthfeel, probably top 5% of all the beers I’ve had.  Velvety roast is interesting here, not rough at all and the smoke is faint.  Sticky, rich malt with just a hint of citrus zinging through the fudgy clouds.  Don’t think I would have pegged this as a saison, but no matter -- it’s intense and flavorful, but more importantly, very balanced and even-handed.  Massive success, and at this low alcohol level, something I’d drink a lot more of if given the chance.
Deep brown pour with a tan head. Aroma is malt, pepper, a touch of smoke. Flavor is peppery and smokey. Interesting beer.

Poured into a tulip.

4.0 A: Deep mahogany brown color. Two fingers of creamy light brown head withe average retention and a healthy ring of lacing.

4.0 S: Belgian yeastiness and peppercorns are most dominant. Lots of black pepper spiciness, followed by clove phenols, followed by some light banana esters. Earthy and dry with a light roastiness.

4.0 T: Taste is full of pepper and clove. Good amount of yeastiness. Banana fruitiness again with hints of plum and raisin as well. Again this is earthy, mildly burnt and roasty, and fairly dry (though much sweeter than the nose suggests).  A touch of rye spiciness. Good here.

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good spritzy carbonation in appropriate amounts. Reasonably creamy and overall pretty smooth with a slight charred aftertaste.

4.5 D: Good beer. I decided to give this a 4.5 for drinkibility because a lot of the above scores could have easily be the next highest. Good flavors and interesting. I would like another, but I only have this one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-10-2011 00:37:45

very dark brown pour appearing black in the glass with a medium off white head.
aroma is coffee, roasted malt,  some wheat tones. 
flavour is roasted malt, light smokiness to it. a lemony saison fruitiness in there as well.

Draft at Cincy Winter Beerfest.  Aroma is roasted wheat, toasted malts, and yeast.  I get notes of black pepper, smoke, lemmon, and some other spices.  Flavor brings out a bananna type flavor, finnishing dry.  Not bad.
Dark brown color with a large head.  Spicy aroma, plenty of yeast and light brown sugar.  Yeast and spice ditto for flavor.  Light bitterness and floral hop taste.  Thick body.

22 ounce bottle, bottled on 1/7/2011.  Served in a tulip, the beer pours dark brown with about an inch tan head.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  Aroma is peppery spice, roasted malt, chocolate, and some bananas and dark fruit.  The brew tastes like roasted and charred/burnt malt, bananas, peppery spice, bittersweet chocolate and a bit of dark fruit.  There’s also a slight bitter roasty/burnt finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, it’s a bit creamy and silky and has good carbonation.  A little too much carbonation for me, but that’s not a big deal.  Drinkability is good, it’s smooth and enjoyable.  I think it’s a solid overall brew, it’s definitely worth a try.  I liked it.

Bottled 1-7-2011. Pours a very clean, deep black color with a tall, tan head with a very strong staying power. Aroma has a strong saison sweetess with some light estery presence. A nice roasted kiss is present with a a peppery note that resides in the back of your throat after a sniff, kinda like when you sniff some fresh ground pepper. Flavor starts off with an awesome saison sweetness combined with a light peppery kick and smooth roasted malt presence. The middle has more of a Belgian ale yeast sweetness too it, similar in yeasty character as Matilda. It finishes with a peppery, light black malt roasted presence. Body is pretty light with a semi-crisp feeling, lower carbonation and not much alcohol detected at all. Very good brew as the back of the throat peppery flavor really compliments the light roasted and saison light sweetness.

bottle.   pours like a porter.  peculiar roasty stout saison mixture.   initial aromas of roasted coffee,   dates, doughy figgy pudding, black pepper, and raisins.   taste is roasty, light smoke, herbal.   spices.  if you want a rustic, old world saison, this may not be your thing.   at times the roast and earthy herb combo seemed a bit muddled.   good carbonation.   refreshing, easy to drink.  bit of an identity crisis, but overall better than expected.

Bottle.  Pours a dark crimson brown with a large lightly tanned beige head.  Spicy rye and some caraway notes up front, nice big Belgian yeast phenolics.  Medium bodied, sweetness up front before lots of spicy rye and peppery yeast take over, very smooth and well structured.  Nice yeast notes throughout, finishes up with some more phenolic yeast notes, and a slowly warming alcohol note.  Nice stuff.

Bottle; Pour is Dark brown with a frothy beige head. Retains fairly well - Nice lacing in this snifter. I’m going to give them some credit for trying something different (for me). It’s an odd feeling to get that belgian yeast/fruit ester aroma on a beer that looks like this one. What the hell. The beer pours a little over carbonated, in my opinion. The roasted malt profile is muted, overall, when compared to the typical saison characteristics. "Pepper spice" are certainly on the muted side as well, however. This is a decent brew, for sure -

Enjoyed at the mega Whole Foods in Chicago, IL while getting some pizza.  Appearance pure oil black with thin off white head that laces to the glass.  Aroma coffee and chocolate, not very pungent, nice.  Taste of chocolate, brewers licorice, pepper-y, a bit of alcohol, very thick, a little carbonation, feel slightly bloated while drinking it.  All in all pretty good and unique, wasn’t really expecting it.
Solid. Roasted cloves/peppercorns, good carbination & mouthfeel. I enjoyed this beer thoroughly.
Draft at Beer kitchen. Dark brown and amber color with a small offwhite head and lacing. Light fruity aroma and sweet malt. Darker malt shows up in the flavor. Tasty.
Poured into a tulip.  Pours a dark cola color.  Tan head.  Aromas of yeast and malt.  Medium body.  Taste malt with some spice.  Not a much carbonation as the typical saison.  Easy drinkability.

12oz Bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee.  Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is yeast, bread, and a hint of pepper.  Light to medium on the palate with above average carbonation.  Flavor is pretty mild...some of the familiar Saison flavors...spicy, yeast.  Not much rye or peppercorn.  An ok beer.

On tap at the Sanctuary. Very dark, thin brown head. It’s a subtle beer. Some fruity esters to it, a bit of spiciness. I wouldn’t really call it a saison (closer in character to a dubbel, but thinner). Intriguing, but not great.
a generous bit of rye and smoke and pepper in a hoppy concoction that is dark. interesting spiced up brew that bleeds through to the body. demonstrative.

Bottle.

A - Dark cola brown with a healthy, creamy, thick, full, off-white head. Really nice retention with a very nice creamy lace.

S - Strange aroma. First whiff I did get some of the hay and floral type of saison aroma (not really funky/barnyard though). Next whiff I get some spice with pepper, rye, and clove along with some roasted malt and chocolate. Hints of banana that along with the dark flavors, resemble a dunkleweizen.

T - Not really all that much like a typical saison flavor. Spiced with a lot of rye, clove, and roasted malt/chocolate. Pepper is definitely present but it’s not a peppery saison like I was somewhat expecting. A good amount of earthy flavors and a faint phenol hint. Interesting and fairly spiced although I would probably say more earthy than spicy, but definitely not what I was expecting.

M - Medium body with average carbonation. Slightly crisp and dry.

D - Not exactly what I was expecting from a saison, just a little too earthy and slightly spicy to be all that drinkable. Glad I had one, but probably wouldn’t really want to drink another right after.

Notes: Bottled 01/03/11. Interesting beer, not quite what I was expecting and doesn’t seem entirely focused but it was good and definitely has some potential. Not really like a saison with roasted malt, chocolate, rye and earthy flavors being strongest. Worth of try and it is good, but it could be better.

2011 bottle.  Pours dark red and brown, ruby red along the edges, with a slight haze and a small off-white head.  Spicy Belgian yeast dominates the aroma, with accompanying bubblegum, slight lemon peel, raisin, and cocoa.  The flavor is sweet fruit and slightly tart yeast, raisin, and bubblegum, with a slightly spicy, citrusy finish.  Medium carbonation and medium to full body, with a lightly warming quality.  This is sweet, smooth, and overall good, although I would have liked a little more heat/spice from the peppercorns.

First off, this is a beautiful beer. Don’t let anyone tell you otherwise. It’s a pretty reddish brown and fairly clear. The head is just amazing. I don’t think I’ve ever seen a more tenacious, thick and evenly bubbled head on a beer w/o nitrogen enhancement. The texture is really nice too, quite as creamy as the appearance applies. The yeast character here is quite spicy and it tastes of juicy bananas. I am not sure this is a siason as Goose Island claims. To me, it is is just a plain old Belgian ale. It veers more toward richness rather than light drinkability. Even so, it is quite good and I’m thoroughly enjoyable.

Draft at ginger man with Linh. Pours the darkest body of any saiskn I’ve ever seen, leaving me questioning whether they gave me the right beer. Aroma is sweet notes, wheaty, and slight roast. Mouthfeel is smooth and balances with notes of wheat, funk, much more Smokey and roasted flavours.

Bottle, thx tarheels. Pours black with a nice frothy chocolate head. Aroma is belgo yeast, smoke, dark malts, dark fruit. Flavor is oily, smoke heavy with pepper and a dry finish. Mouthfeel is light. I see what they are going for but comes off unbalanced.

On tap at Red’s Alehouse.  Nice funky, spicy saison aroma.  Waitress brought a jet black beer to the table, figure there was a mistake since I ordered a saison.. But, no mistake.  Nice thick head which dissipates after a few minutes to a thin tan layer, good lacing.  Medium body with good carbonation.  Flavor is roasty, some pepper and spice, bit of the usual saison funk.  Very drinkable beer.

651mL. Pours a near jet black with a healthy tan head. Very healthy retention and lava/obsidian formations on the sides of the tulip comprise sticky lacing. Aroma is all saison yeast: pepper, melons, durian, a little meaty, lime, sweet kumquat. Very on target for saison despite its stout like appearance. The taste up front is light and fresh with not too much character. Slowly you can pick out some plastic phenols and then some peaty, smoky flavors. There is a bit of a burning plastic, peat, soap, and smoke character I would compare to Islay scotch. But overall it comes off a bit watery and eventually lavender soap dominates. Carbonation is wildly soft. Palate is oily, coating like a stout and finishes pretty quickly with some suddy soapiness and herbal/floral notes. When I think black saison I can only envision some of the odd Fantome creations that are really hit or miss. This has wicked potential but perhaps needs to be a little higher gravity and be attenuated a little be less to give a smidgen of sugar body. Still, this was a great idea and executed with precision from a brewery that has gone from decent to world class in the past couple of years.

Draft at Red’s. Poured an opaque black color. The head was tall and light brown with good retention and lacing. Smelled of pepper, subdued clove, roast, and a bit of sassafras. Medium bodied and sweet. Spicy, roasty, chocolatey flavors. There was also some cola. Lower carbonation. Pretty good stuff.

Pour is a black but you can see through it.  Aroma is kinda roastey with an earthy peat with some sweetness.  Flavor is the same, some earthy malts with a sugar sweetness and a creamy yeast.  Decent but nothing really great and deffinatly no Sofie.

12 oz. tulip glass from the tap at Bigelo’s.  This beer pours as black as a stout with very little red.  A small off white head.  A unique aroma.  Pepper, black licorice, roasted notes, and yeast.  That black pepper is retained in the flavor along with the yeast.  Some interesting fruit and an occasional taste of hop spice, and a bit of coffee.  An active feel.  Unlike anything I have had and pretty good, too.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of rye bread, cocoa powder, light roast, and a touch of funk.  Flavor shows the same with a hint of coffee.  Overall body is light to moderate, and finish
is dry.  Can you say dark session beer??
Dionysus hooks it up! Dark brown pour, tan head.  Molasses, rye, bread, and dusty yeast.  Flavor is a remarkable blend of spice, yeast, light funk, bread.  Good stuff...no great!

22oz btl. Pours a deep medium bodied brown with a finger of off white head. Not a lot going on in the aroma obvious rye, some powdery chocolate. Rye bread, some chocolate, a mildly dry with a bit of bitterness. A little boring.

12 oz bottle. Pours deep brown with a glowing red. Aroma is very basic. A bit of grain and rye, very soft and simple, some roastinesa. Flavor starts with some dark fruit and raisin. Picks up some woody and earth hop notes to a dryer abd toasty finish. NOt bad

Dark brown pour with tan head, somewhat murky.  Aroma of pepper, some roast and smoke character.  Some fruity belgian esters, specifically a banana note.  Earthy.  Flavor is earthy and smokey, the spicy rye pairs with the pepper notes from the yeast.  The dark malts brings out some coffee and roast.  Very dry, well carbonated.  Very nice.

Had on tap at Holy Grale. Pours very dark with ample brown to light brown head. Aroma is a little earthy, a little roasty. Taste is very interesting, with hints of the rye, the roasted malts, and some spice, the only significant clue to this brew’s saison heritage. Finishes with roasty bitterness that ends cleanly.

Draft at Blind Pig Co. in Champaign, IL. Pours a deep brown with a tan head- WAIT! A saison? Aroma of nutty malts and faint Belgian esters. Lighter side of medium bodied with average carbonation. Flavor of chocolate, very mild coffee, and wheat malts countered by a slight phenolic tang. Finish is a tad medicinal. Interesting, but really struggles for identity.

Pours a milky brown with a nice head and some lace. 
The aroma has a bit of chocolate and a nice light fruitiness. Some of the peppery notes show through the aroma and there is a light earthy presence. The flavor is very bready like a nice loaf of country bread with some snappy peppery character. There is a mild bit of fruit in here as well.


Subtle and awfully nice.
On tap at El Bait Shop. Not much black pepper. Nice brown ale malts. Dry. Everything I love about brown ale, dubbel, and saison all mixed nicely together.

Tap on GI night at el Bait Shop. The body is deep rusty brown with a thin yellowish khaki head. The nose has some sweet grass, hay and a hint of the pepper. There is also a little bit of tropical mango. The taste is orange peels and bitters. There is also a little tang along with bread crust. I get just a whiff of black pepper in the finish.

I got to try this rarity on tap at the Goose Island Invasion at International Tap House-Chesterfield.  Pours a dark, cloudy brown color with a minimal off-white head.  Aroma of earth, chocolate malts, toast, farmhouse funk, and Belgian yeast.  Flavor follows suit mostly, with a lot of the same earthy character found in the nose along with some overripe fruits.  However, the mouthfeel was oddly metallic, which kept this from being a lot better.  Medium-bodied, with low carbonation.  I had higher hopes from Pepe Nero, although it’s still a pretty good beer.

32oz growler pours a watery, translucent black with some light, white head.  Nose is bread, yeast, spice with some nice malts.  Flavor is sweet, malty, light spice, yeast, bananas.  Finish is medium bodied and sweet.

32oz growler, thanks nimbleprop.  Clear brown body topped by medium beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, roast, some smoke, light caramel.   Taste is medium sweet, spicy/rye, some smoke, light chocolate.  Medium body, low carbonation.
Dusty aroma with some spice, clove, and smoke.  Slightly smoky flavor with cherries and some spicy rye on the finish.  A little bit of funk.
Roasty chocolate nose, some smoke, some dark fruit. Taste is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, some chocolate, light roast, light smoke, some raisins> Finishes with a bit of chalk.

On tap at Clybourn location: Pours a barely transparent dark mahogany with a spotty-lacing beige head.  Aroma of roasty dark biscuity malt with some fruity esters and faint peppercorns.  Starts with pretty good fullness and fine carbonation with a nice light sweetness and doughy Belgian yeasty complexity before a drier finish with some lingering peppercorn flavor.  A pretty true to style and unique brew.

Tap at Blind Tiger.  Deep brown pour with a tight tan head.  The nose is lovely.  A light spicy yeasty component behind a kiss of toasted cocoaish character.  A little bit herbal and a little bit spicy as well.  There is a distinct citrusy twang on the back.  Fairly bright and the dark malts on the back remind me a little bit of some of the black IPAs that are out there.  The combination here works pretty well.
World Cup Beer tasting at Lazy Boy Saloon beer #12.  A nice ruby brown color.  Tastes of wheat and spice.  there are hints of dark fruit and overall its kinda sweet.

Tap at gi clybourn... Pours a mostly opaque chocolate brown with lighter hues at the edges and topped with a light beige head... Aroma of soft grains, grapes, and darker unripe fruit with a tinge of a sweet malt undertone... Flavors were an amalgamation of the same, not quite put together with an emphasis on toasted malt, a caramel middle, dark fruit, and a slight bitterness in the finish.

Draft. Pours brown with a medium, tan head. Aroma is fruity with hints of yeast and spices. Flavor is sweet and fruity with sugary, peppery, and malty notes and some nuts, rye, yeast, and caramel as well. Light bodied and medium carbonation.

On tap at World of Beer.  Poured cloudy medium brown with a nice beige head.  The aroma picked up sweet chocolate and biscuity malts with lots of earthy accents.. well-balanced and enjoyable.  The flavor found chocolate, caramel, and bready sweetness at the core with lightly-sour earth and fruity notes around.. dry, dusty yeast throughout.  Medium-bodied with ample carbonation.. a touch too sweet, but overall a solid drinker.
pours black with a thin off white head.  sweet yeast aroma. taste is excellent with notes of vanilla, cherry, lemon and sauvignon blanc.  finish is dry and tart.

toast, hay, roasty, herbs, leather, banana, earthy, smoke, red, brown, black, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, paper napkin, medium body, thick feel, creamy, soft carbonation,

Tap at Blind Tiger. Poured a rich and deep mahogany brown with a thin beige head. Nose is sweet candied sugars and dark fruit. Dark farmhouse ale? Ok. An interesting style, and a good beer. A nice combination pfndark fruits and Belgian yeast. Not that dissimilar to a strong ale,on thenfruitu side. Some sweetness,and some lightly roasted malts. Finish is sligtlu acidic.

Tap at BT.  This one was a winner, maybe only becuase it was on tap next to thier lex raspberry saison which sucked.  Pours a deep dark brown amber with a nice lasting head.  Aroma is spicy earthy toast, ryebread, light burnt notes phenolic spicy salty yeast and light doughiness- some black pepper and light cardamon come out as it warms.  Flavor is light sweet chocolate cake, with hints of mint chocolate?  Strange but good in that respect, then the mint goes with the grassy herbal phenolics, and a drying leather feel in the back of the mouth- clean dry and spicy in the end.  Nice.

Draft. Pours deep dark ruby brown with a beige head. Sweet toffee-esque malty aroma with a dark fruity sweetness. The flavor is a bit busy, with toffee, toast, and some fruity/spicy notes. Definitely different, not that bad.
Draft. Weird.  I mean it was a dark saison, of course it was weird.  Sort of like a dunkel or something.  Interesting but don’t want another.

[Darft @ WaCo] Hazy brown color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus, toast, rye, and a bit of caramel sweetness.  Taste was citrusy, some tart wheat, spice, and light sweetness, dry finish.
Tap. Cloudy brown pour with thin off-white foam. Roasted nuts, chocolate and spice.  Did not taste like a saison...

On tap at Rattle n Hum

Aroma soft nose, grainy , hint of wheat and fruit , flowery medium softness.6+

 Appearance  comparing to aroma uneventful dark appearance, hint of ruby red .Light top.

Flavor and Palate : mid bodied , blend of darker roasted ale with lighter easy going saison here. Personally I don’t like this combination. It is messy and confused.

On tap at the Sunset Grill in Boston. Pours quite dark cloudy amber with foamy head.  Bready yeast and sweet malt aroma, with some spicy notes. Flavor a bit floral with noticeable yeast, dried fruit, citrus and spices. Lingering slight aftertaste.
Draft at Rattle.  Poured into a goblet.. black in color.  Taste is sweet, yeasty, a bit dry in the finish.   Some peppery notes to couple.
Draught at Sycamore. Black and dark. Malty. I don’t know who called this a saison. More like a light Quad. Yeast gives in the Belgian taste, but not a saison.

Tap @ the Foundry next to McCoy’s Publick House.  Comes in a tulip glass with a nicely long lasting, medium thick brown head.  The beer is black in color.  The rye aspect comes off nicely in the beer as it warms.  A very earthy, dry, and strong, almost pumpernickel character comes through that I attribute to the rye.  In general, it is safe to say I get black rye bread.  Unfortunately, all this does is mask an industrially-stripped Saison that is underneath.  The base Saison is missing any nuance or subtlety of a fine style of beer.  Its light in body, slightly tart in the finish but in general empty of anything that brings a Saison to life.  Its limp, comes off as industrial grade but with cloak of rye to cover up that which is blatantly missing from the style.  Its black rye with limp beer underneath.

opaque with excellent foam cap and moderate lacing.  aroma is roast sweetness and beginnings of yeast influence.  lips and glass become sticky from resident sugars, flavor produces unsweetened cocoa and more yeast.  lips hop/booze sizzle, mouth soft clinging roast.  yeast cuts through it and keeps it interesting.

Tasted on draft at Bad Apple.  Pours almost black with a tint of amber.  The head is thin but long lasting and off-white.  Nose of rock candy, yeast, some breadiness, and both light coffee and coconut.  Flavor is very light considering the color with citrus, candy, black pepper, yeast and bread.  The dark malt comes through on the back with coffee and chocolate.  Carbonation and body are both fairly light with a long, dark finish.  Overall, this beer is good but not great.

On tap.  Poured a cloudy brown color with a thin layer of off-white foam.  Spotty lacing.  The aroma was definite roasted malts and even some chocolate with a touch of yeast.  The flavor was mostly roasted malts and light chocolate cut with some spices and yeast.  Thin to medium in body.  Tasted more like a Belgian ale than a saison to me.

Draft @ Coles in Buffalo NY> Darker cola colored pour. Aromas of dried fruit, almost aventinus like, black pepper, raisins, cloves. Taste is peppery, sweet malts, minor maltiness & clove. Different & pretty enjoyable

Original Rating (5/3/2010): On tap at the Flying Saucer in KC. Pours a deep brown body with a finger-width, creamy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is fairly spicy with a light sweetness. Pepper, rye, earth, and some roast along with a Belgian yeastiness. Some caramel, berries, and a faint citrus. Flavor is similar. Spicy, yeasty, estery, and a light malty sweetness. The roast comes out just a touch at the end with a nice peppery rye and earthy, spicy finish. Dry with a light bitterness and a medium length aftertaste. Body is fairly light and almost thin at times, but very easy drinking. Light carbonation and mostly clean. Overall, a cool beer. Lighter with a nice spice and estery, yeasty fruits. Not bad (7,4,7,3,14=3.5). Re-rate (10/7/2012): 12oz bottle with a bottled on date of 01/02/11. Pours a glowing, very deep brown colored body with a bit of a ruby hue around the edges. Finger-width, creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is big estery, berry dark fruits up front with a lightly spiced, Belgian yeast. Some bready malts with a light sweetness, a touch of peppercorn, and just a hint of toastiness. Flavor is similar. Estery dark fruits up front with a lightly spiced Belgian yeastiness. Lightly sweetened bready malts in the middle with a touch of caramel, a light earth, and a few floral peppercorn notes. Finishes somewhat dry with a light, peppery spicing and a good amount of dark fruit esters. Fairly lengthy aftertaste following a medium body and a moderately lively carbonation. Overall, this is a pretty old bottle, so I’m going to keep my original rating. The berry esters have really picked it up a lot over the 2 years since this was bottled and the peppercorn has faded. Not worth holding onto for so long.

Tap @ Sugar Maple some weeks back.  Pours to a dark brown body with a quickly dissipating tan head.  The aroma has a light chocolate and earthy yeast.  Flavors of chocolate, bananas, and earthy yeasts.  Yellow raisins and dark stone fruits.  Palate is clean even with the heavy texture.  Effervescent.  Black pepper.

(tap at Acadia) Pours black with a white head that retains.  Aroma of funk, mushroom, roasted malt, light chocolate, and some spices as well.  Taste is lightly funky, roasted malt, with some flavors of smoke and chocolate.  There is black pepper present, but it’s very subtly integrated and only present on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is lively.  Sounded good, but was ultimately forgettable.

On tap at hopcat. Murky brown body with beige head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, clove, chocolate and spice. Flavor is more subtle than expected. Chocolate, spice, banana, and herbal elements. A bit weaker than I was hoping

On tap @ Old Chicago. Pours ahazy brown with a nice tan head. Aromas of chocoate, rye, Belgian yeast. Flavors of rye, dark chocolate, and various spices (black pepper?). I had no idea what this was when I ordered it, but it turned out to be very good and rather unique.

On tap at hopcat.

A: Pours a muddy murky shade of brown with an above average tan head. Little retention and no lace.

S: Aromas of chocolate malt, belgian yeast, spicy rye, and clove.

T: Dark malts with chocolate standing out with hints of roast. The Farmhouse yeast and spices are there with roast and white pepper.

M: Medium in body, subtle carbonation.

D: Pretty good. Unique take on the style.

On tap @ RevBrew.  I didn’t know what I was ordering - but it ended up being a good choice.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of rye, spices, and belgian yeast.  Interesting beer - spices and rye actually blend alright with the Belgian yeast - good beer.

Tap at Sugar Maple. I had no idea what this beer was before purcasing, but was not disappointed.  Pours hazy light brown.  Roastiness mixed with fruity belgian yeast, banana/clove, and chocolate in the aroma.  Flavor has the nice wheat and rye components and finishes with roasty, chocolatey bitterness.  This actually reminds me a little of a slightly lighter version of NG Black Wheat.  Great dark beer for warm summer days.

Sampled at the GI FIP (Chicago, IL). Pours a very dark brown, murky, with a decent offwhite head that laces well, stays a thick film. Aromas are fruity, pear and banana pear with a touch of black pepper, white pepper, belgian yeasty spice. Not any sense of dark malts. Initial is a bit darker, mellow sweetness with a light spice, apple and grain paired with faint pepper, Belgian yeast, a touch of spicean darker malt males an appearance. Very nice.  Mellow sweetness, fruit, light spice. Finish is lightly sweet, clings to the palate, pleasant and highly drinkable. Tasty, can’t say much bad about it at all.

On tap at Charlie Orr’s Maple Tree Inn in Blue Island.  Goblet shows off this brews pretty deep brown color and fluffy white head.  The nose is saison spicy and sweet.  Flavors of black pepper, rye, citrus, yeasty fruitiness, cuurants?, moderately roasted grain, and refreshingly active carbonation.  Very unusual recipe and results, well worth seeking out and repeating frequently!

Draft at Maple Tree Inn. Pours black/brown. Nose is really interesting with black pepper and rye notes coming through. Also pick up banana and citrus, a bit of mustiness. On taste, some light roast comes through but is washed out by the esters thrown from the yeast. Distinct GI saison character with light citrus and peppery notes. There is actually black pepper in this one and it is noticeable, layering complexity. Nice.

On tap at Brixie’s in Brookfield, IL. for their Spring Tasting, and served from pitchers. The color was a hazy, dark brown, with decent, off white foam to the head, and web-like, clingy lacing. The aroma was roasted malt, dark coffee, with light peppery/dry notes. The flavor added a low hop bitterness and continued the peppery dryness into the finish. The carbonation was low, and probably due to the pitcher serve. A nice style variation that I will definitely try again.
Tap. Very interesting. Black pour with a minimal white head. Thinner body. Nose is roasted malt, almost coffee-like, yet the Belgian spice and yeast is there too. Quirky and cool.

Draft at Blind Tiger, i do hope this is a new beer and not the Black saison at 6.2%.  Pours a black body with an off white head.  Earthy with citrus rinds, spicy earth y herbal tones and a dash of pepper and rye.  Roasted malt with a mild smokiness and a slightly sweet citrus and rye finish.  Nice.
